DOC.HEAD: New Governor Not Alarmed At Budget Deficit
DOC.TEXT: Gov.-elect Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said Wednesday Connecticut's budget problems may get worse and he is weighing all options, including tax increases, to deal with a $2.1 billion shortfall. ``I'll have to study it,'' said Weicker, a former three-term U.S. senator. ``We'll get whatever job has to be done, done,'' Weicker said. ``I think it's clear to anybody that sacrifice is going to be required in some form and I don't want to go ahead and state what the sacrifice is going to be until I understand the full dimensions of the problems.'' The $2.1 billion gap between spending necessary to maintain current services and income from existing taxes represents 30 percent of the current $7.05 billion budget. Retiring Gov. William A. O'Neill, who decided not to seek re-election this year, had said he could not see how the next governor could balance the budget without raising taxes. He reiterated that stance after a meeting with Weicker Wednesday. ``I think that's going to be very difficult if not impossible,'' O'Neill said of avoiding tax increases. Weicker was to be provided budget details Thursday. State law requires that the governor present a balance budget each year and the Legislature approve a balanced spending plan. Weicker said he was ``not taken aback'' by the size of the deficit estimate. ``The recession we're in has accelerated at a rate far exceeding any predictions,'' he said. ``It could very well get even worse.'' Weicker will be inaugurated Jan. 9.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Endowment Panelists Resign to Protest `Decency' Standard
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Monday correct in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Nine members of a literary panel of the National Endowment for the Arts resigned to protest a new congressional edict that federally subsidized works must meet ``general standards of decency.'' ``We deplore the implied threat of censure and attempt to constrict freedom of artistic expression and the rights grantd by the First Amendment,'' they wrote in a joint letter Monday to NEA Chairman John E. Frohnmayer. The nine resigned from an 11-member NEA panel of outside experts that judges grant applications from small, independent presses, literary magazines and non-profit organizations that distribute contemporary literary works. Last year, on the basis of the literary publishing panel's recommendations, Frohnmayer approved 99 grants totaling $1.4 million. Frohnmayer said resignations were ``premature'' and ``unfortunate.'' He predicted the endowment would find a way to implement the new law in good faith without stifling artistic creativity. The protest seemed largely symbolic. NEA spokesman Josh Dare said the panel was effectively dissolved when it completed its work on 1989-90 grant proposals last December. A new panel - minus the nine protesters - will convene Nov. 26 to review next year's grants. The nine said they resigned over a new congressional requirement that the NEA chairman ``shall ensure'' that grants are made ``taking into consideration general standards of decency and respect for the diverse beliefs and values of the American public.'' Congress tacked those restrictions onto the endowment's current $174 million budget shortly before it adjourned Oct. 28. The curbs replaced a much stricter obscenity ban that covered NEA grants last year. This year, Congress said only that obscenity ``shall not be funded'' by the NEA and that obscenity judgments should be left to the courts. Even though the new curbs are milder than the former ban, they nevertheless set ``a very scary precedent,'' said Jennifer Moyer, former chairwoman of the NEA's literary publishing panel. ``If there are any restrictions on freedom of expression, it's unacceptable.'' Ms. Moyer, a poet and literary publisher from Mt. Kisco, N.Y., resigned along with eight others representing writers, editors, publishers, booksellers and arts administrators on the panel. In a separate letter informing Frohnmayer of her resignation, panelist Helaine Harris, a bookseller from Hyattsville, Md., asked how the endowment can distinguish between ``decent or indecent art'' under the new law. ``I feel that I can be a judge of artistic merit, but I don't feel that I should pass judgment on decency,'' she wrote. ``I refuse to be a part of this self-censorship process.'' The other panelists who resigned were Michael Anania, a poet, fiction writer and teacher from Chicago; Denise Chavez, a Houston writer; Katharine Harer of Berkeley, Calif., director of a distributing company for small literary presses; Brooks Haxton, a poet and teacher from White Plains, N.Y.; poet Susan Howe of Guilford, Conn.; Peter Meinke, a writer and director of a literary workshop at Eckard College in St. Petersburg, Fla.; and E. Ethelbert Miller, a poet and teacher at Howard University in Washington D.C. The two panelists who did not resign were Anne Bourget of the California Arts Council in Sacramento and Beverly Jarrett, editor in chief of the University of Missouri Press at Columbia, Mo. Ms. Jarrett, who will serve on the newly formed literary publishing panel, said she refused to resign because it ``seemed like throwing the baby out with the bath water'' at a time when the NEA deserves support for helping the arts survive. Ms. Bourget did not return repeated telephone calls seeking her comment.

DOC.HEAD: National Geographic Unveils Massive New Atlas
DOC.TEXT: ``If you don't know where you are, you're nowhere.'' That's the word from National Geographic Society President Gilbert M. Grosvenor who unveiled a massive new book Tuesday that shows where everywhere is. The $18 million, 405-page, sixth National Geographic Atlas arrives in a world undergoing change. And that change made compiling the new book exciting, confusing, taxing and costly, say its editors. ``Producing this new atlas was like covering a breaking news story ... It's been a scramble,'' said William Graves, editor of National Geographic magazine. Changes such as the merger of East and West Germany and North and South Yemen - and the potential for other changes - nearly delayed publication and resulted in some unexpected costs. For example, on Sept. 21 the German embassy called to inform the society that the new united Germany had chosen Berlin as its sole capital. That call cost the Geographic $100,000. Officials thought they had taken every precaution. They printed all the physical maps first, then the less controversial political maps. Germany, in the process of merging two nations into one, was left for last. But finally the Geographic had to go ahead. The editors took a chance and designated two capitals: Bonn and Berlin. But the Germans outfoxed them by choosing to have just one. The presses ground to a halt. The map of Germany and some of the text was changed. And on Tuesday, when the society unveiled the result, its newest world atlas showed only Berlin as the German capital. Wary of further potential changes, in the Soviet Union for example, Grosvenor said buyers of the $74.95 book will be entitled to two updates over the next three years. Those would be supplements, but Grosvenor said the exact form they take will depend on what changes they reflect. In addition to the traditional maps, the new volume has a number of satellite images, including an unusual world map showing all land areas virtually cloud-free. That map was compiled from thousands of pictures collected over several years by National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration satellites. Then the best cloud-free images of each part of the world were pieced together to form a giant world mosaic. ``It's an image of the Earth as we've never seen it before,'' said Grosvenor.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Postal Contract Offer Divisive, Union Leader Says
DOC.TEXT: The Postal Service is trying to ``pit worker against worker'' by offering cash bonuses but no hourly wage increases, the president of the largest postal union contends. ``It's just a massage piece designed to divide us,'' Moe Biller, president of the American Postal Workers Union, said Tuesday as thousands of unionized postal employees held a rally at a Washington hotel. The Postal Service and its four largest unions, which together represent 660,000 workers, are in the midst of negotiations to replace contracts that expire Nov. 20. Biller called management's latest offer, which has not been publicly outlined by the Postal Service, ``a piece of garbage designed to pit worker against worker.'' Postal Service spokesman Michael West said: ``We have negotiated at the table and not in the press. ... At least for now, we prefer to leave the specifics on the table.'' Biller said management had offered the 234,000-member National Association of Letter Carriers a separate pay incentive plan aimed at dividing the two unions, which bargain together although for separate contracts. Biller's union represents 334,000 postal clerks, maintenance employees, drivers and special delivery messengers. Assistant Postmaster General David Charters said the pay-incentive plan was part of the Postal Service's goal of holding the rate of postage increases below the rate of inflation. ``We think incentives to support (that) plan are in order,'' Charters said. Because the agency, no longer subsidized by taxpayers, must break even over time, its board of governors has proposed raising the cost of mailing a letter from 25 cents to 30 cents next spring. The unions have not made a counter offer. Biller declined to say how big a pay increases the unions were proposing or when the proposals would be presented. Letter carriers and clerks now receive a starting salary of around $24,000 and can earn a maximum of about $31,500. Employees receive an additional $8,560 in benefits and premium pay. Tuesday's ``solidarity rally,'' attended by both letter carriers and clerks, was aimed at showing the Postal Service that the two unions would stand together, Biller said. Two other unions also negotiating with the Postal Service are the National Postal Mail Handlers Union, which represents 50,000 mail handlers, and the National Rural Letter Carriers Association, with about 42,000 members. Biller said little progress had been made since the talks began in August. He said he was not optimistic that a deal could be struck by next week. ``Right now, I don't see anything on the horizon,'' he said. But Postal Service officials ``still have hope that an agreement will be reached by deadline,'' West said. Under federal law, it is illegl for postal workers to strike. If a contract isn't reached by midnight Nov. 20, both sides could extend the current contract to give themselves more time to settle the dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Rolling Stones guitarist Ronnie Wood was hit by a vehicle and broke his legs while directing traffic around an accident involving his car. Wood, 43, spent the night in Princess Margaret Hospital in Swindon after the accident Monday. On Tuesday he said he was ``fine and dandy.'' After Wood's wife crashed the family car west of London, the guitarist stepped out to direct traffic and was struck by another vehicle, police said. Police gave no cause for the crash of the Woods' car. Jo Wood and the couple's children Leah, 12, and Tyrone, 7, suffered minor injuries, police said. --- PALM SPRINGS, Calif. (AP) - Sonny Bono says he is exploring a run for U.S. Senate. The pop singer-turned-mayor of this desert community said Tuesday he is contemplating a run in 1992 for the seat held by Democrat Alan Cranston. Cranston, who is battling prostate cancer, has said he won't run again. Bono, a Republican, was the ``I Got You, Babe'' teenybopper idol of the '60s and the butt of former wife Cher's gibes on their TV show in the '70s. ``I'm sure there's going to be some staunch Republican conservatives who ... may view me as a rock 'n' roller,'' Bono said. ``I'm going to have some things to confront that may be difficult from an image viewpoint. ``Hopefully, we can flip the coin on that.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Linda Ellerbee, who left NBC in 1986 after it canceled her ``NBC News Overnight,'' may return in a daytime information series. She has taped a pilot for the show, she said Tuesday. She declined to comment further. After leaving NBC, she was co-anchor of ABC News' ``Our World.'' The show was dropped after one season. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Delta Burke is again accusing the producers of ``Designing Women'' of picking on her. In an interview with Barbara Walters to be broadcast on ABC tonight, a tearful Miss Burke reopened the feud with Linda Bloodworth-Thomason and husband Harry Thomason that flared over the summer. Miss Burke said the producers of the CBS series were upset with her weight gain and threatened to replace her as the shallow, sharp-tongued Suzanne Sugarbaker. ``I do not want to be squashed down on the floor like I don't matter, or have no brains and nothing I say means anything,'' she said. The Thomasons did not respond to repeated calls Tuesday but denied Miss Burke's allegations of mistreatment earlier this year. Despite the furor, Miss Burke said she wants to stay on the show. ``I would like it to work better with everyone, but I have to be recognized and I have to be acknowledged,'' she said. --- NEW YORK (AP) - President Bush, Ronald Reagan, Jimmy Carter, Gerald Ford and Richard Nixon will be among recipients of the Ellis Island Medal of Honor. The medals honoring representatives from various ethnic backgrounds will be presented Dec. 9 at Ellis Island in New York Harbor. The winners are selected by the National Ethnic Coalition of Organizations. The medals were last awarded in 1986. Other recipients announced Tuesday included Frank Sinatra, songwriter Paul Simon, former congresswoman Barbara Jordan, Cincinnati Reds manager Lou Pinella and sportscaster Phil Rizzuto. --- HOUSTON (AP) - Paul McCartney's birth certificate is for sale and could fetch $20,000, the auctioneer says. Auction house owner Ray Simpson said Tuesday he examined the paper, stamps and certification language and concluded it's the real thing. The birth certificate was sold to an American investor by the former Beatle's stepmother, he said. ``I have no doubt about it at all. It is absolutely unconditionally guaranteed,'' he said. The certificate shows that on June 18, 1942, at 107 Rice Lane, James Paul McCartney was born to James McCartney, a ``centre lathe turner (aircraft factory),'' and Mary Patricia McCartney of 10 Sunbury Road, Liverpool. --- ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. (AP) - Little Richard says he'd like Michael Jackson to play him in the movies. Eddie Murphy, he says, isn't good looking enough. The 57-year-old piano-pounding rock 'n' roller will be in Atlantic City on Saturday for a one-time appearance at Trump Taj Mahal. He said he is looking for a record deal and negotiating to create a syndicated variety show. He also is planning an autobiographical movie. ``I want to see Michael Jackson as me,'' he said. ``There was talk that Eddie Murphy would do it, but I think he would talk too nasty, say things that don't need to be said. And he's not good looking enough to be Little Richard.'' Little Richard, whose hits include ``Long Tall Sally,'' ``Tutti Frutti,'' and ``Lucille,'' doesn't jump around the stage as he once did, nor does he indulge in the drugs, liquor and frequent sex with both men and women that twice led him to leave rock 'n' roll for gospel, in 1959 and in the mid-1970s. ``I think everything is under control at this age,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``We don't have to pay tolls, we just sing with a lot of soul, but we are still bold. ''

DOC.HEAD: Panel Recommends Splitting Budget Office Due to HUD Failures
DOC.TEXT: The White House and Congress share blame for allowing scandal and mismanagement to go unchecked at the Department of Housing and Urban Development during the Reagan administration, a Senate panel concludes. In a report Tuesday, the investigative panel recommended a series of reforms, including splitting up the White House's Office of Management and Budget to create a separate office to monitor management of federal agencies. ``HUD mismanaged programs either because it opposed the program itself ... or because it lacked the capacity or leadership to operate them free from abuse,'' the investigative subcommittee of the Senate Banking Committee said. ``Unfortunately, the various parties responsible for oversight were all negligent, including HUD itself, OMB and the Congress.'' Sen. Bob Graham, D-Fla., chairman of the panel appointed to handle the Senate's inquiry into the $2 billion HUD scandals, said the White House budget office under President Reagan gave little scrutiny to required management reports and acted on none. ``There's a need for more emphasis on the management side of OMB,'' Graham said in an interview. ``OMB has become essentially a budget office. ... They completely collapsed. They became a filing agency - not hardly reading and certainly not acting on the reports.'' ``Almost every safety net ripped and let HUD crash to the ground,'' he said. The report blamed Samuel Pierce, HUD secretary for all eight years of Reagan's term, for a hands-off management that fostered abuse. It blamed Congress for ignoring warnings of management problems and for holding no oversight hearings on the troubled department. It said the Senate failed in its confirmation responsibilities by allowing the Reagan administration to fill the agency's top ranks with political appointees who had little interest in housing. Only two people nominated for HUD positions during the 1980s failed to gain confirmation, it said. The panel recommended creation of a federal advisory panel to evaluate future HUD political appointees and report to the Senate on their worthiness. Graham compared it to the American Bar Association's review of judicial nominees, which the Senate considers before confirming judges and justices. The Senate panel focused on structural flaws that permitted the scandals. A separate House investigation focused on personalities in the scandal and received far more public notice. Most of the subcommittee's findings were approved unanimously. The ranking Republican, Sen. Connie Mack, R-Fla., disagreed on splitting OMB. He also opposed creating the confirmation advisory board and the panel's recommendation that HUD's staffing be increased. Graham said he would sponsor bills to implement the report. Congress created the White House budget office and could change it by law, or the president could take executive action on his own, he said. Among the panel's other recommendations: -HUD's assistant secretary for administration should be a career employee, not a political appointee. HUD should report to Congress on other positions that should be reserved for career staff. -Senate hearings should be held to receive each report of the HUD inspector general, the secretary's semiannual report and other required HUD management reports. -HUD should increase its monitoring of subsidy programs to eliminate excess subsidies for specific projects, which were revealed in the HUD scandals. It should overhaul its calculation of fair market rents. Graham said he concluded the HUD scandals were in part due to a deliberate effort by the Reagan administration to fill the agency with people who weren't competent and had antipathy for the department's mission, resulting in failure and discredit falling upon housing programs. The panel did not allege illegality, but Graham said he believed there ``may be some examples of perjury'' in reports Pierce made to the president and Congress on management capability as required by law. The report cited a 1987 HUD document stating that its financial management controls were adequate. ``At the same time,'' the report said, ``HUD management knew that serious problems existed with HUD's accounting systems'' and that the Federal Housing Administration's accounting systems failed to meet accepted standards and were deemed unauditable. Pierce, who is under investigation by the special prosecutor, has denied any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEAD: Clerk in President's Copter Unit Faces Murder Sentence
DOC.TEXT: A former civilian clerk at the Quantico Marine Base will be sentenced Jan. 9 for killing a Marine corporal in an attempt to hide her role in an alleged embezzlement scheme involving the helicopter squadron that serves President Bush. Markeithia R. Reeves, 24, of Suitland, Md., on Tuesday entered a so-called Alford plea, in which a defendant does not admit guilt but acknowledges that the state has enough evidence to convict. She faces a maximum sentence of 20 years to life in prison. The plea was accepted just before Reeves was to begin her first-degree murder trial in the death of Cpl. Estella Pearson. Pearson, 26, a Quantico clerk whose responsibilities included reviewing travel vouchers, was found shot to death March 5 in her car in a shopping center parking lot. A second defendant, Tania T. Morton, 23, of Arlington, Va., a former Navy civilian clerk, is scheduled to go on trial Tuesday. Following Reeves' plea in Prince William County Circuit Court, prosecutors called two witnesses to the stand to substantiate the case against her. According to testimony, Pearson was killed shortly after it became apparent that travel vouchers were being falsified involving members of the Quantico-based Helicopter Squadron One, which transports the president and other government officials. Secret Service agent Robert Turner testified that 44 U.S. Treasury checks totaling $33,000 with endorsements that had been forged had been traced to Reeves and Morton. Reeves worked in the same department as Pearson and was responsible for preparing travel vouchers for employees going on temporary assignments. Turner said Pearson's supervisor asked her to verify several suspicious travel vouchers. ``Markeithia saw this,'' the agent told The Washington Post outside the courtroom. ``Then she started to realize they had caught on.''

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Activist Vows Not to Change
By PHILIP BRASHER
DOC.TEXT: A Senate employee had a warning for Paul Wellstone when he walked into the Capitol for the first time since unseating Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn. ``Senator, this place changes people,'' the worker told him. ``Remind me some time, if I'm changing,'' Wellstone replied. Wellstone, who has never held public office, arrived for two days of orientation sessions Tuesday, intending to live up to his advance billing as an aggressive, articulate spokesman for liberal causes. ``He didn't seem to be intimidated at all,'' Sen. Tom Daschle, D-S.D., said after an organizational meeting that was the first chance for many senators to see and hear Wellstone. ``I'm going to roll up my sleeves,'' Wellstone said. ``I'm very serious about public policy. I also have a mandate to be outspoken. That's the way I am. I want to enjoy myself here. I don't want to change.'' Wellstone, the lone Democrat in the 1990 class, was the only Senate candidate in the country this year to defeat an incumbent. The other senators-elect - Republican Reps. Hank Brown of Colorado, Larry Craig of Idaho and Robert Smith of New Hampshire - won open seats. Wellstone is a short, balding 46-year-old, a former state campaign manager for Jesse Jackson and a political science professor on leave from Carleton College in Northfield, Minn. Boschwitz aides dismissed him as an ``Abbie Hoffman-type character'' and the incumbent outspent him 7-1 in the campaign. But Wellstone crisscrossed the state in a rickety converted school bus and captivated Minnesotans with his high-energy style, self-deprecating humor and infectious enthusiasm. He also drew attention for a series of offbeat TV ads that exploited his underdog status. One was a breakneck parody of a candidate's day in which he said he had to talk fast because he had little money. Another followed the frustrated Wellstone trying to find Boschwitz at offices all over. He called for national health insurance, universal health care, deep cuts in military spending and big increases in education and nutrition aid. ``Because of the deficit we've built up, the kind of agenda I believe in, which is kind of a human capital-people agenda, can't happen right away,'' he said Tuesday. Wellstone, however, can't wait forever. His promised after the Nov. 6 election to serve only two terms. ``I think I can make a difference,'' he said. ``I really believe there will be big changes in our country in the '90s. I think that people are ready for change. If that's the case I'll be a strong force for it.'' Wellstone introduced himself at the Democratic Senate caucus Tuesday. ``He talked about how he hopes the Democrats will stand up for the things they believe in,'' said Daschle. ``I think he's going to be a welcome addition to the caucus.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said Wellstone ``will be a valuable, productive and contributing member of the Senate and will represent the people of his state fairly and effectively and vigorously.'' But first, more mundane matters beckoned, such as getting into the Capitol, bidding for committee assignments and learning who people are. ``What I'm most nervous about is that I hope everybody has name tags,'' Wellstone said. ``Otherwise I'm going to go up to somebody who I should know and say, what is your name? And it turns out to be the Senate majority leader or something like that.''

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Slain After Killing 11 In Shooting Rampage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with gunman dead. Picks up 12th pvs, `They had ...'
DOC.TEXT: In a tiny seaside village, police on Wednesday fatally wounded a gunman they said killed at least 11 people in a shooting rampage that was New Zealand's worst massacre, officials said. Police said 33-year-old David Malcolm Gray, who had fled to a house on the village's northern edge after being driven from his own, had been shot in the chest and ankle, and also suffered a head wound. At about 5:45 p.m., police lobbed smoke grenades into the house and stormed it, ending a 21-hour ordeal that wiped out nearly half the population of the village of Aramoana. Black-clad officers, some with ski masks, had stormed Gray's house nearly two hours earlier but found it empty and began a search. Police originally said Gray was being airlifted by army helicopter to nearby Dunedin. Later, they said he had died of his injuries. Aramoana, which had a population of 25 before the rampage, is about 17 miles north of Dunedin in rugged country on New Zealand's South Island. Victims of the massacre included a 6-year-old boy who had rode his bicycle up to the gunman's house to see what was happening, and a police sergeant from nearby Port Chalmers whose body was found in dunes outside of town. Bodies lay strewn about outside Gray's house and a neighboring home that he had set on fire when the rampage began Tuesday night, said Dunedin police Sgt. Bill O'Brien. Police had been unable to check if the victims were still alive for fear the gunman might open fire. Gray had been holed up inside his home for much of Wednesday, firing indiscriminately, they said. About 140 police, including an anti-terrorism squad, had poured into remote Aramoana after the shooting began. Police spokeswoman Kaye Calder said police found a .22-caliber rifle, an air rifle and 9mm ammunition inside Gray's home. Residents who had been trapped in their homes since the onslaught began were finally evacuated aboard a navy training vessel, the HMNZS Moa. They had spent a terrifying night huddled on the floors of their homes as gunfire punctuated the silence. The worst previous worst massacre in New Zealand occurred in 1941 when Eric Stanley Graham killed six police officers before being shot dead. The rampage started Tuesday evening when Gray, who apparently lived alone, set his neighbor's house on fire and began shooting at firemen and residents who approached to put it out, according to neighbors. O'Brien said police were mystified as to what sparked the incident. ``We don't know why he has done this,'' he said. Aramoana is among cliffs and sandy marshes in an isolated area across Otago Harbor from Taiaroa Head, a famous albatross colony that attracts birders from around the world. Dorothy Crimp, 74, who lives across from Gray's house, described him as ``a very quiet chap, a real loner.'' ``I have met him on the beach - he never spoke to anyone.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Stop Reservist's Deployment to Middle East
With PM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. troop buildup in the Persian Gulf poses a ``difficult legal question,'' says a federal judge in refusing to bar the Army from sending a reservist to Saudi Arabia without a formal declaration of war. U.S. District Judge Royce C. Lamberth rejected a bid Tuesday by Army National Guard Sgt. Michael R. Ange for a temporary restraining order to stop his deployment to the Persian Gulf. ``If I gave your soldier a TRO, I would have a few others in here tomorrow,'' Lamberth told Ange's lawyer, Michael Ratner. The judge scheduled a Dec. 10 hearing on Ange's request for a permanent injunction. The case ``does pose a difficult legal question'' about President Bush's power to send troops to a combat zone without a congressional declaration of war, the judge said. Ange's lawsuit was filed as two key Republican lawmakers, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole of Kansas and Richard Lugar of Indiana, former chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, urged Bush to seek congressional authorization for the U.S. military mission in the Middle East. Ange contends that Bush has not gotten the authorization from Congress that is required by the Constitution. Ratner, an attorney for the Center for Constitutional Rights, also argued that the order to deploy Ange violates the 1973 War Powers Act. ``There has not been sufficient congressional consent, or any consent, to the military activities at issue,'' Ratner argued. The Constitution makes the president commander-in-chief of the armed forces, including National Guard troops called into federal service, and gives Congress the power to declare war. The War Powers Act requires the president to notify Congress of any substantial new deployment of forces overseas, and requires him to win congressional approval or withdraw troops within 60 days if he sends them into combat or into situations where hostilities are imminent. Ratner said the buildup of 230,000 U.S. troops in the Middle East - plus Bush's order to send up to another 200,000 - creates the likelihood of war, which must be declared by Congress. ``How does a court decide that hostilities are imminent?'' Lamberth asked. ``The record here is nothing has happened since August, except a few minor incidents.'' Ratner said the suit also seeks Ange's return from the Middle East if he is sent there, the lawyer said. Ange is a former Beaufort County, N.C., police officer now studying criminal justice at Appalachian State University in Boone, N.C. He was ordered to active duty Oct. 10 with other members of the 1450th Transportation Company. ``When we volunteered we swore to defend our country and our constitution,'' Ange told reporters at Fort Lee, Va. ``We did not swear or agree to fight ... to defend economic interests of major oil companies.'' At Tuesday's court hearing, Justice Department attorney John Tyler urged Lamberth to stay out of the growing political dispute between Congress and the president. ``Congress is not without power. This is a political debate. It belongs in the political arena,'' Tyler said. Courts have been extremely reluctant, on the grounds they lack jurisdiction, to uphold lawsuits challenging troop deployments.

DOC.HEAD: North Dakota Farmers Sell Bread For a Nickel
LaserPhoto BI1
DOC.TEXT: A nickel will get you a loaf of bread this week in North Dakota, where farmers are demonstrating against wheat prices they say are forcing them out of business. Members of North Dakota's Farmers Union are selling 5-cent loaves in every county, usually outside the courthouse where farm foreclosures take place. Some customers are needy and come to buy bargain bread. But most just want to show they support the farmers. ``It appears the crisis in agriculture is getting to be a pretty severe problem, and as a banker I see more severe problems in the future if they don't get their point across,'' said James Helgeson, who was among the customers Tuesday. Wheat prices have plummeted because of a worldwide glut. A nickel is roughly the price farmers get for the wheat in a 1{-pound loaf of white bread that sells for $1 to $1.25 in stores, farmers say. They receive slightly more than $2 per bushel for that wheat - about $1 less than last year and the lowest price in nearly five years. To dramatize the problem, the farmers are selling store-bought loaves by the score. ``We're discovering that there are some really hungry people in our major cities,'' said Karl Limvere, a Farmers Union spokesman. ``It shows the irony, that farmers can't make any money from their production and yet we have hungry people.'' In Benson County, the farmers bought 100 loaves from the rural county's only bakery and sold them under gray skies that some called ``foreclosure weather.'' ``I think perhaps it should have served as an eye-opener to a lot of people, as far as the disparity of prices,'' said James Wang, a county state's attorney who bought a loaf. Farmers took a blow under the new farm bill sent to President Bush, which cuts $13.6 billion from farm programs. The Farmers Union wants price guarantees for family farmers and an increase in the amount farmers can borrow from the government to pay their bills. Albert Maruggi, a U.S. Department of Agriculture spokesman in Washington, said Tuesday, ``We're doing what we can to continue to push U.S. wheat sales.'' He said USDA has favored a market-based policy that promotes wheat exports. Gov. George Sinner proclaimed this Farm Income-Rural Crisis Awareness Week. The state has struggled through drought the past three years and has lost 6,500 farmers in the past 10, he said. ``In North Dakota, net farm income has fallen by 60 percent during the past decade,'' the governor said. Farmers reeled off other statistics: In 1980, 172 bushels of wheat paid for a refrigerator that cost $809. Ten years later, they said, the cost of that refrigerator has dropped to $712, but 282 bushels are needed to pay for it.

DOC.HEAD: Water Supply for Some Communities Contaminated by Pesticides
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of American communities get drinking water from wells that contain unhealthy levels of pesticides and nitrates, the Environmental Protection Agency says. A survey of 1,347 wells in 50 states indicates that fewer than 1 percent are contaminated from pesticides to levels that are of concern, the EPA said Tuesday. About 2.5 percent of the wells have nitrate levels considered worrisome, the agency said. Nevertheless, those wells provide drinking water for millions of people, EPA officials said. While the ``vast majority'' of the country's drinking water wells don't pose a risk to public health, the findings provide an ``early warning sign that this needs to be taken seriously,'' said Henry Habicht, the EPA's deputy administrator. Environmentalists cited the survey as further proof that the nation's groundwater is being contaminated by chemical runoffs from agriculture and other sources. Nitrates come largely from fertilizer and sewage. Ron Phillips, a spokesman for the Fertilizer Institute, said the survey confirms that ``at least 96 percent of our groundwater is perfectly safe.'' He disputed that the levels of nitrates found in some of the well water should be of concern. The EPA survey covered both private wells and wells that feed community water systems. From the results of the survey, the agency estimated that about 10.4 percent of all community wells nationwide and 4.2 percent of private wells likely contain at least some pesticides. The survey also indicated that more than half of the nation's wells have water contaminated with nitrates from fertilizer, sewage sludge or septic tanks. Although in most cases the contamination was at levels too low to be a health concern, the EPA said as many as 750 community water systems may have wells that have pesticide or nitrate contamination exceeding federal health guidelines. It estimated that nearly 80,000 private wells in rural areas also likely have unhealthy levels of contamination. Many of the pesticides found in the drinking water are suspected of causing cancer or damage to vital organs if consumed at significant levels over a long period. High levels of exposure to nitrates can cause ``blue baby'' syndrome in very young infants as well as other illnesses. ``The EPA survey reinforces existing strong evidence that nitrates are contaminating groundwater,'' said Justin Ward of the Natural Resources Defense Council, a Washington-based environmental group. The NRDC and other environmentalists, however, said the EPA findings may understate the seriousness of the problem in some regions of the country where pesticides and nitrogen fertilizers are heavily used. They criticized the EPA's use of national contamination estimates that include parts of the country where there are few pesticides or nitrates to contaminate wells. The EPA's Habicht said there likely are regional ``hot spots'' where a significantly higher percentage of wells are contaminated. He said the EPA planned to further examine the overall findings to focus on regional problem areas. The agency provided no estimates on water contamination by regions or states. The community water systems included in the survey ranged from those that provide drinking water to very small towns to others that serve densely populated urban areas, including mid-size and large cities. Many of the country's largest cities rely on surface water for drinking rather than groundwater from wells. The two most frequently detected pesticides found in the well water were dacthal, a broadleaf weed killer used primarily on lawns; and atrazine, a widely used weed killer used in agriculture, especially on corn and sorghum, the EPA said. Dacthal and nine other pesticides were found at low levels not considered a health threat. But atrazine and five other pesticides, including some that have been banned by the EPA, were found at levels considered a health concern.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Overhauls Second Tier of Senate Leadership
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Restive Republicans elected conservatives to second-echelon Senate leadership posts in secret balloting that signaled more combative GOP dealings with majority Democrats in the next Congress. In their organizational caucus Tuesday, the GOP senators re-elected Minority Leader Bob Dole of Kansas and his chief deputy, Alan Simpson of Wyoming. But in contests for four second-tier party leadership posts, conservatives held sway over more moderate colleagues. Dumped from the Republican Party's No3 leadership job was Sen. John Chafee of Rhode Island, the most liberal Republican in the Senate. Republicans voted 22-21 to replace him with conservative Sen. Thad Cochran of Mississippi. Democrats, meanwhile, re-elected Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell of Maine and chose Sen. Wendell Ford of Kentucky to succeed Alan Cranston of California as assistant majority leader in a caucus that produced no surprises. Ford had been assured of election when Sen. David Pryor of Arkansas decided not to challenge him. The move to the right among Republicans held throughout the closed-door voting on three other open posts in which no incumbents were seeking new terms. Sen. Don Nickles of Oklahoma defeated Sen. Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico for the chairmanship of the Republican Policy Committee. Sen. Phil Gramm of Texas beat out Sen. Mitch McConnell of Kentucky for the job of campaign chairman. And Sen. Robert Kasten of Wisconsin was elected secretary of the Republican conference over Sen. Christopher Bond of Missouri. ``I don't think you should read into the election any kind of statement about ideology or statement that we are tilting one way or the other,'' Cochran told reporters. ``It may be they just wanted a change,'' Chafee suggested. But Sen. Malcolm Wallop, R-Wyo., who backed Cochran, said, ``It was just more Republican.'' This year, Chafee voted to override President Bush's veto of the civil rights bill, voted against a constitutional amendment to ban flag burning, voted with liberals on restricting aid to El Salvador and voted to cut funds for the Strategic Defense Initiative, or Star Wars. The party caucuses came a week after a disappointing GOP performance in the off-year elections. The party lost a Senate seat when it had hoped to pick up a couple and position itself to retake the chamber in 1992. The Democrats picked up a net of nine seats in the House. Many congressional Republicans also were angered when Bush reversed his no-new-taxes pledge and agreed with Democrats on a deficit-reduction package that included major new taxes. Norman Ornstein, a congressional scholar with the private American Enterprise Institute, said the GOP leadership election was a signal to Dole and Simpson ``that it's time to get tougher with the president. They (rank-and-file Republicans) wanted high-energy, rock-the-boat leaders.'' He said Chafee and Domenici were ``two extraordinarily well-liked and well-respected moderates, but they were defeated by more conservative and more junior upstarts.'' Conservative fund-raiser Richard Viguerie compared the Senate elections to the atmosphere that caused Georgia Rep. Newt Gingrich's rise to House Republican whip two years ago. Cochran is a mild-mannered conservative who in 1978 became Mississippi's first Republican to win election to the Senate since Reconstruction. ``He's like a fire ant,'' said state GOP chairwoman Evelyn MacPhail. ``He never goes into anything unprepared. He does his work quietly.'' Gramm was likely preferred over McConnell because the Texas senator is more combative and more likely to succeed in money-raising efforts, GOP officials said. The Democrats, who will hold a 56-44 majority in the 102nd Congress, emerged from their closed-door caucus with a show of unity. All of the top jobs were filled without contention, Mitchell said. Mitchell, who first won the majority leader's job two years ago in a spirited three-way race, won his second term by acclamation. Health care and campaign finance reform are tops on his list of legislative objectives for the new Congress, he said. Cranston, 76, has served since 1977 as the assistant majority leader, or whip. He announced last week he was stepping down from the post, and would leave the Senate at the end of the next Congress, because of prostate cancer. Cranston is one of five senators under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee for their involvement with former savings and loan operator Charles F. Keating.

DOC.HEAD: Prospects Uncertain for Regulatory Action on S&L Favoritism
DOC.TEXT: A newly released report alleges favoritism in the government's past handling of some shaky savings and loans, but regulators haven't decided whether to pursue the matter. The document indicates that federal regulators gave preferential treatment as far back as the mid-1980s to some ailing S&Ls whose executives sat on a regional regulatory board. The report, made public Tuesday at a hearing by the House Budget Committee's Task Force on Urgent Fiscal Issues, names several S&L executives who allegedly received favorable treatment from the Federal Home Loan Bank in Dallas. But regulators said they haven't decided if they will take action against those executives or the federal S&L examiners who allegedly favored them. ``This has come to us off the wall,'' Thomas Mason, a spokesman for the Office of Thrift Supervision, said of the new revelations. Mason said the OTS, the agency that took over S&L regulation from the Federal Home Loan Bank system, has ``no idea'' at this point whether it will pursue action against the people involved. At the hearing, Rep. Charles E. Schumer, D-N.Y., said the favoritism indicated by a 1988 government review of the Dallas Home Loan Bank discouraged bank examiners and slowed recognition of the magnitude of the S&L crisis. ``Sirens were sounding in the basement of the (Federal Home Loan Bank Board) throughout 1988, but the regulators just plugged their ears,'' said Schumer, who chairs the Budget Committee task force. The task force released a summary of the 1988 review of the Dallas bank board, which was responsible for regulating S&Ls in Texas, Louisiana, Arkansas, Mississippi and New Mexico. Like home loan banks in other regions of the country, the Dallas institution was controlled by S&Ls that it both supervised and loaned money to. The review of the Dallas bank by an outside ``peer review team'' of government examiners indicated that senior federal S&L regulators knew losses were deliberately concealed by the thrifts with the approval of local examiners. It also found conflicts of interest that resulted in preferential treatment for some S&L executives who also were directors of the Dallas bank. In one case, local examiners removed an auditor who questioned the chairman of an Arkansas S&L who was a director of the Dallas bank, according to the task force document. M.R. Godwin, chairman of First Federal Savings of Arkansas, had been accused of defrauding shareholders. The Dallas bank board ``had been more interested in helping a fellow director'' than in removing Godwin from his First Federal post to protect shareholders, the document said. It said preferential treatment also apparently was given to: Allan D. Myers, chairman of Olney Savings Association and a director of the Dallas bank; Shelby Smith, a director and former employee of the Dallas bank; Robert Mettlen, a director of Lamar Savings Association and a former director of the Dallas bank; and James Ward, chairman of Commercial Federal Savings Bank of Louisiana and a director of the Dallas bank. The review found that the Dallas bank failed to do financial examinations of nearly 200 S&Ls in a timely manner. It said the Dallas regulators delayed taking some supervisory actions and failed completely to take others. It also accused the Dallas bank board of: -``Terrible'' monitoring of S&Ls' financial condition. -Approving excessive pay and bonuses for S&L executives. -Weak supervision and inflated financial ratings of S&Ls in the face of ``tremendous growth, high-risk lending, poor capital and insider abuse.'' -An overly bureaucratic, multilayered decision process that slowed proper supervision. Another spokesman for the Office of Thrift Supervision, William Fulwider, declined to comment directly on those findings but said the system has improved greatly since S&L bailout legislation was enacted last year. ``There has been a decided move to improve examination and supervision'' of S&Ls, Fulwider said. He cited stricter capital requirements for S&Ls, regulatory action against conflicts of interest, and an increased number of federal examiners. Bailout legislation passed by Congress last year to rescue the S&L industry could ultimately cost taxpayers $500 billion, according to some estimates. The legislation transferred regulation of S&Ls from the Federal Home Loan Bank system to the OTS, a new unit of the Treasury Department.

DOC.HEAD: US, European Community to Step Up Talks on Farm Subsidies
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and European Community leaders say they'll intensify the search for a solution to a farm subsidy battle that threatens to derail four years of talks on a new global trade agreement. Bush met Tuesday with Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, head of the community's council of ministers, and with EC President Jacques Delors. Delors planned to continue the talks with other administration officials today, but there was no hint that a breakthrough was imminent. The United States is seeking to eliminate 75 percent of current domestic farm supports and import barriers and to reduce export subsidies by 90 percent. The European Community, with its network of heavily subsidized small family farms, has labeled the Bush proposal politically unrealistic. The EC wants to trim 30 percent of 1986 farm supports - which the United States says would be only a 15 percent cut from current subsidies - while leaving the import barriers and export subsidies untouched. The farm issue is considered central to completion of the current round of global trade talks, which involve 105 nations under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Thousands of farmers from France, Germany, Italy and Switzerland demonstrated Tuesday in front of GATT headquarters in Geneva, contending that the U.S. proposal threatened their livelihoods. Bush has made GATT reform his top trade priority in a belief that lowering trade barriers offers the best chance of expanding U.S. exports to reduce America's huge trade deficit, which has topped $100 billion for the past six years. Without agreement to cut farm subsidies, Third World countries say they will not go along with U.S. proposals to tighten copyright protections for American companies and reduce barriers keeping U.S. service companies - such as banks and insurance firms - from expanding their overseas operations. Bush, addressing Andreotti during a White House departure ceremony, said both sides had expressed a ``strong conviction that we must succeed in substantial trade liberalization.'' Bush said he and the EC leaders had agreed to ``make every effort to insure the round concludes in the coming weeks.'' Andreotti said failure to conclude the trade talks would ``bring about serious damages'' to the global trading system, especially to Third World nations. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills told reporters Tuesday the administration remained committed to achieving a comprehensive trade agreement during a final round of bargaining scheduled for Dec. 3-7 in Brussels, less than three weeks away. ``The problem is not time. The problem is political will,'' she said. ``We could solve this in three days if we had the political will.'' Senate Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, whose committee would have jurisdiction over whatever agreement is produced, said a recent trip to Europe convinced him that the talks were in ``serious trouble'' with only about a 50-50 chance for success. He said there was significant opposition in Congress as well, noting that 37 senators were sponsoring legislation to remove the fast-track authority that would speed the measure's passage in Congress. ``Any Uruguay Round agreement can be sold to Congress only if the administration shows they have achieved a balanced package that gives Americans greater access to markets abroad,'' Bentsen said.

DOC.HEAD: Anonymous Buyer Snap up Mustang Ranch for $1.49 Million
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service let go of Nevada's oldest legal bordello for $1.49 million at a bankruptcy sale where most of the 1,000 bidders were more interested in nude paintings and other kitsch. The future of the Mustang Ranch remained as clouded Tuesday as the identity of its buyer. Storey County commissioners last month revoked the bordello's permit, vowing never again to endure the ``circus'' that surrounded the place for 35 years. During bidding on the 330-acre property Tuesday, there were no takers at the asking price of $10 million. The winning bid was made by Reno lawyer Victor Perry, who refused to identity the new owner. Perry's brother, Peter, is the lawyer of former Mustang owner Joe Conforte. But Conforte denied he was secretly bidding. ``How can I?'' he asked. ``They've got me handcuffed financially.'' People had expressed interest in the property as a nursing home, halfway house or home for wayward girls, said Dierdre Pagni, IRS manager. She said even a religious group inquired about the property, but she refused to give details. IRS agents padlocked the 104-room bordello Sept. 21, three days after the property owned by Conforte and his wife, Sally, was forced into liquidation. The government planned to apply the proceeds from the sale to the $13 million in back taxes owed by the Confortes. ``My personal feeling is I hate to see this carnival happen,'' Conforte said of the auction. But he took part in the activities, autographing items for buyers. He signed a painting of a partially clad woman bought for $190 by Mary Kay Walker and Bill Davis of San Diego. On vacation at nearby Lake Tahoe, they said they came out of curiosity. ``This is Nevada history,'' Ms. Walker said. A box of six T-shirts bearing a Mustang Ranch logo fetched $105, while a case of pocket-sized ceramic liquor bottles adorned with naked ladies sold for $260. Some of the larger paintings sold for around $2,000 A Reno-area couple purchased a nude portrait for $80. ``I liked it,'' said Marietta Shaw of Stead. ``It was cheaper than the T-shirts,'' said her husband, Michael Shaw. Also on the auction block were boxed condoms and framed posters pointing out the locations of Nevada's legal bordellos. Ray Grimm of Reno offered a successful bid of $395,000 for a 58-acre trailer park in nearby Lockwood. He said he planned to keep the property as is. The Confortes founded the Mustang Ranch illegally in the 1950s. In 1960, local authorities proclaimed it a public nuisance and burned it to the ground. But a decade later Conforte won approval to operate legally, paving the way for legalized prostitution in Nevada.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Appoints First Woman Sergeant-At-Arms
With PM-Senate Leaders
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in its 202-year history, the Senate will have a woman sergeant-at-arms. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, following his party's organizational caucus Tuesday, announced the appointment of Martha Pope to succeed Henry Giugni in the powerful job. The sergeant-at-arms oversees a vast pool of patronage jobs, the Senate's doorkeepers, police and support services for staff. In rare instances, the sergeant-at-arms also is required to arrest senators who fail to respond to roll calls in the Senate chamber, and bring them to the floor to vote. Ms. Pope had been Mitchell's chief of staff. ``Martha Pope's understanding of the legislative process and of the Senate as an institution makes her the most qualified person for this office,'' he said. Mitchell nominated her to the post and she was elected by acclamation by the Democratic caucus. Ms. Pope must still be elected by a resolution by the full Senate in January. Giugni, a former member of the staff of Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, has been sergeant-at-arms since 1987. He is leaving to form his own consulting business.

DOC.HEAD: First Gene Therapy Treatment For Cancer Approved
DOC.TEXT: Cells from a middle-aged man with terminal cancer are being genetically altered at the National Institutes of Health in preparation for the first use of gene therapy in the treatment of cancer. An NIH team led by Dr. Steven A. Rosenberg received approval Tuesday from the Food and Drug Administration to use the experimental gene therapy in patients critically ill with advanced melanoma, a deadly skin cancer. Rosenberg said his team had been poised for the approval and had already been culturing cells from the first patient's tumors. ``Now that we've got approval we will go full speed ahead,'' he said. The still-experimental therapy amplifies the body's own cancer-fighting ability. It uses a type of white blood cells, called tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes, or TIL, that naturally invade and attack tumor tissue. A gene inserted into the TIL cell adds a second natural anti-cancer protein. In the new therapy, TIL cells are removed from a patient's tumor and placed into a culture. The scientists then add to the TIL cells two new genes, one of which makes a powerful cancer fighter called tumor necrosis factor, or TNF. The cells are further cultured until they number in the billions and then are returned to the patient's blood stream. The TIL cells, now carrying the TNF gene, migrate back to the tumor sites. Doctors hope the treatment will bring powerful doses of the natural tumor fighters directly against cells in the melanoma tumors. Rosenberg said the first patient to receive the therapy will be a middle-aged man who is in an advanced stage of melanoma with only weeks to live. Two other patients are standing by and culturing of their cells should start soon. He declined to further identify the patients. The FDA gave the Rosenberg team permission to treat up to 50 melanoma patients using the new gene technique. Once the process is started, the NIH scientists expect to add about one patient a week to the treatment group. ``These are all patients with very limited life expectancy - about three months,'' Rosenberg said. Rosenberg, Dr. R. Michael Blaese and Dr. W. French Anderson have been seeking approval for more than a year to use the gene therapy on patients. The technique was considered by six committees organized by the NIH before the FDA approved it for limited use. Another form of gene therapy was approved Sept. 14 for the treatment of an extremely rare inherited immune system disorder called adenosine deaminase deficiency disease. That study's first patient, a 4-year-old girl, received a transfusion of her own white blood cells after a gene to correct the disorder had been inserted into the cells. Rosenberg has been using unaltered TIL cells to treat melanoma since 1987. But he said the cells seemed to help only about half of the patients and the rest died of the disease. To strengthen the treatment, Rosenberg and his team turned to genetic engineering techniques with the aim of arming the TIL cells with the more powerful tumor necrosis factor. As a marker to monitor treatment, the scientists also put into the TIL cells a gene that is resistant to myacin antibiotics. Laboratory experiments in mice showed that the TIL-TNF cells were very powerful against cancer in mice, Rosenberg said. ``In rodents, the TNF made the tumors go away within hours,'' he said. But the laboratory animals are able to tolerate 40 times more of the TNF than are humans. And, Rosenberg said, it takes a high dose for the substance to kill tumors. The body naturally produces TNF in response to infection. The protein also plays a role in regulation of inflammation and in repairing injuries. However, if TNF is active throughout the body for too long, it can cause shock and wasting. Melanoma is a skin cancer that usually cannot be successfully treated once it becomes widespread. It is thought to be caused by excessive exposure to the sun, particularly at a young age. The disease has been on the rise in the United States in recent years, now striking about 10 of every 100,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up Slightly, Tokyo Stocks Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar erased some of its gains but held its ground against the Japanese yen Wednesday in Tokyo. Share prices narrowed earlier losses but ended lower. The dollar closed at 129.05 yen, up 0.28 yen from Tuesday's 128.77-yen finish. It opened higher at 129.67 yen and ranged between 129.02 yen and 129.80 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 36.23 points, or 0.15 percent, to end the day at 23,937.44. The index, which surged 1,041.87 points or 4.54 percent Tuesday, was a 148.47-point loser at the end of the morning session before shrinking the losses in the afternoon. The dollar opened higher against the yen after speculation that the U.S. Federal Reserve Board would lower interest rates Tuesday failed to materialize, dealers said. But the dollar gradually narrowed its gains as some investors sold back the currency following its initial rise, they said. Toru Kanai, a currency analyst with New Japan Securities Co., said trading was thin because many investors remained on the sidelines in continuing anticipation of the U.S. Federal Reserve lowering interest rates. Lower U.S. interest rates tend to weaken the dollar. Shigeto Yanase, foreign exchange section manager at the Dai-ichi Kangyo Bank, said market players avoided buying yen in part because of rumors linking senior politicians with a stock insider trading case currently under investigation. On the stock market, traders said index-linked large-scale purchase by institutional investors supported the index in the afternoon, traders said. They said the Nikkei's earlier decline was mainly because of profit-taking after Tuesday's sharp advance. The index was unexpectedly well-supported considering the amount of Tuesday's gain, which could have prompted more active selling Wednesday, traders said.

DOC.HEAD: Snoring-Related Breathing Disorder Doubles Risk of Fatal Heart Attack
DOC.TEXT: About 2 million Americans unknowingly suffer from a breathing disorder that doubles their risk of dying from a heart attack, researchers say. The disorder, in which people stop breathing for 30 to 60 seconds or longer during sleep, is most common in people who snore, said Dr. Bernard Burack, a cardiologist at the Montefiore Medical Center's Sleep-Wake Center in New York. ``That doesn't mean everyone who snores is going to drop dead,'' Burack said. But patients with the snoring-related disorder have a risk of heart-related death 2.1 times the national average, Burack reported Tuesday at the annual scientific meeting of the American Heart Association. The disorder is called obstructive sleep apnea. It occurs most often in men, but when it occurs in women it is even more lethal, Burack said. It tends to occur in people who are overweight, have high blood pressure and heart arrhythmias, or rhythm disturbances, Burack said. Daytme sleepiness is another indicator of the disorder, because it often disrupts sleep. The disease is particularly dangerous in people who have atherosclerosis, or hardening of the arteries, Burack said. In a study of 223 patients, Burack and his colleagues found that the patients died at a median age of 61, compared to the national median of 78. Twenty of 35 deaths in the group occurred between 11 p.m. and 8 a.m. During an episode of sleep apnea, the amount of oxygen in the bloodstream plummets. The heart may beat slowly or even stop beating. The heart, already stressed by the lack of oxygen, is further stressed by the abnormal rhythms. Efforts to breathe then produce an overdrive, often triggering rapid heart rhythms. ``That can kick off, in somebody who's vulnerable, a fatal rhythm,'' Burack said. Weight loss can help alleviate the condition in some people, Burack said. Patients can also be fitted with a mask and air pump that will force air into their mouths and keep the airways open during sleep. ``The problem is people don't want to sleep with a mask over their faces for the rest of their lives,'' Burack said. Surgery to remove excess tissue in the throat can sometimes help. In extreme cases, an incision is made in patients' throats that can be fitted with a plug meant to be removed at night. Burack said people who suspect they suffer from sleep apnea should seek treatment in a sleep disorders clinic.

DOC.HEAD: Widely Available Heart-Shock Devices Could Save Thousands
DOC.TEXT: Almost two-thirds of the 300,000 Americans who drop dead suddenly each year from cardiac arrest might be saved if automatic shocking machines were made as common as fire extinguishers, heart specialists say. Catastrophic disturbances in the heart's normal rhythm - what doctors call sudden death - account for about half of all heart disease fatalities. Shocking the heart with a machine called a defibrillator can restore normal beating. But the shock must be delivered within five minutes, or the victim will die or suffer brain damage. ``This is an immense problem,'' said Dr. Douglas P. Zipes of the University of Indiana. ``In terms of numbers, it far outstrips everything else, but it's a solvable problem.'' Zipes and other experts outlined the need for better and faster care of cardiac arrest Tuesday at the annual scientific meeting of the American Heart Association. Defibrillators have long been standard equipment in hospitals for reviving patients whose hearts stop beating. But since most such attacks occur outside the hospital and without warning, highly automated devices have been developed that can be used by people with relatively little training. Dr. James Atkins of the University of Texas in Dallas said only 5 percent to 15 percent of ambulances across the country carry these devices. The machines can sense whether the victim's heart is in fibrillation - quivering, disorganized beating that fails to pump blood throughout the body. And if it finds this condition, it delivers a shock that can restore normal beating. Even when ambulances and fire trucks carry the machines, getting them to the victim in time is extremely difficult. Atkins said that in the best of cases, ambulances often need five minutes to drive to the emergency, and they lose an additional minute or two setting up the defibrillator. By that time, it is probably too late to save the patient. Dr. W. Douglas Weaver of the University of Washington said that even if all ambulances carried the machines and they responded quickly, at best they might save one-quarter of patients in cardiac arrest. Several experts agreed the best solution is easy-to-use defibrillators that are stored in office buildings, stores, sports arenas or wherever large numbers of people gather. ``We need to make devices that are cheap and idiot-proof,'' said Zipes. ``They need to be as common as fire extinguishers wherever there is a congregation of people. They could be snatched off the wall, patches applied and then let the device do the work.'' Current devices, while relatively simple, still require some training to operate, and they cost between $4,000 and $7,000. He said the technology already exists to mass-produce machines that would cost between $500 and $1,000 and could be operated by virtually anyone. A variety of research has shown that the faster the shock is delivered, the better the chances of saving the victim. ``If you shock them in the first minute, virtually everyone survives,'' said Atkins. ``It's all time.'' Dr. Richard E. Kerber of the University of Iowa said nearly two-thirds of victims of cardiac arrest have fibrillation, while the rest have other rhythm disturbances that cannot be corrected with electric shocks. ``This means that 60 percent of the 300,000 people who die have a good chance of being revived'' if defibrillators became widely available, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Aspirin Taken With a Cocktail Will Get You Drunker, Rsearchers Say
DOC.TEXT: Taking a couple aspirins with a cocktail can get you drunker, doctors warned today. Aspirin blocks the action of a stomach enzyme that breaks down alcohol before it reaches the bloodstream, researchers reported in the Journal of the American Medical Association. ``It's important that people be warned not to mix those two - not to take aspirin before they drink, or rather, not to drink after they take aspirin,'' Dr. Charles S. Lieber, director of the Alcohol Research Center at the Bronx Veterans Affairs Medical Center in New York, said in a telephone interview Tuesday. He and his colleagues studied aspirin and alcohol absorption in five healthy men ages 30 to 45 years. Each man was given a standard breakfast, then an hour later, a glass of juice containing three grams of alcohol per kilogram of body weight - about a drink and a half for an average-size man, Lieber said. The men underwent the procedure again, but first took one gram of aspirin - the equivalent of two extra-strength tablets - with breakfast. ``There was a 34 percent increase in the blood level of alcohol,'' Lieber said. The same effect could occur on an empty stomach, but previous studies have failed to show it, possibly because alcohol remains in an empty stomach so briefly, the researchers said. Women would probably be more susceptible, said Lieber, who has reported previously that women produce proportionally less of the enzyme in their stomachs. Dr. Ernest P. Noble, director of the Alcohol Research Center at the University of California in Los Angeles, said the findings are important because many people consider aspirin a ``magic drug'' that can protect against heart attacks. ``If they're going to do their drinking, they should do it with a full stomach, and not taking aspirin,'' said Noble, former director of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism. Lieber said people who take aspirin daily should do so in the morning if they plan to drink at night. The findings do not mean drinkers need to abandon the time-honored strategy of taking aspirin before going to sleep to try to avert a hangover, he said. ``If they just go to bed, the alcohol will wear off,'' he said. More danger lies in going out to dinner, taking aspirin, having a drink and driving home, he said. Another dangerous scenario he cited included taking an an aspirin and having a beer or two at lunch, returning to work and using machinery. Lieber said heavier drinking was not studied for ethical reasons but that the effect would most likely be the same. Blood-alcohol levels in the study's subjects ranged from 0.025 percent to 0.037 percent, well below the strictest standard of any state for drunkenness in motorists - 0.08 percent, he said. ``We're not talking about drunkenness here,'' he said. But ``these are levels that impair one's capacity to drive or to operate some sophisticated machinery.''

DOC.HEAD: More Than 40 Killed In Typhoon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Aquino declaring nearly half the country a disaster area, ADDS importance of Cebu. Picks up 4th pvs, `Telephone lines ...' ^By CLARO CORTES
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Mike roared into the South China Sea on Wednesday after killing more than 40 people across the central Philippines. First reports indicated severe devastation in a major industrial center. About 100 people were missing and 320,000 jammed schools, offices and makeshift evacuation centers. President Corazon Aquino, who returned Wednesday from Japan, declared 30 of the country's 73 provinces disaster areas. Unconfirmed radio reports put the death toll at about 30 in Cebu, a city of more than a half million people and the country's second most important transport and industrial center after Manila. Telephone lines to the city were cut and residents reached by radio from Manila, 350 miles to the north, said hundreds of buildings were damaged and the city was without electricity. Nineteen ships sank in the storm, including 17 in Cebu harbor. Radio station DYHP in Cebu, which reported the 40 deaths, said about 90 percent of all houses built of wood were damaged or destroyed. Crisologo Enriquez, the Manila weather bureau's chief forecaster, said the typhoon, which roared into the country early Tuesday with peak winds of 150 mph, had weakened to 94 mph and was continuing west at 14 mph. The Philippine coast guard said 25 crew members were missing after the ship Dona Roberta sank near Cagayan de Oro, about 500 miles south of Manila. Three sailors also were missing after their navy craft sank in Cebu harbor. On Negros Island, officials said 32 people were killed and 61 were missing. Twenty-seven of the dead perished in a landslide in Isabela town, officials said. Five others drowned on the island. Relief agencies said at least 4,200 houses had either been destroyed or damaged by the typhoon. The typhoon, which roared into the Philippines on Tuesday, was the 14th to hit the country this year and struck the Leyte Island first. Six people were killed either by drowning or crushed by falling trees on the island, the Office of Civil Defense said. To the west on Panay Island, at least three people died, including a 10-year-old boy hit by a tree, officials said. Three other bodies were recovered from the surf off Mindanao, second largest of the 7,100 Philippine islands, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Cancer Treatments Will Keep Cranston From Keating Hearing
DOC.TEXT: Cancer treatments in California will prevent Sen. Alan Cranston from attending much of the Senate Ethics Committee's hearings int the ``Keating Five'' case. But the California Democrat who already has announced his intention to retire in 1992 said Tuesday he will make an opening statement once the hearings begin Thursday. One of the five senators under investigation, Cranston said he will be unavailable next Monday and Tuesday, when his radiation treatment for prostate cancer is to begin, and after Dec. 7, when it is likely to have a weakening effect. In a letter to Ethics Committee Chairman Howell Heflin, D-Ala., and Vice Chairman Warren Rudman, R-N.H., Cranston said he could appear before the committee this week, when opening statements are expected. After then, he said, his answers would most likely have to be in writing. The hearings will focus on five senators who received $1.3 million from Phoenix financier Charles H. Keating Jr. and also intervened with regulators on behalf of Keating's failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. The other senators targeted by the probe are John McCain, R-Ariz.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John Glenn, D-Ohio, and Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. The committee is trying to determine whether the contributions influenced the actions of the senators in violation of the chamber's rules. Cranston did not run Tuesday for re-election as Senate majority whip. He said he would begin a seven-week course of radiation therapy Monday at Stanford University School of Medicine. Dr. Malcolm Bagshaw, professor and chairman of radiation oncology at Stanford, will supervise the treatment. ``I naturally want to cooperate fully with the committee so that the hearing proceedings may be carried out as expeditiously with as little interruption as possible,'' Cranston wrote. ``I have been advised by Dr. Bagshaw that because of the side effects of my treatment, deposition by written questions will be the most appropriate way for me to adhere to the hearing procedure.'' The senator said he will ``put myself at the committee's disposal in California between my daily radiation treatments.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Offers an Rx for Hard-Core Smokers
DOC.TEXT: Veronica Iversen was an expert on how to stop smoking. She'd done it a half-dozen times. But after a few days, or the end of Lent, or her sister's hospitalization, she always lit up again, despite her vows and prayers. Finally, she sought help from a source to which a small but growing number of heavy smokers are turning: a doctor. She chose Elliot Wineburg, a psychiatrist at Mount Sinai Medical School who specializes in treatment of stress. About a third of his practice consists of heavy smokers who want to quit. Public education and anti-smoking classes ``have filtered out most of the people who can easily stop,'' he said. ``Now we're seeing the hard core ... people who are desperate and ashamed.'' And who need medical attention. ``A smoking problem is more than just a problem of will, it's an illness,'' Wineburg said. ``Curing it takes more than `Just say no.' You can't say that to an addict.'' Attention must be individual, he argued, since, ``If you have a sore throat your internist doesn't say, `Come to my lecture on penicillin along with 20 other people.''' Depending on the patient, Wineburg may prescribe three types of medicine: nicotine gum; antidepressant drugs, or clonidine, a drug usually used to control blood pressure. In addition, he uses techniques such as hypnosis, biofeedback and cognitive therapy to help smokers relieve their underlying psychological problems. Within five weeks, Wineburg reports, 68 percent of his patients stop smoking - compared to a rate of 20 percent for many programs and courses. Wineburg treated Iversen, a single, 68-year-old retired secretary from Brooklyn who was smoking a pack a day, for $750. The fee was not covered by insurance because she was not suffering from an ailment caused by smoking. On her first visit, Iversen insisted she didn't know why she smokes - it was a bad habit with no purpose. But after prodding, she admitted to a very good reason: ``If I'm tired it picks me up. If I'm upset, it calms me down.'' Iversen used nicotine to cope with everything from the drudgery of housekeeping to the illness of her sister, who has Alzheimer's disease. ``Nothing is more difficult than being worried about someone and not being able to do anything about it,'' she said. At the beginning of her second visit, Iversen announced that she'd smoked her last cigarette two hours earlier. Since nicotine is highly addictive, Wineburg needed to determine how much Iversen had been ingesting. Told that she smoked a pack of True Kings a day, Wineburg calculated that she consumed about eight milligrams daily. He prescribed a daily dosage of four pieces of nicotine gum to ease the symptoms of nicotine withdrawal and showed Iversen how to chew the gum - slowly, not swallowing the saliva until the nicotine could be absorbed through the cheek membrane. During her third visit, Wineburg tested Iversen and decided she would not be a good candidate for deep hypnosis. He then showed her a way to relax her body from the toes up. As he did so, he tried to shore up her self-confidence, insisting, ``You are a very strong person.'' He concluded by saying, ``I'm going home with you'' - and handing her a cassette recording of their session. The following week Iversen talked about the times she is tempted to smoke, and things she associates with smoking, such as an occasional whiskey sour before dinner. ``You'll always want to smoke,'' Wineburg told her. ``You can't get it out of your head.'' The trick, he said, is to know how to resist. On her fifth visit a therapist attached Iversen to a machine that recorded the tension in her forehead muscles. As she watched a video screen, she learned ways to relax those muscles in moments of stress and tension. She also learned a technique of deep breathing that reduces stress. That was April 19, 1989. Since then Veronica Iversen has not smoked. She no longer gets scowls from other members of her church group. She has taken up oil painting to occupy her hands and mind. And sometimes she would just love a cigarette.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Panel Delayed Announcing News of Steroid Treatment
DOC.TEXT: A federal panel waited five months before announcing its finding that steroids can halve the death rate from the pneumonia that is the leading killer of people with AIDS, The New York Times reported today. The panel withheld the announcement until Oct. 10 because members could not agree on how to word their statement, the newspaper said. Part of the reason they could not agree, said panel vice chairman Dr. Paul Meier, was that the findings had not yet been accepted at a prestigious medical journal, and they feared an early announcement would jeopardize publication. Many medical journals have a policy of not publishing studies that have been reported in the popular press. The journals say the policy is aimed at ensuring that studies are subjected to scrutiny by disinterested scientists. AIDS activists have attacked the policy as a barrier to the release of life-saving information. The panel of 16 AIDS specialists and statisticians convened by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases had concluded on May 15 that a steroid hormone treatment can be effective against pneumocystis carinii pneumonia. The finding, and the delay in releasing it, came to light in the Nov. 2 issue of AIDS Treatment News, a San Francisco-based newsletter.
