The delay has angered members of the AIDS treatment and research communities. ``When the lives of people are in the balance, it is totally unethical not to release information immediately,'' said Dr. Mathilde Krim, a founder of the American Foundation for AIDS Research, a non-profit group in New York. Dr. Jerome Groopman, an AIDS researcher at the New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston, said it is time to set new ground rules for the release of potentially life-saving information. ``One of the things we're learning from AIDS is that the situation has to change and adapt to all life-saving situations,'' Groopman said.

DOC.HEAD: Disk Games Recalled
DOC.TEXT: Three outdoor disk-tossing games have been recalled by their manufacturers in the wake of facial injuries to children. The voluntary recalls announced Tuesday by the Consumer Product Safety Commission involve the Yard Spinner, Style 3209, made by Franklin Sports Industries of Stoughton, Mass.; the Lawn Discus, made by Regent Sports Corp. of Hauppauge, N.Y., and the Pro Sport Lawn Spinner, marketed by Service Merchandise Company, Inc., of Brentwood, Tenn. Each of the games involve plastic disks shaped like flat fan blades, nine inches in diameter. The disks have seven fins each, with multiple holes in them. The commission said that Regent had learned of 12 facial and eye injuries suffered by children struck by the disks and that Franklin Sports knows of six similar cases involving its game. Consumers can identify the Franklin Sports disks by the words ``FRANKLIN'' and ``Yard Spinner,'' imprinted on the disks. The Regent Sports disks have the words ``Regent'' and ``Lawn Discus'' imprinted and the Service Merchandise model has the word ``TAIWAN'' molded into the disks.
DOC.HEAD: Air Force Withholds $240 Million Payment to Boeing
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force says the Boeing Co. has failed to make satisfactory headway on an air defense network for Saudi Arabia and is withholding $240 million in progress payments to the aerospace company. Jack Rankin, a spokesman for the Air Force's Electronic Systems Division at Hanscom Air Force Base, Mass., said Tuesday the primary complaint was Boeing's failure to meet a Sept. 30 deadline for software testing. The Washington-based publication Defense Week, quoting a government documents, said the Air Force had told Boeing it was considering terminating the $3.7 billion contract for the ``Peace Shield'' program. Rankin said he could not confirm this. In Seattle, Boeing spokesman Don Brannon conceded that progress payments had been withheld and that the Air Force was unhappy with the company's failure to meet the Sept. 30 test date. ``We are behind schedule as far as the program is concerned because of the difficulties that we experienced in the software development,'' Brannon said. But he said tests of the software have begun and ``are proceeding better than anticipated.'' The Boeing spokesman said the company has completed design and development of the system and has completed half of its work on 17 radar sites being built in Saudi Arabia as part of the network.
DOC.HEAD: Vaccine Compensation Claims Deadline Extended,
DOC.TEXT: The government is extending until Jan. 31, 1991, the deadline for victims of vaccine-related injuries to file claims under the National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program. The deadline for claimants injured on or prior to Oct. 1, 1988, had been Oct. 1, 1990, but Congress extended it another four months. Those who miss the deadline can still pursue claims in civil courts. The federal program was set up as a faster, less expensive procedure to get compensation for vaccine-related injuries. Under it, petitioners have to prove only that injuries are related to a vaccine, not that the manufacturer of the vaccine was at fault. Covered by the program are diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis vaccines; the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine; the oral polio vaccine; and the inactivated polio vaccine. Claims for injuries after Oct. 1, 1988, must be filed by deadlines stipulated in the National Childhood Injury Act. The amount of compensation is determined by a U.S. Claims Court, based on the needs of the injured person and the extent of the injury. The maximum death benefit is $250,000. Information on how to file a claim may be obtained from the U.S. Claims Court, 717 Madison Place NW, Washington, D.C. 20005. The Department of Health and Human Services' Health Resources and Services Administration also offers a toll-free hotline, 800-338-2382.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Five Might Be Buried in Kansas Field
DOC.TEXT: Police have unearthed the remains of two people and believe up to three more are buried in a cornfield near the boyhood home of a man charged with murder in one of the deaths. Guided by tips and anonymous letters, authorities Tuesday combed 220 acres near Highland, about 30 miles from St. Joseph, Mo., for more bodies. Hunters on Sunday came across a skull and bones in the field, and officers on Monday unearthed a body. The skeletal remains have not been identified, but the body was identified Tuesday as that of Crystal Simmons, 33, who vanished from St. Joseph on Oct. 29. An autopsy showed she died of blows to the head, investigators said. Marvin Irvin, 41, was charged Thursday with murdering Ms. Simmons. He was one of the last people seen with her, and blood was found in his truck, authorities said. Police said her body and the skeletal remains were found about 100 yards apart near land formerly owned by Irvin's family. Irvin, a former St. Joseph police officer, had been on parole the past year for assault on an Iowa woman, police said. He is being held in a Missouri jail. Sgt. Jim Connors, a St. Joseph police spokesman, said recent tips and anonymous letters received in the past four years by police and reporters lead police believe at least five people have been buried on the property. They include 19-year-old woman who vanished in 1979 and a 31-year-old woman who has been missing since Sept. 17, authorities said. Both were from St. Joseph.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Tokyo Stocks Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained against the Japanese yen today, while share prices fell slightly in profit-taking and uncertainty over U.S. interest rates, traders said. The dollar closed at 129.05 yen, up 0.28 yen from Tuesday's 128.77-yen finish. It opened at 129.67 yen and ranged between 129.02 yen and 129.80 yen in quiet trading that totaled some $8.18. The dollar started strong after gaining overnight on overseas markets. An expected lowering of the interest rate by the U.S. Federal Reserve Board, which would have made the dollar less attractive, did not materialize, dealers said. But dollars were being sold again Wednesday afternoon in Tokyo, said Masato Hayashi, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. ``The dollar's afternoon slip resulted from position adjustments because investors still expect that the (U.S.) Fed will lower interest rates today,'' he added. Hayashi said the dollar's afternoon slide against the yen also was prompted by its weakness against the major European currencies, especially the German mark. Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co., said trading was thin because many investors remained on the sidelines in continuing anticipation of lower U.S. interest rates. Dai-ichi Kangyo Bank's Shigeto Yanase said market players avoided buying yen in part because of rumors linking senior politicians with a stock insider-trading case currently under investigation. On the stock exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 36.23 points, or 0.15 percent, closing at 23,937.44. The index, which surged 1,041.87 points, or 4.54 percent Tuesday, was down 148.47 points at the end of the morning session before rebounding somewhat. Trading was thin, with first section volume estimated at 350 million shares, down from Tuesday's 400 million. Traders said profit-taking following Tuesday's sharp advance and uncertainty about U.S. interest rates pushed down large-capital issues, such as steel. Institutional investors' index-linked large-scale buying supported the index in the afternoon but continuing profit-taking by other investors dampened a recovery, they said. The index was unexpectedly well supported considering the amount of Tuesday's gain, which could have prompted more active selling today, traders said. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 84.69 points by 5 p.m. (3 a.m. EST) from Tuesday's 84.55-point finish. Their yield fell to 7.780 percent from 7.810 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Shield Soldiers Shipped to Germany With Broken Bones, Snakebite
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
By GEORGE BOEHMER
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,400 U.S. troops assigned to Operation Desert Shield have been airlifted to Germany for treatment of broken bones, depression, snake bites and other afflictions, military officials say. But the Army is treating fewer GIs than anticipated for a population of 230,000 people, ``based on health risk assessments for that region of the world,'' said Barbara Slifer, spokeswoman for the Army's 7th Medical Command in Heidelberg. Forty-three soldiers have died in the deployment, mostly in accidents. Officials say two Army hospitals in Germany had received 926 evacuated patients as of Tuesday afternoon, and the Air Force hospital in Wiesbaden had received 515 since Aug. 11, when U.S. troops were sent to Saudi Arabia. The figures mean that of the 230,000 GIs sent to the Persian Gulf region, about one soldier in every 166 has had a medical problem. Some have been treated and returned to the Persian Gulf region, and others with more serious conditions have been transferred to the United States, said Ms. Slifer. She said 88 remained hospitalized at the Army's regional hospital in Frankfurt and 53 in the regional hospital at Landsthul. Capt. Robert Lenahan of the Air Force's hospital in Wiesbaden said 39 Desert Shield patients were still there as of Tuesday. Military medical officials have said that facilities newly set up in the gulf region can care for most casualties as well as hospitals anywhere. But evacuating patients to Germany keep beds free in the gulf in case of hostilities. The medical problems ``run the gamut,'' Ms. Slifer said. ``The predominant area of care that we've been providing is orthopedic, broken bones. We've had one snakebite case, we've had gallbladder attacks,'' she said. She said a few soldiers were also sent back for psychological care. ``I think the psychological ailments are pretty much what you would expect in any type of military-type environment.'' Most of the patients coming through Wiesbaden are sent back to the United States, unless they can be treated in ``a fairly short timeframe,'' Lenahan said. ``But we have people coming back with kidney stones, torn knee ligaments, things that take more than just a couple of weeks to repair,'' Lenahan said. He said that long-term patients requiring treatment of more than three to four weeks are sent back to the United States ``so that we still have enough empty beds here for other patients that may come up.'' In addition to injuries, patients needed treatment for allergies, asthma and dermatological problems, he said. He said that the allergies and asthma are apparently due to the very dry climate in Saudi Arabia. ``People who wouldn't normally have asthma problems are experiencing that.''

DOC.HEAD: School Choice Program Struck Down on Technicality
DOC.TEXT: Poor Milwaukee youngsters can continue to attend private schools at taxpayer expense while the state drafts an appeal of a ruling that the program was unconstitutionally enacted, officials say. A state appeals court Tuesday struck down on a legal technicality the law establishing Milwaukee's first-in-the-nation School Choice program. It said the program was passed in violation of the Wisconsin Constitution, which forbids sneaking through ``local'' programs in state budget bills. The court did not address the program's merits. Roger Sundby, an executive assistant to the state schools superintendent, said his agency will let it continue for at least 30 days, the period allowed for lawyers to appeal to the state Supreme Court. The program has been praised by the Bush administration for creating a healthy competition between public and private schools. Critics sued to block the program, arguing it undermined state efforts to ensure that educational standards are met at private schools and ignored the majority of students left behind in public schools. A judge rejected those arguments in August, ruling the program served a legitimate public purpose. The case went to the appeals court. ``I'm sad they did not make a decision on merits, just on the process,'' said Gov. Tommy G. Thompson. ``Parental choice is a model program that holds great promise for disadvantaged children in Milwaukee's poorest neighborhoods,'' he said. ``It must be given an opportunity to prove its potential.'' The program, passed by the Legislature in the spring, was authorized to provide $2,500 each for as many as 1,000 students this year, but only about 400 were able to enroll in about 10 eligible private schools because of space limitations. The money is deducted from the state aid provided to the Milwaukee public school system, which has about 97,000 students. The ruling implies that lawmakers can rewrite the law and salvage the program. Senate Majority Leader Dave Helbach said such an effort will be undertaken when lawmakers reconvene in January.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate For UN Post Accuses West of `Bias'
DOC.TEXT: An Indian relief official bitterly withdrew his name from consideration for the post of U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees after charging Western officials with a ``demeaning'' bias against non-Europeans. The United States and other Western countries had strongly objected to Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar's choice of Virenda Dayal, his chief of staff, for the post. Dayal, a former Indian civil servant, sent a letter to Perez de Cuellar withdrawing from consideration, U.N. spokesman Francois Giuliani said Tuesday. Giuliani said it was ``accepted with regret.'' ``Given the present controversy as to whether a non-European can be worthy of the post, which I find demeaning, I would appreciate it if my name could be withdrawn from consideration,'' Dayal wrote. ``There is no way in which I can develop the attributes of a Western-European politician, whether in or out of office. And I would not wish UNHCR or the refugees of the world to be deprived of funding on that account,'' he said. The U.N. High Commissioner serves a three-year term and oversees programs for an estimated 15 million refugees. Both Western and Third World nations are seeking a strong and independent candidate who can appeal for more funds and public support for refugees. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Tuesday that the Bush administration was ``extremely concerned over reports that we heard last week that the secretary-general intended to appoint the next high commissioner without consulting concerned governments.'' The United States is the single largest donor to the refugee program, providing $117 million of its $550 million budget, Boucher said. Cnada, Britain, France, Austria, Belgium and New Zealand have all put forth their own candidates; they are expected to confer with the United States and agree on a nominee who is a Westerner. The director of the State Department's office of refugee programs, Princeton Lyman, was leaving today on a foreign trip to interview candidates. On Monday, a U.S. official who spoke on condition of anonymity said the Bush administration was ``outraged'' that Perez de Cuellar insisted last week that either the commissioner or deputy commissioner be from the Third World. Washington took that as a threat to fire the deputy, American Douglas Stafford, if Dayal didn't get the top post. U.N. spokeswoman Nadia Younes denied there had been a suggestion Stafford would be eliminated. She also denied there had been no consultations with the U.S. Mission on Dayal's candidacy. Dayal was a senior official in the refugees program from 1965-1979, serving as regional representative to U.N. headquarters and as executive assistant to the high commissioner. The previous commissioner, Thorvald Stoltenberg, resigned two weeks ago to become deputy prime minister of Norway. Stoltenberg had replaced Jean-Pierre Hocke, who resigned in October 1989 when it was disclosed he used a special education fund to upgrade his airline travel to first class, at a cost of about $300,000. The secretary-general appoints the commissioner, and the General Assembly approves the candidate in a vote. Perez de Cuellar, who was traveling in Japan and Europe and was to return to New York next week, will have to see who emerges as the Western candidate, or propose another himself.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Recommends Death Penalty in Slayings of Transients
DOC.TEXT: A jury asked for death by injection for a 69-year-old farm wife convicted of murdering five drifters in an alleged attempt to cover up a cattle-rustling scheme. If a judge accepts the recommendation, Fay Copeland will become the oldest person in Missouri to receive the death penalty since it was reinstated in 1977. She was convicted Saturday of five counts of murder. The jury Tuesday recommended death on four of the charges and life in prison on the fifth. Under the law, Judge E. Richard Webber may accept the jury's decision or give her life without parole. No sentencing date was set. Defense attorney David Miller said he will appeal. Mrs. Copeland wept quietly and held the hands of Miller and a son, Al Copeland, as the jury's decision was read. Authorities said the victims were unwitting participants in a cattle-buying scheme orchestrated by Mrs. Copeland's 75-year-old husband, Ray. Four bodies were found in shallow graves and the fifth was found in a well. All had been shot in the head. Prosecutor Doug Roberts called it ``one of the worst, if not the worst, cases of serial murder in the state's history.'' Prosecutors charged that Copeland hired the drifters at missions, promising them $50 a day plus room and board to act as cattle buyers. Copeland had the men buy livestock with bad checks and then killed them to conceal the thefts, they said. Authorities said Mrs. Copeland was his partner in the scheme, which netted the couple $32,000 from 1986 to 1989. The defense contended she was dominated by her husband and did not know of his business dealings. Copeland's murder trial begins Jan. 24. His attorneys contend he is senile and incompetent to stand trial. A drifter who once worked for the couple told authorities last year that bodies were buried at their small farm about 90 miles from Kansas City. No bodies were found on the farm, but police unearthed victims at area farms where Copeland performed odd jobs over the years. A list in Mrs. Copeland's handwriting with an ``X'' marked next to the names of several of the victims was a key piece of evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Garbo's Paintings Auctioned at Sotheby's
DOC.TEXT: A Renoir portrait of his nephew sold for $7.04 million at an auction of the artworks with which Greta Garbo was alone in her final years. The auction at Sotheby's on Tuesday night attested to the public's enduring fascination with the reclusive actress and gave the otherwise slumping art market a glamorous boost. While one of Garbo's Renoirs failed to sell, three other paintings from her apartment on Manhattan's East Side sold for $15.9 million, near or above the level expected by the auction house. ``People like to own things that have been owned by famous people,'' said auctioneer John Marion. Surprisingly to some, the paintings from the actress' sanctuary depict intimate human scenes in brilliant colors. The Renoir that brought the highest price was ``Portrait of Edmund Renoir Jr.,'' which went to an anonymous buyer. The 1889 oil is a portrait of the son of Renoir's brother. The child has waist-length blond hair and a dark blue coat. The painting's pre-sale estimate was $4 million to $6 million. The contents of Garbos's apartment being auctioned off this week are estimated to be worth at least $20 million. Much of the value is attributed to Garbo's ownership of the works. Also the auction block this week are hundreds of other items from Garbo's apartment, including a carpet estimated to be worth $50,000, upholstered chairs for $10,000 each, and a perfume bottle in the shape of a wizard worth $600. The actress lived alone for 37 years in the building. She filled the place with paintings and porcelain that she bought at Manhattan galleries, where she was known as G.G. or ``Ms. Brown.'' Renoir's ``Leontine and Coco'' brought $5.7 million. It also went to an anonymous buyer. The 1909 oil depicts the artist's young son, Coco, reading in the company of a young nursemaid. A third Renoir, ``Secret,'' did not sell. The highest bid was $1.5 million, and did not meet the pre-sale estimate of $2 million to $3 million. The 1897 painting shows an unidentified model and composer Claude Terrasse. Pierre Bonnard's ``The Corn Poppies'' brought $3.19 million from an anonymous buyer. It was painted circa 1914-15 and shows a graceful white pitcher with a falling cherry design, and a small dog in a chair. Also auctioned Tuesday was a collection of other Impressionist and modern paintings. The highest price went for Monet's ``Water Lillies,'' which brought $9.45 million against a pre-sale estimate of $7 million to $9 million. It was bought by a Japanese dealer.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Extends State of Emergency
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has extended the state of emergency with Iran stemming from its 1979 seizure of the U.S. Embassy and American hostages in Tehran. ``Because our relations with Iran have not yet returned to normal ... the national emergency declared on Nov. 14, 1979, must continue in effect,'' Bush said in the annual renewal notice to Congress published Tuesday in the Federal Register. Iran seized the U.S. Embassy in Tehran on Nov. 4, 1979. Former President Jimmy Carter declared a state of national emergency with Iran 10 days later, allowing the U.S. government to freeze Iranian assets and impose other economic sanctions. The last of the remaining 52 hostages were released by Iran on Jan 20, 1981, just after President Reagan was inaugurated into office. A state of emergency must be renewed every year prior to its anniversary date or the economic and diplomatic sanctions it imposes would otherwise expire.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Steel Industry Rewriting the Recipe
DOC.TEXT: The steel industry is working to remove the dirtiest ingredient in its 378-year-old steel recipe - coke. The $44 million, four-year experiment in this Pittsburgh suburb to make steel in a cleaner, more efficient way could clear the air near coke ovens and help steelmakers meet federal pollution standards, but could also mean layoffs. The American Iron and Steel Institute and U.S. Department of Energy unveiled their research on Tuesday. ``What you have is steel without all the stink,'' said Carnegie Mellon University professor R.J. Fruehan, a researcher on the project. An American company will be selling steel made with the new cokeless process by 2005, said Ian Hughes, technology vice president at Inland Steel Corp. At least one environmental activist is sketical the changes will come anytime soon. ``Coke will be around for a long time, and it's certainly going to be another generation of our children before these changes are in place,'' said David Jasnow, a board member of the Group Against Smog and Pollution. In the method first used in blast furnaces in 1612 in England, steel is made by melting iron ore to remove oxygen, then mixing the liquid iron with limestone and coke. Coke is almost pure carbon made by baking impurities from coal. The iron-coke-limestone mixture then must go through two furnaces before it is finished into steel. The experimental process mixes coal, iron ore and limestone to make liquid steel in one step. Hughes said the new technology, combined with other advances in steel finishing and rolling, would cut the current 1,000-hour method of making steel to 10 hours while demanding the same amount of coal from American mines. The steel industry's work force would be halved ``if all of this eventually works out,'' said project director Egil Aukrist. The one-step process will cut energy costs by 20 percent, saving $10 to $25 per ton of steel, AISI said. The process should help big steelmakers such as USX, Bethlehem Steel Corp and LTV Steel Co. regain market share lost to imports, said Joe Goodwin, director of the Center for Materials Research at Carnegie Mellon University. Japanese steelmakers are developing technology similar to AISI's cokeless production, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Cracks Down on Uprising Leaders, Ponders Jordan Border Issue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with curfews, plans to cut Arab work force. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Israel launched a new crackdown on the nearly 3-year-old Palestinian uprising today, imposing widespread curfews and announcing plans to halve the Arab work force from the occupied lands. The curfews were to prevent demonstrations on the eve of the second anniversary of the Palestinian state declared by the Palestine Liberation Organization's parliament in exile on Nov. 15, 1988. The measures also came a day after two key pro-PLO Palestinian activists were ordered jailed for six months without trial for alleged involvement in inciting a wave of attacks against Israelis in the past month. Israeli left-wingers protested the detentions of Radwan Abu Ayyash, 40, of Ramallah in the West Bank and Ziad Abu Ziad, 50 of Jerusalem. Abu Ayyash heads the Arab Journalists' Union and Abu Ziad edits a Hebrew-language Palestinian weekly. ``The message of the Israeli government to the Palestinian leadership is clear: there is no point in being a moderate,'' said Dedi Zucker of the Citizens' Rights Movement. Yossi Beilin of the left-of-center Labor Party warned that ``the price is liable to be more unnecessary bloodshed.'' The curfews in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip confined roughly 420,000 people indoors. Schools were also shut in the West Bank, keeping 300,000 Arab pupils away from classrooms. Holiday celebrations were launched Tuesday night in Gaza and the West Bank in anticipation of the curfews. Activists set off firecrackers, draped outlawed Palestinian flags over electric wires and marched in the streets, Arab reports said. Demonstrations persisted today before the curfews. In Gaza City's commercial district, school girls marched chanting pro-PLO and pro-Iraqi slogans, Arab reports said. One chant was: ``Saddam, fire the chemical weapons!'' In Israel, authorities rounded up 1,350 Palestinians working without security permits, Army radio said. The sweep was part of a campaign launched last month in the wake of a spate of stabbing attacks in Israel. Labor Minister David Magen said the government would institute new policies that he expected to cut by more than half the number of Palestinians working in Israel. ``The government will discuss new labor laws. The significance will be a serious reduction in the number of workers from the territories,'' Magen said on Israel radio. Magen added he expected 60,000 of about 108,000 Palestinians employed in Israel to lose their jobs. The slack would be taken up by Soviet immigrants and discharged soldiers, he said. The so-called administrative detentions of Abu Ayyash and Abu Ziad were announced several hours after an infiltrator from Jordan shot and killed an Israeli soldier Tuesday. Security officials blamed the attack on the PLO's mainstream Fatah movement and the Moslem fundamentalist group Islamic Jihad. It was the seventh infiltration this year along the previously quiet Jordan frontier. Right-wing legislators voiced concern that Jordan's support for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was encouraging the attacks. The army stepped up patrols along the frontier today, Israel radio said. Also Tuesday, two policemen were wounded in a stabbing in Jerusalem's old walled city, only four days after another policeman was attacked near the same site. Both Abu Ayyash and Abu Ziad were accused of being senior figures in Fatah and in the underground leadership of the uprising. A Defense Ministry statement said both were either involved in writing leaflets calling for attacks on Israelis or directing ``strike forces'' to conduct violence. Israeli reports said a physician in Gaza, Ahmed Al-Yaziji, was also placed under administrative detention for one year on allegations of involvement with Fatah. The imprisonment of the three Palestinians without trial was ordered under emergency regulations adopted by the British in 1945, when they ruled Palestine, and kept on the law books by Israel. Israelis have killed more than 770 Palestinians in the uprising that began Dec. 8, 1987 against Israel's occupation of lands seized in the 1967 Middle East war. More than 290 Arabs have been killed as collaborators by other Arabs, and more than 50 Israelis and foreigners have died.

DOC.HEAD: High-Pressure Front Warms East, Midwest; Stormy Weather in Northwest
DOC.TEXT: A high-pressure system moved east from the Plains today, chasing away the chilly weather that had gripped the East Coast and leaving clear skies across the eastern two-thirds of the nation. A winter storm moved across the Pacific Northwest and into California's Northern Sierra, however, bringing lower temperatures and the threat of heavy snow in the mountains. The Sierra was expected to get a foot by tonight. Fair weather was forecast for the East Coast, Midwest and South. Highs were expected to range from the 40s in the North to the 60s and 70s in the middle regions and the 80s in the South. Highs along the West Coast ranged from the 50s in the north to the 60s and 70s in California. The high temperature for the nation Tuesday was 94 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: U.S. Special Forces Team: Training Kuwaitis For a Worthy Cause
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD strength of Kuwaiti army, SUB 6th graf, `Part of ... several months.' Picks up 7th, `For soldiers ...' ^An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: A chill wind blew dust into every pore. At times, visibility on the desert plain dropped to about 100 yards. But there was no morale problem for a U.S. Special Forces team preparing Kuwaitis for war. American troops elsewhere in Saudi Arabia may be clamoring to go home, but in the shrubless, stony desert wasteland of eastern Saudi Arabia on Tuesday, 10 hardened U.S. soldiers were embarked on a mission that stirred their emotions. ``You have a cause worth fighting for,'' said the officer commanding the team, which includes both Special Forces and regular Army experts. ``Talking with the Kuwaitis you seen their concern for their families ... for their country. Being a family man, I cannot help being moved.'' Staff Sgt. Barry D. Sparlin, 29, of Houston, said it was time to stop Iraqi President Saddam Hussein before he gets nuclear weapons. ``We're here ... to prevent our children from having to do the same thing we're here for right now,'' he said. Part of Kuwait's 20,000-man army escaped to Saudi Arabia with their tanks after the Iraqis overran their country on Aug. 2. They have been camping in the desert for several months. For soldiers like Capt. Ali, a 34-year-old tank commander, waiting for the order to attack has become almost an obsession. ``We want revenge,'' said Ali, who didn't identify himself further because his wife and four children are still in Kuwait. ``We didn't have a chance that day when they surprised us. But now we are ready.'' The chief U.S. adviser, speaking on condition he not be identified, agreed that all the Kuwaitis need is some equipment: ``They're as good as any brigade anywhere in the world, in any army.'' The Kuwaitis could use more tanks, spare parts and ammunition for the existing Martyrs Brigade. A second brigade being formed has manpower but no armor. A brigade normally has from 4,500 to 5,000 soldiers, about the number of regular Kuwaiti forces who escaped to Saudi Arabia, and more than 100 tanks. The U.S. team arrived in the Kuwaiti camp only about two weeks ago, just before the Americans and Saudis agreed on a joint command for operations inside the country and U.S. command of any operations outside Saudi Arabia. Some 145,000 Arab troops, under Saudi command, are part of the more than 350,000-strong multinational force confronting Iraq. The U.S. officer said he didn't know why it had taken so long to get American advisers into the field. But he said ``the time has been put to good use'' and the confusing command structure among the Arab forces had been straightened out. The American team leader said he assumed other U.S. advisers were also based with Syrian troops. His men had an unscheduled meeting with the Syrians one night: They got lost and drove into the Syrian camp where they were stopped by an alert sentry who checked them out and sent them back to the Kuwaiti camp. Sgt. Paul Evans, 28, of Vista, Calif., said relations with the Kuwaitis were so good that team members were invited to dinner almost every night. That meant lamb or chicken with rice and potatoes instead of pre-packaged Army meals. The Americans refused to discuss their role, saying only that they were coordinating activity between U.S. units and the Kuwaiti brigade. ``The Americans are training us on many things we need to face Iraq,'' said Capt. Ali. ``They are very good soldiers - they just want to help.'' Ali said Americans were training Kuwaitis to deal with chemical weapons, to communicate with U.S. aerial command posts to call in air strikes, and to use TOW anti-tank missiles more effectively. ``They teach us Iraqi doctrines. They teach us about Iraqi minefields and they teach us how to handle prisoners,'' he said. A Kuwaiti captain in intelligence, speaking anonymously, said the Americans were also teaching the Kuwaitis house-to-house warfare, which would be essential in liberating Kuwait City. The chief U.S. adviser said winds gusting between 20 and 30 mph were churning up dust Tuesday and curtailed training. But the colder weather was welcome, he said, because it meant fewer flies. The location of the camp could not be revealed under military rules.

DOC.HEAD: Saud Says Summit Needs Prior Iraqi Pledge
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia said today that it won't take part in a proposed Arab summit until Iraq pledges to pull out of Kuwait. ``Any Arab meetings will bear no fruit or results'' unless Iraq promises to adhere to the resolutions of the emergency Arab summit held in August and of the United Nations, said the foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal. Prince Saud's statements were distributed by the official Emirates news agency, WAM, following his arrival and a meeting with President Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al Nahyan. Saud's was the first Saudi comment on the proposal by King Hassan II of Morocco for an emergency Arab summit to work out an Arab solution to the Persian Gulf crisis and avert war over Iraq's refusal to quit Kuwait, which it seized Aug. 2. The comment came as Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's second-in-command and first deputy prime minister, Taha Yassin Ramadan, returned to Baghdad from a meeting with Hassan in Morocco. The official Iraqi News Agency said Ramadan stressed to Hassan ``the need to provide a positive atmosphere and to make mature ideas available for discussion at the level of an Arab summit.'' The Iraqis have said Saddam would consider attending such a summit if it first consulted on the time and place - and if the Palestinian issue is on the agenda. INA said Ramadan said an Arab summit would ``erase the infamous Cairo summit resolutions, which created divisions in the Arab stance toward the dangers and the collusion against the Arab nation created by its enemies, led by the United States and its allies.'' At the August emergency summit in Cairo, 14 of the Arab League's 21 members voted to condemn the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and demand Iraq's withdrawal, while six either abstained or voted against the measure. The six were Sudan, Palestine, Jordan, Mauritania, Iraq and Yemen. Libya was not represented at the meeting.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad. --- Nov. 13 Birmingham (Ala.) Post-Herald on the Persian Gulf crisis: Whatever lies ahead in the Persian Gulf, the large new deployment of forces ordered by President Bush is justified. ... The magnitude of the force being built up in the gulf sends a necessary message, too, to all Americans: This commitment is irrevocable - and may be costly. War against Iraq would be no quick-fix intervention on the order of Grenada or Panama. It could be long and bloody. President Bush, who has handled many aspects of the gulf crisis with skill, has yet to level with the public about the possible sacrifice ahead. --- Nov. 11 Grand Forks (N.D.) Herald on the Persian Gulf: It would be reassuring if Bush toned down the rhetoric while he built up the armies, as well. There may yet be a diplomatic solution to this crisis. There have been suggestions that Iraq might be satisifed with better access to the sea, control of an uninhabited sandbar and an indemnity for Kuwait's well-documented theft of oil and its shenanigans in the oil cartels. With these conditions, Kuwait could be restore as an independent nation, perhaps with a U.N. peace-keeping force stationed there. If such a settlement is possible, it ought to be sought. It is far more attractive than the war. Saddam may yet reject it, of course. Then the consequences are on his shoulders. If it is not offered before thousands of lives are lost, the president will need to explain his failure as a diplomat to his people and to history. --- Nov. 13 The Charleston (W.Va.) Gazette on the Persian Gulf: Is President Bush preparing to invade Iraq and Kuwait, without asking Congress for a declaration of war, just as he invaded Panama without Congress' approval? Would he do it without a United Nations decision authorizing warfare? Questions like these hang in the air as Bush continues his bellicose tone and his military buildup in the Middle East. ... Bush contends that he is acting to deter aggression, to undo Iraq's seizure of tiny Kuwait. But that's window-dressing. ... No, America and other nations are acting strictly to protect the Mideast oil supply that sustains the industrialized world - an understandable goal. The nagging question is: does one man have the right, all by himself, to plunge America into a major war? ... We would feel less uneasy if he would promise not to send 400,000 young Americans into a blood bath without asking Congress first. --- Nov. 13 Delaware County Daily Times, Primos, Pa., on the death of Stormie Jones: Doctors are vigorously trying to find out what exactly killed Stormie Jones, the 13-year-old Texas girl who underwent a historic heart-liver transplant in 1984. ... But all forensic medical technology in the world is useless in telling us what kept Stormie going and her chin up the past 6{ years. Stormie battled her way through hell - a living hell. She survived a war in which many of us would have been mentally conquered. ... This courageous little girl captured the hearts of America - time and time again as she showed us all how to manhandle adversity and what it really means to live. ... --- Nov. 8 The Marietta (Ohio) Times on the U.S. elections: An expert, as most people know, is someone who offers an opinion from far away. ``Pork barrel'' is used to describe government money that funds a project in somebody else's neighborhood. Now, Tuesday's national election figures have given us a new definition: ``Bum'' is somebody else's congressman. ``Throw the bums out!'' supposedly was the cry of the land, at least according to media prophets before the election. Wednesday morning, however, America woke up to find Congress almost exactly as it was before the vote - before the budget-tax debacle, before the savings and loan bailout, before the pay raise issue, before ethics inquiries, before any of the other decisions that supposedly inflamed right-thinking patriots ... So, basically, on election day, we got what we asked for. We apparently are being duly represented. --- Nov. 12 The New Mexican, Santa Fe, N.M., on the elections: What the voters did on Nov. 6 should give neither the Republicans nor the Democrats much comfort. Neither major party really won or lost much. Although the returns gave a few members reason to worry because of the closeness of the tally, they set the U.S. on no new course. The state of the economy and events in the Persian Gulf will probably do more to shape politics in the next two years than did Election Day, 1990. . .. If messages were sent to Congress they were that taxes are unpopular, perhaps even more unpopular than the Democrats believed. Despite the difficulty of this year's tax fight, and the votes' reaction to it, taxes will probably be an issue both in 1991 and 1992. The sour taste of the 1990 tax debate likely sets the stage for harder fights over budget cutting in 1991 and 1992. ... ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: and 1992.
DOC.TEXT: --- Nov. 9 The Dallas Morning News on William Bennett's legacy: The resignation of William Bennett as director of the Office of National Drug Control Strategy should have the Bush administration thinking seriously about where it wishes to go from here. Is the nation to stay the course in aggressively confronting the challenge of illegal drugs, or is a new approach called for? The chorus of voices calling for drug legalization should not obscure the fact that the nation does appear to have achieved some success in reducing certain kinds of drug use among certain segments of the population. Moreover, the price of cocaine is reportedly down, and the product being sold on the street is said to be unusually diluted. No one is claiming victory. And whether Mr. Bennett can take credit for even these limited successes is open to question. But to shirk from our commitment to an aggressive two-track policy based on education and law enforcement could reverse even these few favorable signs. The fact is that Mr. Bennett's strength has reposed in his ability to move national debates forward. ... --- Nov. 7 The Times, Trenton, N.J., on the Bush administration's gag order on abortion information: Late last month the U.S. Supreme Court heard oral arguments on a case in which the verdict ought to be a foregone conclusion. At its heart is the Reagan-Bush administration's gag order that bars government subsidized family planning clinics from giving any information about abortion to their clients, even in answer to direct questions. It is the Bush administration's intent to block the option (of abortion) by trampling upon the priceless right of free speech and the priceless obligation of professional responsibility. The court won't find many easier cases than this one. It should throw those regulations into the Potomac River. --- Nov. 9 The Plain Dealer, Cleveland, on the S&L bailout: Grim as it is, regulators and taxpayers should keep an eye on the intricate S&L cleanup process. Timely action - including closing down reckless thrifts, selling off RTC (Resolution Trust Corporation) assets, strengthening the Bank Insurance Fund and reforming federal deposit insurance - will save taxpayers money in the long run. The voters are already hopping mad about the thrift fiasco. There is no excuse for Washington's further delay in speeding the inevitable S&L salvage operation. --- Nov. 13 The Atlanta Constitution on the Noriega tapes: What poses the real threat to Manuel Antonio Noriega's right to a fair trial? Is it the airing by Cable News Network of a few leaked recordings of privileged conversations between the ousted Panamanian dictator and his legal defense team? Or is it the bald fact that federal agents taped an unknown nubmer of telephone discussions involving Noriega and his attorney and legal staff, and thus may possess important clues as to the direction his defense strategists will take, clues that a prosecutor could use, if he were so minded, to parry effectively his adversary's courtroom thrusts? The latter possibility seems a far more plausible menace to a fair hearing for the accused drug trafficker Noriega than the off-chance that potential jurors might be swayed by his conversations as broadcast by CNN. (By the way, one has to wonder why some official made the tapes available to CNN.) The case against Noriega is already burdened with constitutional issues: the circumstances of his capture and the gathering of evidence; the release of sensitive documents to the defense; and, until recently, the freezing of Noriega assets needed to pay for his defense. And now this - the feds poking their noses into a supposedly inviolate legal communication. It's hard to imagine anything they might have learned in these conversations that would be worth taking a gamble with his trial. The proceeding, after all, was meant to be a culmination of one of the objectives President Bush set for the country in invading Panama last December. It is vital that the case be won. It is no less vital that the trial be perceived around the world as fair. Alas, it's not likely to work out that way. The feds could hardly have done a better job of jeopardizing the case if they tried. --- Nov. 11 The Houston Post on ocean dumping: A quick glance at the globe shows most of the Earth is covered by water. There seems to be so much of it that it's hard to imagine that mere humans could make a difference in the vast seas. But we've been giving it the old college try. ... It's time to stop and think about the future and consider the oceans aren't as limitless as previously thought. Fortunately, the world's largest industrial nations have reached agreement on a global ban on dumping industrial waste at sea and moved toward restricting marine pollution discharged on land. At a meeting of the 43 signatory nations to the London Dumping Convention, a consensus was reached to phase out industrial waste dumping at sea by 1995. It is legally binding on all the nations that signed the 20-year-old London treaty, including the United States, Britain, Germany, France, the Soviet Union and almost all other industrialized nations. ... The international agreement calls for dumping to stop without increasing pollution in other parts of the environment. Nations are encouraged to promote cleaner industrial processes, recycling, treatment of waste on land and more research and development on environmentally sound means of waste disposal. These goals are to be applauded ... the seas must not be turned into sewers. ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: into sewers.
DOC.TEXT: --- Nov. 8 The Independent, London, on the U.S. elections: ... American voters ... are against the budget deficit, but do not want to pay higher taxes. They are against the rich, but not eager to spend money on the poor. They dislike incumbent politicians, but are unimpressed by their rivals. They want to be strong abroad, but are - understandably - hesitant about war. If the president could offer clear policies he might get a clear verdict from the voters. As it is, his indecision has been reflected in the indecision of the voters. He emerges with less authority in Congress and therefore in the world. --- Nov. 12 Neue Zuercher Zeitung, Zurich, Switzerland, on Iraq's holding of Western hostages: Undoubtedly the Iraqi regime, through a masterfully staged operation to soften hearts, is intent on diverting the western public from an initially generally accepted insight and the resulting willingness for resolute containment of Iraqi arrogance. By now every diplomatic step conveying to Saddam the illusion that his strategy can succeed is a mistake. The Iraqi dictator's room for maneuver for withdrawing from Kuwait out of political insight is getting tight now that even Moscow is not explicitly ruling out the ``force option'' anymore. And for the American President Bush and the United Nations a military resolution of the Gulf crisis is becoming increasingly unavoidable as diplomatic options are exhausted or prove fruitless. Travelers in humanity have no right to disavow their great political responsibility in this test case of a new world order. --- Nov. 7 The Times of India, New Delhi, on Israel and the Palestinians: How long can the global community, whose will is expressed through the U.N., tolerate Israel's adamant refusal to even consider any move designed to guarantee the security of Palestinians living in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip? ... the U.S. and its Western allies are working to have Iraq charged with ``war crimes'' in Kuwait. Yet, what Israel is doing to the Palestinians in the occupied territories is scarcely less reprehensible. How can the West, much less the U.N., allow double standards to be applied, to put Iraq in the dock but let Israel go scot-free? --- Nov. 12 Financial Times, London, on world trade talks: The Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations stands on the brink of failure, following the breakdown of talks on farm reform over the weekend. As expected, proposals by the European Community, which imply further cuts in support of only some 15 percent between now and 1996, have been roundly rejected by its partners in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Developing countries, many of which have spent the last decade liberalizing their own economies at the self-righteous behest of the industrial world, have a right to feel cruelly deceived by the EC's grudging attitude ... It would be understandable if farm exporters such as Argentina concluded there was no further benefit in carrying on ... Washington and Brussels must back away from the self-serving approach that has nearly brought the Round to disaster. This is not only dangerous ... It also risks fuelling political instability in the developing world and Eastern Europe just when global cooperation is needed to overcome the crisis in the (Persian) gulf. --- Nov. 13 The Guardian, Lagos, Nigeria, on France's tying $1.5 billion in development grants to Africa to democratic reforms: This is because, in the view of the French government, democracy and development are inseparable. In other words, African countries are being told this: If you want aid for development prepare for true democracy. Fortunately, the values of democracy, such as equality, freedom and popular participation, are values we should all cherish. And whoever wants to promote these values cannot be an enemy of the people. There is indeed some good reason for linking democracy and development. As long as African countries remain minority authoritarian regimes, aid flowing to them is easily converted into means for enriching their invariably corrupt elite that exploits the people and diverts the aid into building up arms with which to suppress them. --- Nov. 13 The Daily Telegraph, London, on the enthronement of Emperor Akihito of Japan: The enthronement ceremony itself, which transforms the emperor into a living god, marks a partial regression to the era before Gen. MacArthur compelled Emperor Hirohito to divest himself of the divine status in the name of which terrible things were done half a century ago. Greater sensitivity toward the feelings, in particular, of the countries occupied during Japan's militarist phase is in order. The West, though, should also take these into account when pressing Japan to send military forces to the (Persian) Gulf. While a much greater financial contribution toward the Gulf effort is desirable - as Japan is more dependent on the region for its oil than any major Western nation - the rejection last week of a proposal to authorize the deployment of its forces is probably a healthy acknowledgment of external opinion by Japan's postwar political system. ---
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Roundup
Gorbachev Warns of Disaster if Bid for Unity with Yeltsin Fails
DOC.TEXT:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev says he fears bloody social upheaval if he fails in his efforts to reach a power-sharing agreement with Russian republic President Boris Yeltsin. Gorbachev met Sunday with Yeltsin and pressed him to sign a new union treaty as a means of preserving the federation of 15 republics, to be renamed ``The Union of Sovereign Republics.'' ``The Union of Sovereign Republics, to use the military idiom, is the last trench line,'' Gorbachev told senior military officers at a Kremlin meeting on Tuesday. ``The disintegration of the state begins beyond,'' he said in remarks quoted by the official news agency Tass. Dissolution of the Soviet Union ``could turn into a bloodbath,'' Tass paraphrased him as saying. ``A situation may arise that will be worse than during the Cultural Revolution in China,'' Gorbachev said, referring to the tumultuous final decade of Mao Tse-tung in China from 1966-76, according to Tass. Mao's attempt to revive revolutionary fervor in China sparked a violent struggle for power. An estimated 1 million people died.
Gorbachev made a similar comment in March, grappling with a crisis over Baltic separatism and facing a Russian parliamentary election that eventually put Yeltsin in power of the country's largest and most populous republic. Gorbachev and Yeltsin met for five hours on Sunday in a major initiative to end the paralysis of power in the Soviet Union. Gorbachev confirmed Yeltsin's statement that the two had set up commissions to decide how to divide authority between the central Soviet government and the Russian government, which has emerged as an independent force since Yeltsin was elected its president in June. The Soviet and Russian commissions will work while representatives of the 15 republics try to negotiate a new union treaty to replace the 1924 charter that forms the basis of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Despite the agreement between Gorbachev and Yeltsin on the need to compromise, the two leaders seem to differ on whether to first conclude the union treaty or to define the respective powers of their rival governments. Yeltsin, addressing the Russian legislature on Tuesday, said that during Sunday's meeting, the Soviet leader ``insisted on rushing quickly through'' completion of a union treaty, ``and that Russia should play a great consolidating role in the process of signing a new union treaty. But Yeltsin said he insisted that Gorbachev respect the sovereignty of the Russian republic. He said he would sign such a treaty only after the central government and republics had carefully defined their powers. Russia, which contains more than half the Soviet Union's 287 million people and is rich in natural resources, holds a de facto veto over many of Gorbachev's decisions. In recent months, Gorbachev and Yeltsin and their respective parliaments have issued conflicting decrees and laws that have complicated even simple transactions. That in turn has worsened an already dire shortage of food and consumer goods at the outset of winter. Yeltsin said the commissions appointed by the two leaders ``must clearly define the functions of the governments.'' He said the panels will cover ``division of property, the use of the natural wealth, (use of) foreign currency, debts, financial resources, tax policies, the banking system, on the role of the banks, and the independence of foreign economic trade by Russia, preparation and implementation of convertibility of the ruble, the budget of 1991.'' He said Gorbachev agreed to cede to Russia some elements of the KGB security police, to give the Russian government a voice in military reforms, and to share millions of dollars the German government is paying Moscow to aid the repatriation of Soviet troops.

DOC.HEAD: `Tarzan': A Politician With A Flair For The Dramatic
With PM-Britain-Thatcher, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: After nearly five years out of office, former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine is a more dominant national figure now than when he stormed out of Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet. That reflects both a flair for the dramatic and the patience to wait for the prime minister to stumble. Tall and handsome with flowing blond hair and piercing blue eyes, the 57-year-old Heseltine is a self-made millionaire who doesn't quite fit any faction of the governing Conservative Party. To admirers in the party, Heseltine looks like a savior. Critics accuse him of volatility and showmanship. As his challenge to her leadership loomed, Thatcher aides commented, ``all glamour and no substance.'' He has carried the nickname of ``Tarzan'' since 1976 when he grabbed the heavy ceremonial mace in the House of Commons and swung it over his head at Labor Party left-wingers who were singing their anthem, ``The Red Flag.'' As defense secretary from 1983 to 1986 at the height of the propaganda battle over the deployment of U.S. nuclear missiles in Britain, Heseltine donned a flak jacket for a confrontation with anti-nuclear protesters at a missile base. Politically, he's dead center in the party while Mrs. Thatcher stands well to the right. But many on the Tory left distrust him for views that include enthusiasm for a program in the United States that requires unemployed to work for welfare. He calls his political philosophy ``caring capitalism'' that contrasts with the free-market stance of Thatcherism. ``For any democratic government, the challenge is to take people a little further than they can go by themselves,'' he once wrote. ``And when need be, to show that compassion for which the marketplace makes no allowance.'' Michael Jones, political editor of London's conservative Sunday Times, wrote of Heseltine: ``He has the trick of making Tory supporters feel good about themselves, of making them feel that capitalism can have a moral base.'' While a member of Mrs. Thatcher's government, Heseltine was the golden boy and seemed destined for bigger things. The rift came in 1986 in a dispute over the buy-out of the financially troubled British helicopter manufacturer Westland PLC. Heseltine, always pro-Europe, favored a European consortium while Mrs. Thatcher favored the U.S. corporation Sikorsky. To the surprise of nearly everyone, Heseltine stood up in the middle of a Cabinet meeting in January 1986 and walked out. ``Of course I miss it hugely,'' he mused earlier this year of his long exile from government. ``I regretted profoundly the need to leave the Cabinet, but I have never had any doubts that it was the right thing to do.'' Most other casualties of the Thatcher Cabinets have fallen into political obscurity. But Heseltine conducted a patient campaign of a leader in waiting. He has swept around the country addressing party meetings - an average of five a week -opening fetes, spreading goodwill and glamour and assiduously avoiding direct criticism of Mrs. Thatcher. Subtle criticisms, however, were always there, particularly about her combative stance against the European Community and a controversial new local government tax, the so-called poll tax. Michael Ray Dibdin Heseltine was born March 21, 1933, into a middle-class Welsh family. His father was a structural engineer and part-time army colonel. As an undergraduate at Oxford, Heseltine mapped out his ambitions: to make a fortune in business and become prime minister. Starting with a 1,000-pound legacy from his grandfather, he made one fortune in property and then another in magazine publishing. He and his wife, Anne, who have two daughters and a son, live in considerable style: a magnificent period house in London's Belgravia district and a country mansion where he has planted 2,500 species of trees and shrubs. It also has a lake for his lifelong hobby of bird-watching. ``I haven't been driven by money,'' Heseltine once said. ``I saw money as an important part of the process of being independent - and in enabling me to pursue a political career.'' After two unsuccessful attempts, he was elected to Parliament in 1966. He got his first government job as minister of aerospace in 1972 in Edward Heath's Conservative government. Mrs. Thatcher appointed him to her first Cabinet as environment secretary when she won power in 1979 and then defense secretary.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS NEW YORK-dated item in PM-Names, a0497, to CORRECT spelling to Piniella sted Pinella.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, Ronald Reagan, Jimmy Carter, Gerald Ford and Richard Nixon will be among recipients of the Ellis Island Medal of Honor. The medals honoring representatives from various ethnic backgrounds will be presented Dec. 9 at Ellis Island in New York Harbor. The winners are selected by the National Ethnic Coalition of Organizations. The medals were last awarded in 1986. Other recipients announced Tuesday included Frank Sinatra, songwriter Paul Simon, former congresswoman Barbara Jordan, Cincinnati Reds manager Lou Piniella and sportscaster Phil Rizzuto.

DOC.HEAD: Poland and Germany Sign Historic Border Treaty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 18 grafs to UPDATE with comment from officials, MOVES UP reference to treaty's provisions. Pickup 10th, `Genscher was...'
DOC.TEXT: Poland and Germany today formally settled one of the last disputes of World War II, signing a treaty confirming their long-questioned border on the Oder and Neisse rivers. In the pact, Germany abandons claim to 40,000 square miles of its former territory in East Prussia, Pomerania and Silesia that was added to Poland after the war. The land Poland gained from Germany made up for a much greater expanse of land in the east taken from Poland by the Soviet Union. The formerly German lands account for about one-third of Poland today. The treaty commits the countries to building ``a peaceful European order, in which borders will not divide and which ... will ensure permanent peace, freedom and stability.'' The pact was signed by Foreign Ministers Hans-Dietrich Genscher of Germany and Krzysztof Skubiszewski of Poland at the Council of Ministers building, seat of the Polish government. Skubiszewski said ``both nations should congratulate themselves'' for closing a difficult chapter in their histories. Genscher said the loss of German lands confirmed by the pact was the fault of the ``criminal system'' in Germany during World War II. In a speech after the signing, he called the treaty ``a decisive step between both our countries and for the future of Europe, a step of historical dimension.'' He said the pact shows the newly united Germany's will to establish a firm basis of friendship with Poland. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and his assembled Cabinet stood by as the two-page document was signed. Final agreement on the treaty was reached at a border meeting Thursday between Mazowiecki and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Mazowiecki made what appeared to be Poland's strongest statement of apology to the Germans for the loss of their lands. ``We ask for forgiveness,'' he said. ``The suffering of the German nation must be spoken about. ... Every harm remains a harm, every tragedy remains a tragedy, irrespective of the harms and tragedies that we ourselves experienced.'' Winning unequivocal German acceptance of the border has been one of Poland's chief foreign policy goals. Genscher expressed sympathy for the millions of Germans who lost homes that fell within the new Polish borders after the war. ``The decision we have made ... is not an easy one for us Germans, for none of us, for me neither. And for those who have lost their home lands, who suffered expulsion, it is an especially painful one,'' he said. The treaty signing is seen as a boost for Mazowiecki, engaged in an uphill campaign for president against Solidarity Chairman Lech Walesa. Genscher was to meet with both Mazowiecki and Walesa during his one-day visit, as well as with outgoing President Wojciech Jaruzelski and Cardinal Jozef Glemp, leader of Poland's powerful Roman Catholic Church. Stalin urged the border on the Oder and Neisse rivers at Potsdam in 1945, and Britain and the United States accepted. By that time, the Soviets had installed an obedient government in Poland and were occupying eastern Germany. As a result, millions of Germans fled or were roughly expelled from lands that had been home to German speakers for centuries. In their stead came millions more Poles from the east, whose former homes had fallen within the expanded borders of the Soviet Union. By insisting the border be moved so deeply into former German territory, Stalin partly compensated the Poles for his own land seizures, punished Germany for the war and bound Poland to Moscow as the ultimate guarantor of its western frontier. Communist East Germany recognized the Oder-Neisse line in 1950 and West Germany disavowed any territorial claims in 1970, but conservatives and politically influential associations of those expelled from German land pressed for decades to regain all or part of Germany's lost territories. Under the timetable agreed to by Kohl and Mazowiecki, the border treaty will be ratified by the end of February by parliaments of both countries. At the same time, a broader friendship treaty is to be ready for ratification too. Among other things, that pact will contain assurances of minority rights for the up to 1 million ethnic Germans still living in Poland.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Urges Land Redistribution, Compensation to Dispossessed
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress today called for urgent land redistribution to end the white domination of property and to restore land that blacks lost under apartheid laws. In its first comprehensive report on a future land policy, the group said that nationalizing property was one of several options for reaching a more equitable distribution of land. ``In the context of a mixed economy, there would only be selective nationalization, and ... the distribution of this land would be based on land-use needs,'' the report said. It said landowners in those cases would be compensated in cash and bonds. But the report also said compensation would be ``due from present owners on the basis of the benefits they have received (from the land) to those (blacks) who were dispossessed.'' The 20-page report was based on discussions last month of the ANC's Land Commission Workshop. Whites make up about 16 percent of the population of South Africa but own 87 percent of the land. The imbalance in land ownership is becoming a major issue as the government and black opposition groups move closer to negotiations on a new constitution to give blacks a share of power. President F.W. de Klerk has promised to end apartheid and repeal decades-old land laws that forced millions of blacks into designated townships and rural tribal homelands. Blacks are able to own property in the townships and homelands. White landowners, and farmers in particular, have expressed fears that they could lose their property under a black government. According to the ANC report, workshop delegates envisioned a system of ``one person, one farm'' in a future South Africa and agreed that the state should play the principal role in redistribution of land. A land commission is needed to oversee land claims, and an affirmative action program is needed to help blacks once they have acquired property, the report said. Priority would be given to acquiring land claimed by entire communities, it said, and factors to be considered would include whether the land had been neglected or underutilized. Those people who lose their land under such a plan should be paid 25 percent cash; 25 percent in 10-year government bonds; and 50 percent in industrial bonds, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Policeman Says He Grabbed Gunman's Rifle As He Aimed At Leaders
DOC.TEXT: A policeman said today he grabbed the barrel of a hunting rifle as a marcher in a parade aimed it in the direction of Soviet leaders watching Revolution Day ceremonies in Red Square earlier this month. Up until now, official reports on the Nov. 7 incident had not said what the gunman's target was. But the policeman, Sgt. Andrei Mylnikov, said the gunman was aiming at the reviewing stand atop the Lenin Mausoleum where Soviet leaders, including President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, were standing. Mylnikov said he was three yards away when the man pulled the rifle from under his coat. He rushed the gunman and forced the gun barrel into the air just before he fired, the official Tass news agency quoted the policeman as telling a news conference. ``I ran up to him and, snatching the hunting gun barrel with both hands, sharply raised it upwards,'' Mylnikov said. ``At that time, the first shot was fired.'' Although he said the gun was aimed at the reviewing stand, he did not say whether the gunman seemed to be trying to hit a specific leader. Mylinkov said a second shot was fired over the heads of police guarding the square, but by then they had enough warning from the commotion to ``bend down or fall to the ground,'' he said. ``After that, the gunman was apprehended,'' he said. ``I snatched the gun from his hands.'' About 20 plainclothes police seized Alexander A. Shmonov, 38, an unemployed worker from Leningrad, and bundled him off to the GUM department store across the square from Gorbachev. He has been charged with ``attempted terrorism,'' and Tass said today he was being held in a KGB ``investigating isolation ward.'' Tass quoted KGB investigator Pyotr Sokolov as saying Shmonov's actions amounted to ``an attempt to commit a terrorist act.'' The gunman had been standing about 80 yards from the official reviewing stand. He was marching in a delegation from the Bauman region of Moscow during a pro-Communist demonstration. No one was hurt in the shootings, which came during an otherwise peaceful marking of the 73rd anniversary of the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution. The shooting occurred five minutes after Gorbachev, Russian Federation President Boris Yeltsin and other officials returned to the mausoleum after marching with the demonstrators.

DOC.HEAD: Police Drive Leftists From Mainzer Strasse
DOC.TEXT: Three thousand police fired tear gas and water cannons today during a successful five-hour battle to drive hundreds of leftist radicals from a dozen rundown tenements in eastern Berlin. Police and a special paramilitary unit used armored personnel carriers and bulldozers to break down barricades erected by the leftists. Hundreds of squatters living on Mainzer Strasse responded with firebombs and rocks. It was the third consecutive day of clashes on the street this week. ZDF television said several police officers were injured, but there was no immediate word on injuries among the squatters. ZDF said 135 people were arrested. Police raided Mainzer Strasse and adjoining blocks at 7 a.m. and battled for control for about five hours before driving the squatters from the ramshackle tenements splashed wtih slogans and signs, including ``Eat the rich.'' Berlin Interior Minister Erich Paetzold said today's clash was marked by ``unbelievable brutality'' from the radicals. Late Monday night and Tuesday morning, leftists battled with police for nearly 10 hours on Mainzer Strasse. About 137 police were injured and 20 people were arrested in those clashes. Fighting began Monday on Mainzer Strasse after police began evicting leftist radicals from houses in other parts of the city. The leftists say they have a right to the abandoned homes and have mobilized their supporters to resist police action. Police spokesman Werner Thronicker said Mainzer Strasse is headquarters for people responsible for ``serious criminal acts.'' Anarchists from the former West Berlin have taken over about 12 tenement buildings on the block in recent months and several houses elsewhere in eastern Berlin. While East Germany's democratic government did little to evict the squatters, officials have begun cracking down since German unification Oct. 3. The clashes have drawn new attention to the shortage of affordable housing in Berlin and other German cities. The situation is expected to be particularly acute in eastern Berlin, where many residents still pay relatively low rents. Under the former Communist system, rents were heavily subsidized by the government. They are to begin rising in January.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Company to Test Koala Springs Product
DOC.TEXT: The manufacturer of Koala Springs juice-flavored mineral water is testing its domestic product after small traces of benzene were found in its U.S. stocks. Koala Springs International has recalled its drinks from stores in the United States and eastern Canada following the discovery of traces of the toxic chemical, the same substance that forced Perrier to recall millions of bottles in February. Koala Springs said laboratory tests are being conducted in Australia on fruit concentrate used in its American-bottled product, and on locally bottled fruit mineral water. Tested as recently as June, Australian-bottled mineral water supplies had shown no traces of benzene, but further tests are being verified by the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories, the company said. Benzene is a naturally occurring chemical used in solvents. ``We have no thoughts of withdrawing our product until the results of the Australian tests are known,'' a company spokesman said today. The results of the government test would not be known for at least a week. Containers used to ship concentrates to the United States would also be tested, the company said. Benzene forced a recall this year for French mineral water giant Perrier. The company withdrew 160 million bottles worldwide, includine 72 million bottles in the United States and Canada. Perrier officials said benzene entered their water in trace amounts when workers failed to change a pipe filter at the company's natural spring at Vergeze in southern France. Koala Springs was originally exported bottled to the United States. But as its market grew it established links with contract bottling plants. John Chatham, president of Koala Springs International, said the company had recalled hundreds of thousands of bottles and cans of its product in the United States. ``We are taking this action willingly and voluntarily to protect our product and its good name,'' he said from the company's U.S. headquarters in Fremont, Calif. The move came after the Florida Health Department found samples with 11 to 18 parts per billion of benzene. That level does not pose a significant health risk but it exceeds the one part per billion allowed for bottled water under Florida law, a state health officer said. Last year, the company reported $152 million in worldwide sales, including $60 million in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: NBC, Fueled By 200th `Cheers,' Wins Prime Time Ratings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Overall, NBC...', to CORRECT to eight-tenths sted eighth of a rating point.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Nielsens-List
DOC.TEXT: The 200th episode of ``Cheers,'' a mock scholarly retrospective of Boston barroom comedy, got the highest ratings of any prime-time show this season. The hourlong NBC special, moderated by talk show host John McLaughlin, was seen in nearly 27.5 million homes last week, receiving a 29.5 rating and a 44 share, the A.C. Nielsen Co. reported Tuesday. A rating point equals 931,000 households with television. A share is the percentage of TV sets in use that are tuned to a show in its time period. ``One fourth of all women 25 to 54 in the country watched the show,'' said David Marans, a senior analyst for the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency. ``To put that in perspective, the No. 2 show for that group was `Roseanne,' which got a 17.0 (rating), - or one out of every seven women.'' Overall, NBC led with a 13.7 average rating and a 22 share. ABC edged CBS for second place by eight-tenths of a rating point, or about 745,000 TV homes, with a 12.8 rating and a 21 share; CBS had a 12.0 rating and a 20 share. NBC said ``Cheers'' has been the No. 1 show for six of the season's eight weeks. Thursday's rating also was the highest for any comedy series since ``The Cosby Show'' hit a 29.8 rating and 45 share on Jan. 12, 1989, the network said. The all-time ratings champ is CBS' last episode of ``M-A-S-H'' in 1983. Seen in nearly 50.5 million homes, it averaged a 77 percent share of the auidence in its time period, compared to 44 percent for ``Cheers'' on Thursday. ABC's ``Twin Peaks,'' the eccentric nighttime soap opera about the murky goings-on in a Pacific Northwest logging town, also got a boost in the ratings by at last revealing the killer of troubled homecoming queen Laura Palmer. ``Twin Peaks'' got a 10.4 rating and a 20 share by revealing that Leland Palmer, Laura's father, apparently killed her while possessed by the shadowy, demonic killer known only as ``Bob.'' The week before, ``Twin Peaks'' had a 7.9 rating and a 16 share. In the evening news ratings, ABC won for the 44th consecutive week with an 11.6 rating; CBS had a 10.1, NBC a 9.7. Following ``Cheers'' in prime time's top 10 were CBS' ``60 Minutes,'' with a 21.5 rating; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 20.0; and ``Designing Women'' on CBS tied CBS' ``Murphy Brown'' for fourth place with an 18.9. ``Empty Nest'' on NBC was sixth with an 18.6; ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' and ``Roseanne'' tied for seventh with an 18.5; No. 9 was CBS' ``Murder, She Wrote'' with an 18.4, and NBC's ``Unsolved Mysteries'' was 10th with a 16.2.

DOC.HEAD: Top Secret: Americans Recruited Anti-Soviet Guerrillas, Laid Arms Caches
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with former CIA chief quoted as saying he set up anti-Communist movement in Scandinavia. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `Training centers...' Minor editing thereafter to trim.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. intelligence recruited hundreds of guerrillas and laid weapons caches across Western Europe during the early days of Cold War as part of preparations for a feared Soviet invasion, a newspaper reported today. Only recently was the would-be resistance network disbanded, and several former high-ranking European officials say some of its hidden stockpiles of arms and explosives still existed just two months ago. The top secret organization, brought to light last month in Italy and codenamed Gladio there after the short swords used by Roman gladiators, is now under investigation for possible links to right-wing terrorism. The network is said to have had branches in Italy, Germany, France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Denmark, Norway, Austria, Spain, Greece and Portugal. The respected German newspaper Die Welt said today that even neutral Sweden and Switzerland took part. Sweden's TT news agency today quoted former CIA Director William Colby as saying that he organized an armed anti-Communist movement in a Scandinavian country during the 1950s, when he was based in Sweden. ``It cannot surprise anyone that such movements, networks, were organized in Western Europe to attack Communist occupation forces,'' Colby was quoted as telling TT. He was interviewed by phone at his Pebble Beach, Calif. home. He refused to name the Scandinavian country in which he organized a resistance movement. Die Welt said that soon after World War II, U.S. agents worked with intelligence agencies of ``various European countries'' in setting up the network and training natives as guerrilla fighters. The newspaper did not name its sources. ``Training centers sprang up'' in forests in the U.S.-occupied part of Germany, said Die Welt. At the centers, said the newspaper, ``former prisoners of war, men who had done civilian work for the occupying powers, and young men acquired by chance were trained in pistol-shooting, radio operations and tactics.''
