Pistols, grenade-launchers, explosives and radios were stored in secret caches to be used by the guerrillas, said Die Welt. ``The network was expanded to all of Western Europe by 1959,'' said Die Welt. ``Money was provided by intelligence agencies.'' The operation was designed to be an underground resistance network in case of a Soviet invasion in Western Europe. It mostly prepared communication networks, escape routes and sabotage plans, officials have said. Die Welt said the network's controlling body still exists in Belgium, thought only as a ``shell.'' In 1951, said Die Welt, allied intelligence agencies and each participating nation - Germany, Italy and France being among the first - agreed to set up a Clandestine Committee for Planning to oversee the network. Headquarters were initially in France, said the newspaper. The controlling body's name was changed to Allied Clandestine Committee in 1964, said Die Welt. The newspaper said that in the 1950s the network began ``systematic cooperation'' with the Brussels-based Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe, which worked with the group in maneuvers. The network was independent of NATO's control, said Die Welt. German officials were not immediately available for comment. In Paris, French President Francois Mitterrand on Tuesday confirmed that he had dissolved the French arm of the group but did not say when. He was first elected in 1981. ``I didn't have much left to dissolve,'' Mitterrand said. ``There only remained a few remnants, of which I learned the existence with some surprise because everyone had forgotten about them.'' The Paris newspaper Liberation said the French arm of the network was disbanded only after disclosures of the Italian operation had created a political controversy. Henk Vredeling, the Dutch defense minister from 1973-77, said he had been told about the existence of Gladio weapons caches on Dutch soil. One dump discovered in 1980 could supply a force of up to 150 men and enough explosives to destroy buildings and bridges, reports said. In Belgium, a former Gladio member and former Belgian army intelligence official, Andre Moyen, told the leftist newspaper Le Drapeau Rouge he knew of ``at least six arms caches'' hidden in Belgium up to two months ago. A former Belgian defense minister, Francois-Xavier de Donnea, said Gladio ``exercises were scrapped, perhaps as long as one or two years ago.'' During his 1985-1988 tenure, he said he was briefed on Gladio operations. Belgium is investigating links between the local branch and indiscriminate killings in supermarkets during the early 1980s that left at least 28 people dead. The murders have been linked by authorities to right-wing terrorism. Italian Premier Giulio Andreotti last month revealed the existence of Gladio, which he said had more than 600 members in his country. The operation caused controversy in Italy because of unconfirmed statements that the network might have been behind right-wing terrorist attacks in the early 1970s to keep Communists out of power. Venice Investigating Magistrate Felice Casson, a specialist in terrorism, discovered the existence of Gladio during a probe of a right-wing terrorist attack and has asked President Francesco Cossiga to testify about the group. In Greece, where the anti-Communist network was known as Sheepskin, caches with arms, ammunition, torches and other equipment were dug up between 1985 and 1988, when the network was dismantled.

DOC.HEAD: Large Screen Falls on ``Shogun'' Actor
DOC.TEXT: The leading man of ``Shogun'' was injured by a large piece of falling scenery as he was about to sing ``Death Walk'' at a preview performance of the new Broadway musical. Philip Casnoff was listed in stable condition today at St. Vincent's Hospital, said hospital spokeswoman Gina Gabriel. Tuesday's performance was canceled as actors, crew members and a doctor in the audience rushed to aid the injured actor. It was not known this morning if a preview peformance would be held tonight, or if the show would open on Thursday, as scheduled. Casnoff, 33, was about to sing a song called ``Death Walk,'' in the second act when an electric spark flashed and a prop, a large overhead screen, came crashing down, said Sam Rudy, a spokesman for the show. The screen struck Casnoff on the side of the head and then it tumbled into the orchestra pit. Casnoff was the only person injured. The actor suffered minor injuries to the face and neck, said Emergency Medical Service spokesman Capt. Edward Gabriel. ``He's going to be all right,'' Rudy said. The show is a musical rendition of James Clavell's best-selling novel and television miniseries. Casnoff plays a 17th century English sailor shipwrecked in Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Mystery Powder Found In Shuttle Hangar Not Coke
With PM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: A small bag of white powder found under a desk in the space shuttle hangar was not cocaine as originally believed, NASA said today. An initial analysis by NASA indicated the substance found in the building where shuttles are prepared for launch was cocaine. An investigation was opened by security officers from NASA and the contractors responsible for shuttle preparations and security at the Kennedy Space Center. But a subsequent test by state officials proved it was not cocaine, said NASA spokesman Karl Kristofferson. NASA conducted another test that identified the substance as calcium hydrogen phosphate, which is used in high school chemistry kits. Kristofferson said officials did not know how the bag got into the hangar.

DOC.HEAD: First City Elections Called in 11 Years in Punjab
DOC.TEXT: The Punjab state government said today that municipal elections will be held there next month for the first time since 1979, when they were halted because of militarism by Sikhs. The elections could be a first step toward restoring local control over the wealthy farming state bordering Pakistan, where some Sikhs have been fighting for independence. Also today, police said Moslems and Sikhs rampaged through a predominantly Hindu neighborhood of New Delhi, setting fire to shops, homes and vehicles and killing two Hindu men. Santosh K. Kain, a police commissioner, said at least 17 people were hospitalized. He said two Hindus were stabbed to death, three Hindu-owned shops and homes were set ablaze, and about 10 vehicles were set on fire. Police used gunfire, tear gas and truncheons to put down the riot, Kain said. More than 380 people, mostly Moslems, have been killed in riots across India in the past three weeks. The violence was caused by a Hindu campaign to replace a mosque with a temple in Ayodhya in northeastern India. Punjab state governor Virendra Verma, who was appointed by federal authorities, said elections would be held in three cities and 95 towns on Dec. 22 and 23, Press Trust of India reported from Chandigarh, the state capital. Chandra Shekhar, India's new prime minister, has said he expects to hold state government elections within five months. Punjab's state assembly was dismissed in 1986 when it lost control of Sikh militants, and the federal government took direct control. Federal control has been extended every six months and can remain in force until May. No municipal elections have been held in Punjab since 1979. All the city councils were dismissed in 1985. The announcement of elections came in spite of increased violence this year. More than 2,750 people have been killed by militants. Hindus comprise 82 percent of India's 880 million people. Moslems make up 12 percent, while Sikhs are 2 percent. Sikhs are in the majority in Punjab.

DOC.HEAD: Burma's Leader Says Dissident Committed Suicide
DOC.TEXT: Burma's military leader said in a speech broadcast today that a dissident who died in custody last week committed suicide, and was not tortured to death. Maung Ko, 52, an influential organizer of the opposition National League for Democracy, died in military custody on Friday while a U.N. human rights investigator was visiting the country. Political sources contacted in Rangoon said Tuesday on condition of anonymity that Maung Ko's relatives believe he died of torture. ``We did make necessary interrogations, but there was no reason for us to kill him,'' the head of the military government, Gen. Saw Maung, said in a speech broadcast on Burmese state television. He spoke on Tuesday. Maung Ko's death coincided with a visit to Burma by Sadako Ogata, a Japanese human rights expert who was looking into allegations of widespread abuse by the government. She left Burma on Sunday and is to report back to the U.N. Human Rights Commission in Geneva. Saw Maung denied his government used torture. He said a report he had received from the head of the military intelligence, Maj. Gen. Khin Nyunt, said Maung Ko, ``after confessing what they did and what their plans were, made use of a blanket there and hanged himself.'' ``This happened because of his own problems. Let me say it here today it did not happen because of our doing,'' he said. Khin Nyunt's Directorate of Defense Services Intelligence was cited by Amnesty International last week as the agency most widely blamed for torturing dissidents. The political sources said Maung Ko was arrested late last month and detained at a military intelligence center near Rangoon airport, where he died. Relatives and colleagues who attended Maung Ko's funeral in Rangoon on Sunday said his body was heavily bruised around the face, neck and body and there was blood around the mouth and ankles. They did not believe the suicide report, the sources said. ``On sheer personality grounds they found it difficult to believe. He was not the sort of person who would give up,'' one of the sources said. Maung Ko headed the league's workers wing and was a close associate of its general secretary, Aung San Suu Kyi, who has been under house arrest since July 1989. The league won the May 27 elections by a landslide but the government has refused to hand over power. The government came to power in 1988 after troops killed thousands of people to crush a mass movement for democracy. The political sources said death in detention from torture was not uncommon and often the government did not return victims' bodies to their relatives. It was unclear why they did so this time, they said. ``It may be because he was such a senior person, or that they felt they had nothing to hide. Or they may have done it to make an example of him,'' one said. The sources said the government had arrested at least 50 senior league members in its latest clampdown that began with raids on Buddhist monasteries last month. They said up to 200 monks also were detained.

DOC.HEAD: Day After Rod Removed From Heart, 8-Year-Old Asks to Play Nintendo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Justin was...', to explain that other veins will provide circulation for tied-off jugular vein.
DOC.TEXT: Surgeons unscrewed a steel rod from a brave 8-year-old impaled through the heart in a fall from a roof. Justin Stiner asked for some ice and wanted to play Nintendo on Tuesday after waking up from surgery, doctors said. ``He probably just thinks this is kind of a slight inconvenience in his life,'' said trauma surgeon Dr. Michael Esser. The 4-foot-long, {-inch-thick threaded bar used to reinforce concrete was literally unscrewed from the boy's neck and torso Monday in a 2{-hour operation at University Medical Center. Eighteen inches of the rod had penetrated his body. Justin was listed in critical condition. Esser said the heart wounds should heal fully, and although the boy's severed jugular vein was tied off, other veins can provide the needed circulation. The jugular vein carries blood back from the head to the heart. The 4-foot-10, 86-pound third-grader from Sierra Vista fell onto the rod while playing with friends on the roof of a house Monday morning. He was suspended two feet off the ground for about 20 minutes, alert the whole time, while paramedics cut the rod, which pierced him just below the breastbone. Justin, who was taken the 80 miles from Sierra Vista to Tucson by helicopter, neither panicked or screamed, and on arrival ``wanted to know if I was going to remove it. He was very cooperative,'' Dr. Phillip Richemont said. Esser and Richemont said the rod went through the right side of the heart, which has about one-third the pressure of the left side. ``He would have bled to death'' if it had been on the left side, Esser said. ``He's one lucky kid. It just didn't hit any arterial structures.'' Richemont said surgeons were stunned to find that the rod had pierced the heart in two places and divided the jugular vein. ``But yet it didn't bleed. It's amazing,'' Richemont said, calling it a one-in-a-million occurrence. During the operation, the heart seemingly ``contracted down between the threads,'' cutting off bleeding, Richemont said. The outcome, Esser said, ``makes us feel good. We have a lot that don't make it.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Jury Convicts Woman In Arsenic Killing
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) - A jury today convicted a woman in the arsenic-poisoning death of a former boyfriend. She is also accused of poisoning her first husband and trying to kill her present spouse. Blanche Taylor Moore, 57, showed no visible reaction when the murder verdict was read. The sons of victim Raymond Reid, who died in 1986, hugged and one cried. A sentencing hearing for Mrs. Moore was scheduled Thursday and prosecutors said they will seek the death penalty. Prosecutors said during the four-week trial that Mrs. Moore was driven by a need for money and that she killed Reid to gain part of his estate. The jury began deliberations Tuesday and the verdict was returned shortly after 10 a.m. today. Mrs. Moore also is charged with murder in the poisoning of her first husband, James Taylor, in 1973, and with assault for allegedly trying to kill her estranged husband, the Rev. Dwight Moore, after their honeymoon last year. No trial dates have been set on those charges. Mrs. Moore testified last week that she is innocent and she lovingly cared for the three men. ``I know arsenic was found in these three people, but I know that I didn't do it,'' she testified last week. ``I've never physically harmed other people. To physically harm a person, no, I did not do that.'' Officials exhumed five bodies while investigating the case, including those of Mrs. Moore's father, Taylor's mother and a former co-worker of Mrs. Moore's. They found arsenic in the remains of Mrs. Moore's father, Parker D. Kiser Sr., but she was not charged in connection with his death. Officials began investigating Reid's death after Moore's arsenic poisoning was discovered by doctors last year. Prosecutor Janet Branch said 53 witnesses supported the state's contention that Mrs. Moore fed home-cooked food to Reid while he was hospitalized at North Carolina Baptist Hospital in Winston-Salem. Prosecution witnesses also testified that Mrs. Moore sought to buy Anti-Ant, an insect poison. Mrs. Moore testified that she never sought the poison, never owned any of it and never fed Reid home-cooked food in the hospital. Defense attorneys tried to lay the blame for the deaths upon an acquaintance of Mrs. Moore's, Garvin Thomas. They produced a rambling, five-page letter in which he allegedly confessed to the crimes. Thomas died before the letter arrived at Mrs. Moore's jail cell. Handwriting experts differed on whether Mrs. Moore or Thomas could have penned the letter.

DOC.HEAD: St. Louis Encephalitis Up to 101 Confirmed Cases
DOC.TEXT: Seven new cases of St. Louis encephalitis have brought the state's number of confirmed cases to 101, but a state official said an end to the outbreak is in sight. An additional 45 people are on a ``presumptive'' list, meaning they've tested positive in the first of two tests necessary to verify that they have the mosquito-borne viral illness. ``We're on that trail where we're going to reach the end of this thing,'' said David Adams, a spokesman for the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services. Counts are down in mosquito traps in many counties and colder weather next month should reduce the numbers further, Adams said Tuesday. So far, six deaths have been attributed to the flu-like illness, which can turn fatal with brain inflammation. The youngest to die was 58. The typical death rate in an outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis is 7 percent. Eight deaths were reported in the last major outbreak, in 1977. Confirmed and presumptive cases then totaled only 110, significantly below the 146 combined cases reported this year since mid-August. Florida typically has one to five cases of St. Louis encephalitis each year and an outbreak every 10 years or so, Adams said.

DOC.HEAD: With Congress Challenging Troop Buildup, Baker Stresses Economics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Iraq denouncing maneuvers, Bush extending call-up, Quayle pressing Kaifu for Japanese presence in gulf, Iraqi letter to Security Council, edits to trim. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Challenged by congressional leaders over its new war footing, the Bush administration has begun to emphasize that American jobs could be at risk if Saddam Hussein is allowed to maintain his grip on Kuwait. Iraq today stepped up its accusations that the United States is preparing to attack. It denounced a plan by U.S. Marines to hold amphibious assault exercises in Saudi Arabia, calling it a ``clear act of provocation.'' Meanwhile, President Bush told Congress today he was extending for an additional 90 days the 90-day call-up for reservists already serving in the Persian Gulf region, and the United States pressed Japan to toughen its stance in the gulf crisis. In a setback for Arab diplomatic efforts, Saudi Arabia suggested it would probably not take part in a proposed Arab summit until Iraq pledged to pull out of Kuwait. The Saudi foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, said any Arab meetings ``will bear no fruit'' unless Iraq promises to adhere to the resolutions of the emergency Arab summit held in August and of the United Nations. King Hassan II of Morocco has proposed an emergency Arab summit to work out an Arab solution to the Persian Gulf crisis and avert war over Iraq's refusal to quit Kuwait, which it seized Aug. 2. The Saudi foreign minister's statement came on his arrival today in the United Arab Emirates, where he met with President Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al Nahyan. The remarks were distributed by the official Emirates news agency, WAM. The Iraqis say Saddam would consider attending the summit if he was consulted on the time and place and if the Palestinian issue is on the agenda. Bush was meeting at the White House today with a select group of lawmakers to try to bolster support for his gulf policy. Secretary of State James A. Baker III set the stage with comments a day earlier linking the economy and the Persian Gulf crisis. ``The economic lifeline of the industrial world runs from the gulf, and we cannot permit a dictator such as this to sit astride that economic lifeline,'' he said. ``To bring it down to the level of the average American citizen, let me say that means jobs.'' Baker suggested that a worldwide economic recession could result if Saddam is not checked and the security of gulf oil reserves ensured. He spoke after meeting in Bermuda with Canada's external affairs minister, Joe Clark, who voiced support for a U.S.-sponsored United Nations resolution authorizing the use of military force to drive Iraqi forces from Kuwait. The call for greater Japanese support for the anti-Iraq coalition came from Vice President Dan Quayle, who met in Tokyo with Japanese Prime Minsiter Toshiki Kaifu. Quayle said he told Kaifu Washington would like a Japanese presence in the gulf in addition to the billions of dollars Tokyo has committed there. Kaifu had proposed sending Japanese soldiers to be the gulf for non-combat duty, but the measure failed to win enough support in Parliament. The government and the opposition have now agreed to draft a new measure calling for the dispatch of Japanese civilians as part of peacekeeping efforts. Still, more allied soldiers and hardware may be on their way to join the U.S. expeditionary force that has gathered in the Saudi desert as the chief challenger to Saddam. The Times of London reported today that Britain is expected to send an additional 6,000 troops and more than 100 additional tanks to the gulf, increasing its ground forces there to 15,500 and its tanks to more than 220. The Bush administration has indicated that its readiness to attack Iraqi forces to dislodge them from Kuwait, if a U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq and saber-rattling fail. That position is encountering resistance from some allies abroad and some leading members of Congress who accuse the president of showing too much of an inclination to resort quickly to the military option. Bush last week decided to send 200,000 more troops to the Persian Gulf to bolster the 230,000 American GIs already there, putting U.S. forces on an offensive footing. On Tuesday, key Democratic and Republican senators asked him to convene an emergency session of Congress to discuss the administration's gulf policy. The White House quickly called such a session unnecessary. Said press secretary Marlin Fitzwater: ``There is no war.'' Iraq's harsh criticism of the U.S. plan for an amphibious assault exercise in Saudi Arabia came a day after the Pentagon announced it. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams would not say when or exactly where the exercise would be held. The Washington Times said it would be held 10 miles from Kuwait. ``This behaviour constitutes a clear act of provocation that exposes, along with other evidence, America's aggressive intentions against Iraq,'' the official Iraqi News Agency quoted an unidentified Iraqi government source as saying. Iraq also criticized the U.S. buildup in the region in a letter to the Security Council today. Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz said the United States was looking for an excuse to ``unleash aggression under a smoke screen by sowing confusion and organizing a campaign to mislead the American people, the United States Congress and world public opinion.''

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Inched Up 0.1 Percent in October
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf, Except for ... to delete extraneous character and make clothing stores decline 1.0 percent.
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales inched up 0.1 percent in October, fueled for the third straight month by the high cost of gasoline, the government said today. Excluding gasoline, sales fell 0.1 percent amid continuing signs of fading consumer confidence. The Commerce Department said sales totaled a seasonally adjusted $152.3 billion, up from $152.1 billion in September. The revised 1.3 percent gain in September was a bit stronger than the 1.1 percent increase originally reported. But excluding the gasoline impact, sales were up only 0.9 percent. Many analysts now believe the U.S. economy is in a recession which could be intensified by a drop in personal consumption. Retail sales represent about a half of all consumer spending, which itself accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. The department said retail sales since August have been artificially inflated by gasoline prices that surged after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and disrupted world petroleum markets - not by increased sales volume. Some of the other details in the report were suggested in advance last Thursday when the nation's biggest retailers reported dismal sales in October. Analysts have said consumers have become cautious in their spending in recent months after fears of war in the Persian Gulf added to their anxiety over the weakening economy. The Conference Board, a New York business research organization, has reported that consumer confidence in the economy plunged in October to the lowest level since 1981-82 recession. Sales at department stores, a key barometer of consumer sentiment, were off 0.6 percent after falling 1.1 percent in September. Automobile sales, which have been choppy through much of the year, slowed to a 0.7 percent gain from a 2.9 percent advance the previous month. Analysts have attributed much of the October sales to fleet purchases by rental car companies. Excluding the automobile category, sales were unchanged from the previous month. Auto sales were off 3.7 percent in August. Sales of durable goods, which include cars and other items expected to last more than three years, were up 0.7 percent following a 1.4 percent increase in September. Besides automobiles, other components of the durable category were mixed. Sales of furniture and other home furnishings fell 0.3 percent while building materials jumped 1.5 percent. Non-durable goods, which include food and gasoline, slipped 0.2 percent after a 1.2 percent gain a month earlier. Sales at gasoline stations rose 3.2 percent but analysts said in advance of the report the increase would reflect higher prices in the wake of the Iraqi invasion rather an an increase in volume. Except for a 1.6 percent increase in drug store sales, all other categories dropped - grocery stores down 0.5 percent, clothing stores down 1.0 percent and restaurant and bar, off 0.3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Says U.S. Wants A Japanese Presence In Gulf
With Gulf Rdp
LaserPhoto TOK4
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle told Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu today that Washington would like a Japanese presence in the Persian Gulf in addition to the billions of dollars Tokyo has committed there. Quayle told reporters he had expressed appreciation for the $4 billion Japan has offered to the U.S.-led force arrayed against Iraq and to the nations suffering economic losses because of the trade embargo against Baghdad. ``It has been an adequate response, but (we) hope for more,'' Quayle told reporters after meeting with Kaifu. ``I reaffirmed our interest in having a Japanese presence in the Persian Gulf.'' The vice president said it was up to Tokyo, and not Washington, to decide what form Japan's involvement would take. ``We are not going to detail what that presence should be. The Japanese political system will make that determination,'' he said. ``As Japan has achieved economic superpower status, there are certain responsibilities on a global basis that go with that.'' Kaifu proposed legislation that would have allowed Japanese soldiers to be deployed in the gulf for non-combat duty, but the measure failed to win enough support in Parliament. The governing Liberal Democratic Party and opposition groups have agreed to draft new legislation saying that Japanese civilians could be sent overseas as part of international peacekeeping efforts. Japan now has a small medical team in the gulf. Japan's Foreign Ministry said Kaifu responded that any further actions by Japan would have to be based on discussions in Parliament about the nation's international role. The ministry said Quayle also had asked Japan to foot a larger share of the cost of stationing U.S. forces in Japan. Japan's Constitution, which was written by U.S. officials at the conclusion of World War II, prohibits Japan from sending troops overseas. Quayle, who was in Japan for the enthronement of Emperor Akihito, left Tokyo soon after the meeting with Kaifu. On the issue of trade, Quayle reportedly gave a letter to Kaifu from President Bush in which the president reiterated the U.S. position that Tokyo should remove its ban on imports of rice, Japan's staple food. ``The Cold War must not be replaced by a trade war,'' Quayle said. ``The `R' word did pass my lips,'' he said, meaning rice. ``Japan has a rice problem, the United States has a problem with sugar and dairy,'' he added, referring to American agricultural products that receive government protection. ``Japan knows what the problems are ... and we just need to move this forward,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Report Details TV's Inadequate Depiction of Women
DOC.TEXT: In front of the camera and behind it, women in television have a long way to go before their numbers equal those of men. Not only are there far fewer women than men in virtually every aspect of TV production, but the depiction of women in prime-time programs perpetuates a stereotype of half-clad, half-brained creatures. Those findings highlight an 81-page study titled ``What's Wrong With This Picture?'' released today by Women in Film, a Los Angeles organization, and the Washington D.C.-based National Commission on Working Women. The yearlong study examined 80 prime-time programs on the ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox Broadcasting Co. networks. It assessed 555 TV characters and the producers, writers and directors responsible for creating them. ``Women continue to fare poorly on television - both on screen and behind the camera - despite significant gains over time and some notable, but scattered breakthroughs,'' the study said. ``Male characters outnumber females in on-screen portrayals (especially dramas), and men producers, writers and directors greatly outnumber women in those jobs.'' Specifically, the study found: - Fewer than half of all television series characters are women, compared to 51 percent of the general population; - Male drama characters outnumber women by almost two-to-one; - Only three percent of female TV characters are over the age of 60, compared to 14 percent in real life; - Men comprise 85 percent of television's producers, 91 percent of directors and 75 percent of writers. Of the four networks, Fox had the highest percentage of women producers, writers and directors, with 26 percent, 33 percent and 12 percent, respectively. Of prime-time shows, CBS' ``Sugar 'n' Spice'' (now canceled) had the highest percentage of female producers with 75 percent. CBS' ``Designing Women'' had the highest percentage of women writers with 83 percent and NBC's ``A Different World'' had the highest percentage of women directors with 96 percent. Still, more than half of the 80 shows studied had no female directors. The report did note that women have made inroads in television, especially with strong female leads such as nurse Colleen McMurphy in ABC's ``China Beach'' and journalist Murphy Brown on the CBS series of the same name. But such portrayals are the exception, not the rule, of TV programming, the report said. ``Despite working women's breakthroughs on TV, too many female characters remain the extension of male fantasies,'' it stated. And, it noted, ``It is virtually impossible to watch an evening of entertainment television without encountering young women in various states of undress. Men on TV wear more clothes than women, and they keep them on.''

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Rival Challenges Her Leadership
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 13th, `The same...' to ADD that Heseltine challenge will not involve a general election. Pickup 14th, `Mrs. Thatcher, who...'
DOC.TEXT: In the most serious challenge to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine said today he will contest her position as leader of the Conservative Party, and thus prime minister. Heseltine, who resigned as Mrs. Thatcher's defense minister in 1986, will run in a ballot among Conservative legislators next week. The challenge to Mrs. Thatcher after 11 years in power comes amid growing criticism within the governing party over the prime minister's reluctance to integrate with the European Community. The party also is suffering in the polls as a result of high interest rates, double-digit inflation and an unpopular local per-capita tax dubbed the ``poll tax.'' ``I am persuaded that I have a better prospect now than Mrs. Thatcher of leading the Conservative Party into a fourth election victory,'' said Heseltine, 57, in a statement broadcast on Sky Television. ``In essence, the prime minister holds views on Europe behind which she has not been able to maintain a united Cabinet. This damages the proper pursuit of Britain's national interest,'' Heseltine said. He said he decided to run because of deep divisions within the party over steps toward European unity and the Conservatives' recent third-place finish in a parliamentary special election. He promised to review the new local tax, which Mrs. Thatcher pushed through Parliament. There was no immediate statement from Mrs. Thatcher, but aides told reporters at her 10 Downing St. office that she was determined to defeat Heseltine. Kenneth Baker, the chairman of the Conservative Party, said Heseltine's candidacy was ``unnecessary and unwanted.'' ``More than 100 of my parliamentary colleagues have urged me to stand and promised me their support,'' Heseltine said. To win Tuesday, Mrs. Thatcher or Heseltine needs to get 50 percent of the votes cast by Tory legislators, plus 15 percent more than the opponent's vote. If all 372 Conservative legislators participate in the secret ballot, Heseltine would need 159 votes to force a second ballot, Mrs. Thatcher 214 votes to avoid one. The number of votes required decreases as the number of abstentions increases. The same rules apply on a second ballot, but other candidates could jump in. If that ballot fails to produce a winner, a third ballot would be held on Nov. 29, limited to the top three finishers in the second ballot. The winner is prime minister, and no general election is required. Mrs. Thatcher, who will be in Paris attending a 35-nation summit of leaders from East and West, will vote by proxy in the ballot, party officials said. Heseltine stepped forward a day after Sir Geoffrey Howe, who resigned as deputy prime minister Nov. 1, delivered a scathing attack in the House of Commons on the leader he had served throughout her years in power. ``The time has come for others to consider their own response to the tragic conflict of loyalty with which I have myself wrestled for perhaps too long,'' said Howe, who had been the last survivor of Mrs. Thatcher's first Cabinet in 1979. Howe resigned in protest of Mrs. Thatcher's rejection of a plan adopted by the 11 other European Community leaders at a summit in Rome to set up a single central bank by 1994 and a single currency, perhaps by the year 2000. Thatcher supporters on Tuesday came to her defense. ``To attempt to throw over Margaret Thatcher now would be an act of panic and madness, and a denial of all she has achieved over the past 11 years,'' parliamentarian Sir John Stokes said Tuesday in defense of the Tory leader. ``If the Tory party is sensible and pulls itself together it can still win the next general election without jettisoning the prime minister,'' he said. Lawmaker George Younger said the deployment of British troops in the Middle East made it the wrong time for a challenge against ``a critical world leader.'' Mrs. Thatcher has faced no serious challenge since she ousted former prime minister Edward Heath as party leader in 1975. The woman who faced down rebellious labor unions, slashed government spending and was known in the Soviet press as the ``Iron Lady'' served notice she would not go without a fight. Howe said he resigned because of a fundamental dispute with Mrs. Thatcher over policy on steps toward European union, an issue on which Heseltine has also disagreed with the prime minister. Howe contrasted Winston Churchill's vision of a United States of Europe with ``the nightmare image sometimes conjured up by the prime minister, who seems to look out on a continent that is positively teeming with ill-intentioned people.'' Though Europe is the issue on which the Conservatives have chosen to fight, the party is also under pressure because of double-digit inflation and interest rates of 14 percent. The opposition Labor Party, no longer the divided doctrinaire socialist party that Mrs. Thatcher easily defeated in 1979, has been ahead in opinion polls for 16 months.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Former Mayor Certified As New Mayor, Challengers Say Inelligible
DOC.TEXT: The city's former mayor, now a convicted felon, has been declared official winner of last week's mayoral race but faces a challenge from a group that says his conviction makes him ineligible for office. The Providence Board of Canvassers refused Tuesday to decide whether Vincent A. ``Buddy'' Cianci Jr. is barred from returning to office because of his 1984 conviction. Board members said their panel did not have authority to consider that issue, so Cianci's opponents took their case to the state Board of Elections. ``I'm not bothered by it,'' Cianci said. ``I don't think it's going to stop me from taking the oath of office.'' A challenge filed Friday by three Providence voters, and joined Tuesday by 15 others, argued Cianci should be barred from office under a 1986 amendment to the state Constitution. That amendment prohibits anyone convicted of a felony from holding office for three years after completing a sentence or probation. The Board of Elections scheduled a Monday hearing on the appeal. Cianci pleaded no contest on April 24, 1984, to assaulting a man he thought was having an affair with his estranged wife. In Rhode Island, a no contest plea is recorded as a conviction. He received a five-year suspended sentence, and the felony forced him from the office he had held for 10 years. Cianci's lawyer, Ronald DelSesto, said the 1986 law was not retroactive to Cianci's 1984 conviction. Cianci, a Republican, was certified the victor with 16,416 votes to independent Frederick Lippitt's 16,099 and Democrat Andrew Annaldo's 14,398. Incumbent Mayor Joseph R. Paolino Jr., a Democrat, ran unsuccessfully for governor.

DOC.HEAD: Four More ANC Members Sought in Alleged Plot
DOC.TEXT: Police said today they are searching for four African National Congress members in connection with an alleged plot to overthrow the government. The four are suspected of illegally importing arms, ammunition and explosives for so-called Operation Vula, police said. Eight other suspects were arrested in July and were recently charged in connection with the alleged plot against the government. They have been released on bail. The ANC says the government should not prosecute its members for Operation Vula, which it claims was part of regular ANC military activities before the armed struggle was suspended Aug. 6. Authorities say the African National Congress and its ally, the Communist Party, planned to topple the government by force if peace talks on ending apartheid failed. The government and the ANC, the leading black opposition movement, have been holding talks since May. Ronnie Kasrils, one of the four suspects sought and a high-ranking ANC and Communist Party member, went into hiding earlier this year when the government failed to extend a temporary amnesty for him. Police said the other three people sought are Janet Love, Charles Ndaba and Christopher Manye. Meanwhile, the Bophuthatswana black homeland said it detained 44 ANC members this week after authorities uncovered an alleged ANC plot to overthrow homeland leader Lucas Mangope. Clement Sehume, the Bophuthatswana education minister, said the crackdown was aimed at ``certain elements'' and not the ANC as a whole. The ANC, which considers the homelands part of the apartheid system of racial segregation and white dominance, denied plotting to kill Mangope or overthrow the government. The ANC and other anti-apartheid groups call for the homelands to be reincorporated into South Africa. Mangope has rejected such a move.

DOC.HEAD: 6-Year-Old Shoots Mother After Being Refused Coca-Cola
DOC.TEXT: A 6-year-old boy shot and seriously wounded his mother with a hunting rifle after she refused to let him drink a Coca-Cola, police said Wednesday. The boy, who was at home with his mother in their apartment Tuesday, took the rifle from the closet in his parents' bedroom and shot his mother in the abdomen, police said. The boy, whom police refused to name, told officers he loaded the gun himself. After pulling the trigger, he ran downstairs to seek help from neighbors, they said. The mother was taken to a hospital in Lille, a northern French city near the Belgian border, while the boy was put in temporary custody of a children's home.

DOC.HEAD: Police Put Down 1-month-old Revolt
DOC.TEXT: Police broke into a wing of Alikarnasus prison early Wednesday and crushed a revolt by 11 inmates that had lasted more than a month. Police reported that four prisoners and four prison officials were slightly injured when the inmates resisted. The uprising began Oct. 8 in protest over crowded living conditions in the small prison, located near this city on the island of Crete. The prison houses 130 convicts. The inmates initially took eight hostages but later released them and continued to occupy a prison wing. On Tuesday, they ignored a police ultimatum to return to their cells. The start of the rebellion at Alikarnasus sparked uprisings in other prisons throughout the country, including Korydallos, the maximum-security institution near Athens, a week later. That rebellion ended Monday.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Tamil Rebels Killed
DOC.TEXT: An army patrol in eastern Sri Lanka repelled a guerrilla ambush and killed four Tamil Tiger rebels, and seven more rebels were killed elsewhere around the island nation, military officials said Wednesday. The ambush occurred Tuesday near the village of Navathakuda in the Batticaloa district. Three more rebels were killed at Tellippalai and two in the town of Mullaitivu in northern Sri Lanka, the officials said. Two more rebels were killed in separate incidents. At least 14,000 people have been killed in the Sri Lanka's 7-year-old ethnic conflict in which Tamil separatists are fighting to create their own homeland in the north and east.

DOC.HEAD: In Baghdad, Word `Hostage' Out; `Guestage' In
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein has contributed a new word to the English language: ``guestages,'' short for ``guest-hostages.'' The Iraqi president's ministers routinely warn reporters not to refer to the thousands of Westerners banned from leaving Iraq as hostages. ``This is a very, very bad and dirty word and I'm not going to accept it,'' says Information and Culture Minister Latif Jassim during his news briefings. And a warning in Iraq today should be taken seriously. After several such warnings, the word ``guestages'' entered the lexicon of Iraqispeak. ``Are you a hos...'' The moment you ask any of the hundreds of Westerners held in Baghdad hotels, comes the swift reply: ``No, I'm a guestage.'' To tell the world that Western news reports on the conditions of hostages held at strategic sites are wrong, Iraq's state-run television has started a new program, ``Guest News,'' in which Americans, British, Japanese and Germans are shown playing pool or giving interviews. Understandably the hostages speak highly of Iraq. But some use sign language to convey their true feelings. --- Iraqis are obsessed with spying on each other. The practice is ctively encouraged by the authorities, who even urge schoolchildren to tell what their parents say at home. As Iraqis tell it, two officials spotted each other dining with western reporters in one of the fish restaurants along the banks of the Tigris River that flows through Baghdad. Both dutifully reported the fact to the Al-Amn, the secret police. Both were promptly transferred to remote towns. It is an accepted fact that foreigners' telephones are tapped. Lines are disconnected if people talk in a language the eavesdroppers don't understood. When a reporter called his home in India and started speaking in Bengali with his wife, the line went dead. There are no Bengali interpreters in Baghdad. On Fridays, the Moslem Sabbath, international calls are restricted to 10 minutes because there are not enough people to tap all the calls. In all of Baghdad, only one public telex functions. It's at the al-Rasheed Hotel, where all foreign journalists must stay. The telex is constantly monitored. People living in Baghdad, almost by habit, switch on the radio or play a tape when talking about politics or war so that their conversations can't be picked up by surveillance bugs. People in offices or at parties whisper when they talk. Iraqis are discouraged from talking to foreigners. Those who are found in the company of one are promptly hauled off for interrogation, or worse. --- ``The Iraqi president is probably the most protected world leader today,'' an Asian diplomat said. Taxi drivers warn their fares in advance not to point their finger in the direction of the presidential palace. Police patrols in Mercedes-Benz sedans scour the area around the palace, ready to arrest anyone who stops outside the perimeter walls. No pedestrians are allowed within a 500-yard radius of the heavily guarded complex, where multi-barreled anti-aircraft guns are manned round the clock. Saddam, who has survived several assassination attempts and coup plots since he took power in 1979, rarely appears in public in Baghdad these days. Foreign television networks allowed to interview him are told to be ready three days in advance. The actual interview is done suddenly at 30 minutes' notice. Cars are sent from the palace to pick up the TV crew. Not that foreigners on the crews get to do much. The networks can only use Iraqi cameramen and cameras for the interviews.

DOC.HEAD: Tennessee Company Recalls Floor Lamps
DOC.TEXT: Landmark Imports, Inc., of Memphis, Tenn., has recalled 24 planter-style floor lamps that the government says may pose an electrocution hazard, even when switched off. The voluntary recall, in cooperation with the Consumer Product Safety Commission, involves the model 4088 3-U planter floor lamp sold in the Memphis area last year. Most of the 24 units were obtained from Landmark by three stores: B&T Enterprises in South Medon, Tenn., and MTC Company and Import 1, both in Memphis. The model 4088 3-U features a single light socket at the top of a center post, and three planter supports at the ends of its U-shaped support legs. The danger, the CPSC said, stems from the possible use of excessively long screws used to attach the three metal support legs to the center post. The screws may pierce the power cord's insulation, meaning consumers could be electrocuted if they touched any part of the brass frame, the agency said. Purchasers of the model 4088 3-U should unplug it immediately and return it to the store for a refund of the purchase price. The lamp sold for about $40. Consumers with questions may call Landmark Imports at 901-346-0708.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Find First Biological Abnormality in Brains of Hyperactives
With AM-Heart-Hostility, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have discovered the first specifc abnormality in the brains of people with hyperactivity, the most common psychiatric disorder of childhood, and believe it may an underlying cause of the condition. Their study found that parts of the brain essential for attention and controlling behavior do not work as hard as usual in hyperactive people. Experts described this as a potentially important insight into the sources of the mysterious ailment. People have long suspected that some physical irregularity is at the heart of the disorder, which affects between 2 percent and 4 percent of school-age children. However, Dr. Alan J. Zametkin, who directed the research, said, ``This is the first large study of hyperactivity that shows some sort of metabolic abnormality.'' The research, conducted at the National Institute of Mental Health in Bethesda, Md., was published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. Brain scans of adults who had been afflicted with the disorder since childhood showed that their brain cells were 8 percent less active than those of normal people. However, the reduction was especially dramatic in the parts of the brain that control attention and inhibit behavior. Hyperactivity, known technically as attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder, is a serious ailment that makes children inattentive and impulsive. They tend to blurt out answers in school, run into the street without looking and constantly fidget, squirm and jump about. Their hot tempers and frequent disobedience make them difficult for parents and teachers to handle. About half the time, the disorder persists into adulthood, and victims are more likely to have run-ins with the law and abuse drugs and alcohol. About three-quarters of victims improve when given mild stimulant drugs, such as Ritalin. Just why these medicines work is unclear. However, they help people concentrate with less distraction and irritability. Zametkin said he hoped the latest findings will reduce the stigma attached to being treated for this disorder by showing that it involves a biological abnormality. Hyperactivity often runs in families. The latest study was conducted on 25 adults who had been hyperactive since childhood. They were also parents of hyperactive youngsters. The researchers compared the metabolism - the rate at which energy is used - in the brains of the hyperactive adults and 50 normal people. They found that brain activity was significantly reduced among hyperactives in 30 of 60 specific regions of the brain. In particular, they noticed reductions in the premotor cortex and the superior prefrontal cortex. These parts of the brain control attention. Damage to them can result in inattention and difficulty in controlling behavior. In an accompanying editorial, Dr. Gabrielle Weiss of Montreal Children's Hospital said the findings ``represent a clear advance in our understanding'' of hyperactivity. But whether low metabolism is the ultimate cause of hyperactivity is still unclear. ``I'm not going to say it's the cause,'' said Zametkin. ``We have to look at young kids and people with the non-genetic form of the disorder. But it's possible this has something to do with the cause.'' Dr. Paul H. Wender of the University of Utah said that finding any biological abnormality in a mental illness ``is of great interest.'' But he said it may not turn out to be the basic cause of hyperactivity. Instead, the cortex may be sluggish because of faulty control signals from a more primitive part of the brain. ``If the more primitive centers don't tell the guys upstairs to wake up, they won't have attention,'' he said. ``But the problem is not in the cortex. It's the guys downstais.'' Zametkin said that measuring brain metabolism may someday provide a way of accurately diagnosing hyperactivity. It could also allow doctors to check the effects of different drug treatments. Currently, he is studying how Ritalin changes the brain's metabolic activity. Zametkin conducted the newly published study by injecting sugar that contained a radioactive label. Then he performed positron-emission tomography, or PET scans. These produce cross-sectional pictures of the head that show how intensely the radioactive sugar is being used.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Rejects Extradition Appeal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs second-to-last graf, `No one...' with 1 graf to CLARIFY that statistic referring to the Irish republic. Pickup last, `The IRA...'
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court of Ireland today ordered the extradition to Britain of an alleged IRA bomber who is in his 36th day of a hunger strike to fight extradition. The accused man, Dessie Ellis, was flown by military aircraft to London after losing the appeal. He will stand trial in Britain on conspiracy and explosives possession charges arising from a 1981 London bombing campaign in which three people died, police said. It was the first time the Irish court has ordered the extradition to Britain of someone wanted on terrorist charges under new Irish laws intended to simplify the extradition procedure. The 38-year-old television engineer was hospitalized last week and was said to be ``very weak.'' He remained in the military hospital this morning and was not in court to hear the unanimous decision by the five judges. Angry Irish Republican Army supporters demonstrated outside the court building in central Dublin, and others gathered at the Baldonnel military air base outside Dublin, where Ellis left Ireland. Hundreds of Irish troops sealed off the base. Ellis had said he would rather die than be extradited to Britain. He said he will not get a fair hearing in Britain and asked to be tried in Ireland. Ellis already has served a six-year jail term in the Irish Republic for possessing explosives. Extradition has been a contentious issue between Britain and Ireland. Under the previous law, some suspects wanted in Britain have successfully pleaded that their alleged offenses were ``political.'' In Northern Ireland, 10 prisoners belonging to the IRA or the Irish National Liberation Army died on hunger strikes in Maze Prison in 1981. The best known was Bobby Sands, who was elected to the British Parliament during his 65-day hunger strike. No one has died while on a hunger strike in the Irish republic since 1946. The IRA is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. It wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland, under socialist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Clean Air Bill Signing Nears; Criticism Remains
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-two months into his presidency, George Bush has yet to make peace with environmentalists, even though he is about to sign legislation to clean up the nation's air. Bush, say the environmentalists, is more talk than substance. ``If I had to grade him, I'd have to give him a low `D'. A year ago, I'd have given him an `F', so he's moving up a little bit,'' said Mike Clark, president of Friends of the Earth. Bush ``has yet to prove he's an environmentalist,'' Clark added. Early in his term, Bush proclaimed himself pro-environment. On Thursday, he will sign the Clean Air Act of 1990 in a ceremony he is expected to try to use to reenforce that image. The legislation, totaling more than 1,000 pages, is designed to stem acid rain, urban smog and toxic industrial pollution by imposing tighter controls on automobiles, factories, coal-burning power plants and thousands of businesses. While leaders of environmentalist groups credit Bush for being a major player in ushering in the first air pollution controls in 13 years, they say there are many other issues, from global warming to protecting wetlands, on which the president has not met their test. Last summer, Bush expressed his irritation with environmentalists and declared that their ``grading system is absolutely ... absurd.'' ``I didn't rely heavily on them for support in getting elected ... and I'm not going to be persuaded that I can get some brownie points by appealing to (them),'' he snapped when asked by reporters at an international economics conference in Houston about environmentalists protesting his views on global warming. Among those targeted by Bush's remarks were such mainstream environmental groups as the Wilderness Society, the National Wildlife Federation and the Sierra Club, all of which have criticized the president. His remarks ``really blew the cover,'' Mike McCloskey, president of the Sierra Club. Until then, McCloskey said, environmentalists had thought that their problems with the White House were largely the work of aides such as presidential Chief of Staff John Sununu. ``The (president's) hostility really showed that's where he's at too,'' McCloskey said in a recent interview. Bush's signing of the clean air act is not expected to soften the criticism. ``This is his one and only significant environmental achievement and he certainly is not entitled to take sole credit for it,'' said George Frampton, president of the Wilderness Society. Among the few Bush actions widely praised by environmentalists is his appointment of William Reilly, a longtime conservationist, to head the Environmental Protection Agency. Reilly, highly respected in the environmental community, staunchly defends the president's environmental record and said in an interview that the president's critics often judge Bush against an unfair ``standard of perfection.'' Among the issues cited by administration officials are the president's ban on ivory imports to protect the African elephant and his decision last summer to postpone the leasing of oil-drilling sites off Florida and California until environmental concerns can be further examined. ``The president has many agendas and has to balance to achieve the best benefits to the country as a whole,'' Reilly said. ``By any objective measures, George Bush ... has done more for the environment than any president in my memory.'' Peter Dykstra, a spokesman for Greenpeace, counters that the president has shrewdly espoused concern for the environment ``and delivered less of the goods than any president.'' Bush has taken his hardest hits on environmental issues of broad, international concern such as global warming. When the latest conference on global warming concluded last week in Geneva, Sen. Al Gore, D-Tenn., said the Bush administration's performance was ``embarrassing (because) ... no one should have to drag us kicking and screaming'' to address the problem. While many industrial nations have established goals on cutting the pollutants that cause global warming, Bush steadfastly has refused to do so and maintains that scientists have yet to determine how serious a threat global warming will be. There is a long list of other issues on which Bush has disappointed environmentalists, said Sharon Newsome, a vice president for the National Wildlife Federation. She cited Bush's strong support for opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to oil exploration, a lack of progress in developing a formal policy to protect wetlands nearly two years after promising to do so and hints of wanting to reexamine the Endangered Species Act to more heavily take into account economic considerations - an issue spotlighted by the debate over the spotted owl in the Northwest. On Capitol Hill, the administration has almost consistently been on opposite sides from environmentalists, even in the debate over how strong clean air legislation should be, said the Sierra Club's McCloskey. He cited administration opposition to legislation that would have required higher fuel economy standards for automobiles; bills that would have reduced mining, logging and grazing on federal lands, and a bill to protect a vast California desert.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Growth At Near Standstill
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales growth slowed to a barely perceptible 0.1 percent in October, the government said Wednesday, prompting analysts to predict the holiday gift-buying season will be a bust. ``I think holiday sales are going to be pretty lousy,'' said economist Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York. ``Compared to Christmases past, it's just not going to look very good.'' Economist Sandra Shaber of the Futures Group in Washington agreed, pointing to two months of declining sales at department and clothing stores - often gauges of consumer sentiment. ``Consumers have a limited budget,'' she said. ``With the rapid deterioration of the job market and more inflation, consumers just simply have less money to spend.'' The Commerce Department said sales totaled a seasonally adjusted $152.3 billion, up from $152.1 billion in September. But like the previous two months, sales were artificially inflated by high gasoline prices, not volume. In fact, the department said sales actually fell 0.1 percent in October when gasoline purchases were excluded. The price of gasoline has spiraled since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait disrupted world oil markets. Analysts saw the report as further evidence of weakness in an economy that many believe is now in a recession. Retail sales represent about half of all consumer spending which itself accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. Ms. Shaber predicted a repeat of last year's holiday shopping season, when many retailers cut prices and offered other promotions to lure consumers to their salesrooms. ``It's really a very, very promotional Christmas already,'' she said. ``We have too many stores and too many malls now being aggravated by the erosion of household purchasing power.'' Retailers depend on the holiday shopping season for about half of their sales and profits. Automobiles, which represent about 20 percent of retail sales, slowed to a 0.7 percent gain from a 2.9 percent increase in September. But Steinberg said unit sales were down in October, suggesting the increase represented higher prices for new-model-year cars. Excluding the auto category, overall retail sales were unchanged from the previous month. Sales of durable goods, which include cars and other items expected to last more than three years, rose 0.7 percent, just half of their 1.4 percent gain a month earlier. Purchases of building materials rebounded 1.5 percent from a 1.5 percent drop in September, but sales of furniture and other home furnishings fell 0.3 percent. Non-durable sales, such as food and gasoline, slipped 0.2 percent after rising 1.2 percent the previous month. Gasoline service station sales were up 3.2 percent after increases of 5.6 percent in September and 7 percent immediately after the August invasion. But department store sales were down 0.6 percent after a 1.1 percent loss the previous month, while apparel purchases declined 1.0 percent following September's 1.7 percent drop. Sales at restaurants and bars were off 0.3 percent from a 0.4 percent increase a month earlier. But purchases at drug stores rose 1.6 percent after a 0.9 percent gain in September. ``People are taking more aspirin because they're more worried,'' Steinberg suggested.

DOC.HEAD: Time Capsule Stuffed With Book Reviews
DOC.TEXT: A time capsule prepared Wednesday by youngsters involved in a national reading program will give students in 2089 the impression that 20th century kids were a very literate bunch. Fifty selected book reviews of fourth-, fifth- and sixth-grade students from each state were placed in the time capsule that was ``buried'' at the Library of Congress to mark the second annual National Young Reader's Day. ``Six Months to Live'' tells ``how to cope with personal problems - the ones you can't change,'' 12-year-old Tiffany Harmon of Lexington, S.C. wrote. ``Kids growing up in the 1990s are faced with their own personal battles,'' Tiffany continued. ``Some of these include drugs, divorce, peer pressure, and stress.'' Thomas Daniel Tarantino of Camarillo, Calif., said of ``The Hobbit,'' ``You know, I've studied a lot about the Revolutionary War in school, but I never had such an in-depth look at the horror and sadness of war this book showed to me.'' ``I love to read,'' said 11-year-old Jennie Pacheco of Bristol, R.I. ``My mother told me when I was young that if I had a good book, I had a good friend.'' Jennie's favorite book is ``The Bridge to Terabithia,'' although she noted ``I read at least two books a week. I've read 100 books in the last two summers.'' The reviews were in the forms of letters in which youngsters displayed a sense of humor, as well as vivid imaginations. Jeremy Eggleston, 12, of Binghamton, N.Y., opened his letter, ``Hi earthling! Maybe I'd better not say `earthling' because in your time you might be living on Jupiter. Anyway, I live in the year 1990. When you receive this letter, you'll probably think my generation lived in `ancient' times.'' Ariane Kiel, 12, of St. Louis, Mo., said ``I am wondering how you enjoy books in the year, 2089. Is your home computer able to type out books directly from the local library? Can your watch tell stories? Do you take a book pill while you rest and then dream about the story?'' ``However you enjoy books, try to pick up `Number the Stars' by Lois Lowry,'' she said. The National Young Reader's Day was initiated jointly by Book It! National Reading Incentive Program, sponsored by Pizza Hut, and the Center for the Book in the Library of Congress to remind Americans of the joys and importance of books for the nation's youth. An estimated 27 million adult Americans are considered functionally illiterate - unable to read, write or compute well enough to function effectively in the workplace and in society.

DOC.HEAD: Time Is Running Out, British Official Warns Iraq
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
LaserPhoto DHA1
DOC.TEXT: British Defense Secretary Tom King warned Saddam Hussein on Wednesday that ``time is running out'' for the Iraqis to leave Kuwait or military force will be used. ``We are moving now into very critical weeks,'' King said at a news conference held beneath camouflage netting in the Saudi desert. ``We aren't going to keep our troops hanging around forever doing nothing,'' King said.``It would be a very foolish man indeed who thought we were bluffing.'' He refused to set an exact timetable, but he added: ``He better make a pretty early decision or he will have to take responsibility for the consequences that will follow.'' King spent the day on tank maneuvers with the 7th Armored Brigade, also known as the Desert Rats. He visited British air and naval stations in the Persian Gulf region to determine what more is needed. King declined to give precise details but said he wanted to see ``where else we can help and fit in the most effective way.'' He said reinforcements would arrive soon. The British have deployed 15,000 ground troops, more than 120 Challenger battle tanks, 50 combat aircraft and 12 warships. British ground and air forces are under the tactical control of the U.S. military. The Desert Rats are under the tactical command of the U.S. Marine Corps, which has been conducting joint training exercises with the British. In Saudi Arabia, all troops are under the control of Prince Khalid, but command and control of international forces under a single commander is still being worked out if fighting spreads outside the kingdom. As part of his mission, King met with Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of all U.S. forces involved in Operation Desert Shield. ``We will have absolutely clear command and control arrangements. I'm satisifed they are being achieved,'' King said. King rode in a tank with brigade commander Brig. Gen. Patrick Cordingly and Lt. Gen. Sir Peter de la Billiere, commander of all British forces in the Middle East. Meanwhile, King said the United Nations embargo designed to starve Iraq out of Kuwait is costing Saddam $1 billion a month in oil exports and $1 billion a month in import business. ``Stocks are starting to run out. They're starting to realize what total isolation from the world is going to mean,'' King said. But he added that the military option would be applied if Saddam refuses to abandon Kuwait. ``There must be no doubting our resolution. We don't want to see conflict, but the warning is quite clear. There are limits to our patience,'' King said. ``We can't allow the atrocities, the cruelty, the unbelievable behavior to go on month after month as though we didn't care,'' King said.

DOC.HEAD: Toxin Found Safe, Effective in Treating Muscle Spasms
DOC.TEXT: Minute injections of a highly poisonous toxin have been found effective and safe in treating a varity of involuntary muscle spasms, a committee of experts announced today at the National Institutes of Health. The toxin, obtained from a bacteria that causes botulism food poisoning, has been used successfully to treat spasms of the eyelids, throat, face and the vocal cords, the panel said. ``This is the most powerful toxin known,'' said Dr. Roger Duvoisin of the Robert Wood Medical School in New Brunswick, N.J. The complex protein, known formally as botulinum toxin, is produced by a bacteria in spoiled food and can lead to lethal food poisoning in large doses. Duvoisin said, however, that in very small injected doses the toxin has the ability to block signals from nerves to muscles. This action will halt involuntary muscle spasms. ``It has given relief where little was available before'' for muscle spasms, Duvoisin said. The injections have been used for patients whose lives were blighted by such ailments as the involuntary and uncontrollable closing of the eyelids, the inability to speak because of vocal cord spasms and facial tics that cause the muscles to contort repeatedly. The committee organized by NIH consisted of experts from around the country who evaluate clinical results from experimental use of the toxin in a variety of patients. ``We have seen at this conference impressive evidence that this is the first choice of treatment for several disabling disorders,'' Duvoisin said. ``Because of the high success rates of the toxin treatment, thousands of more patients have the potential to lead improved lives,'' he said. The committee called for additional studies to determine how else the toxin might be used and to better understand its precise action in the body. Injections of the toxin, which can cost from $400 to $1,800, must usually be repeated three to four times a year for continuous symptomatic relief. Duvoisin emphasized that the injections only control the symptoms of the muscle spasms and are not a permanent cure.

DOC.HEAD: Former Vietnamese Soldier on Healing Mission to US Veterans
LaserPhoto NY23
DOC.TEXT: Two decades ago Nguyen Ngoc Hung was creeping through the jungles of Southeast Asia, a North Vietnamese hunting American soldiers. Now he's telling his former enemies of the troubles they share: brothers missing in action and emotional problems. Hung has embarked on what he calls a ``healing mission'' to meet his former enemies. Other Vietnamese who fought the Americans have visited the United States, but none has come solely to talk to U.S. combat veterans. On Monday - Veterans Day - Hung stood in front of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Manhattan and pledged to organize Vietnamese combat veterans to search for the remains of U.S. serviceman. ``I doubt the diplomats can go into the jungle and forest and find the men buried in battle,'' he said. Moments after making the promise he prayed with American vets. One gave him a flower. At a meeting later in Harlem, Hung told his audience that Americans aren't the only ones with soldiers missing in action - his younger brother is one of 300,000 Vietnamese soldiers still unaccounted for. When he asked U.S. servicemen to help find North Vietnamese remains, a veteran in the audience replied: ``I can give you some of the grave sites.'' Hung, 42, joined the North Vietnamese army at 20 and fought from 1969 to 1975, mostly on foot and sometimes with the Viet Cong in South Vietnam. After the war, he finished college, studied English in England and Australia, and returned to Hanoi to teach at the Foreign Languages College. He and wife have two sons who are crazy about American music. After an interview with him in Vietnam was broadcast last year on ``60 Minutes,'' Hung was invited to visit by the National Network of Indochina Activists and the Asia Resource Center. Since arriving Nov. 1, he has met veterans in New York, Philadelphia and Washington, D.C., and visits are planned during the next month for New Haven, Conn.; Boston; Atlanta; Madison, Wis.; Pittsburgh; Los Angeles; San Francisco, and San Diego. A week ago, he met with a group of veterans with post-traumatic stress syndrome. ``They looked at me attentively as I came in,'' he said. But then they began to talk: about a mother's suspicious looks, about a girlfriend's rejection, about drugs and nightmares and flashbacks. Although some veterans have criticized the U.S. government's psychological programs for them, Hung was impressed. ``In Vietnam the government thought we were the winner, so their soldiers didn't have any problems,'' he said. In fact, ``the Vietnamese had flashbacks and nightmares and things like that, too.'' ``Psychology is new in Vietnam. We need something like that here,'' he said. ``One of my friends went crazy after the war, and they just sent him home. He's with his family, but ... he can't do anything.'' Still, he said, ``In our country we don't have a homeless veteran.'' At the Harlem meeting, one man asked about a rumor he'd heard - that Vietnamese sometimes allowed black soldiers to pass before opening fire on whites. Hung thought for a moment and answered: ``Yes.'' He later explained that the Viet Cong included villagers who by day mingled with many U.S. soldiers. When they became soldiers themselves at night, they would allow friendly faces to pass before firing at officers, many of whom were unpopular with local residents and most of whom happened to be white. ``Not all American soldiers were bad. Some gave food to the people,'' he said. ``We weren't shooting at the black or the white, we were shooting at the bad man. ``There was something nice and funny going on during the war that nobody wanted to dip into. It was kind of like if you behave, you were well, if you didn't behave, you were punished.'' New York state veteran counselor Daniel A. Friedman said he thinks Nguyen's visit is a good thing. ``I think it's healthy to bury the hatchet, to heal the wounds,'' said Friedman, who was at the Vietnam Memorial service. ``I think it's important for people to put the war behind them,'' Friedman said. ``My fellow Vietnam veterans who want to keep refighting the war are not helping themselves.''

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Kills At Least 112 People
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Mike roared out to sea Wednesday after killing at least 112 people and devastating the country's second most important industrial center. The typhoon, which hit the central Philippines Tuesday with peak winds of 150 mph, had weakened to 94 mph and was continuing west into the South China Sea late Wednesday, said Crisologo Enriquez, the Manila weather bureau's chief forecaster. About 140 people were missing and 320,000 refugees from te typhoon jammed schools, offices and makeshift evacuation centers. President Corazon Aquino, who returned Wednesday from Japan, declared 30 of the country's 73 provinces disaster areas. Among the most severely devastated areas was Cebu city, the most important industrial and transport center next to Manila, and Negros Occidental province, where millions of dollars worth of sugar crops could be lost. The typhoon sunk at least 41 cargo and passenger vessels, nearly all of them in the Cebu harbor. Navy officials said most sank in a narrow channel, among the busiest maritime centers in the country, and could pose danger to other vessels. The navy also reported that at least eight ships ran aground, including the research vessel Calypso, operated by Jacques Cousteau. The navy said the Calypso ran aground off Mindoro Island but there was no word on the crew. The French Embassy said Cousteau himself was not in the Philippines. The embassy said it was unaware of the report. Radio station DYHP reported from Cebu that 28 people were confirmed dead in the city and surrounding districts. Cebu Mayor Tomas Osmena, contacted by radio from Manila, said the city was without electricity, telephones and drinking water. He said he had not been able to make contact with officials in Manila. ``The general situation in the city is that it's almost impossible to quantify the damage,'' Osmena said in an interview. ``There is tremendous and widespread damage, particularly among the poor.'' Osmena said numerous telephone and electric poles had been blown down and strewn on the streets ``like matchsticks,'' blocking traffic. During the height of the storm Tuesday, a ship slammed into a bridge that links the city to Mactan island, causing major structural damage, he said. An international airport, which also suffered damage, and an fuel depot, are on the island. ``We are in need of basic infrastructure,'' Osmena said. ``We are highly susceptible to an epidemic because there is no water.'' Other residents reached by radio from Manila, 350 miles to the north, said hundreds of buildings were damaged. Cebu radio stations said about 90 percent of all houses built of wood were damaged or destroyed. The DYHP report said many banks and schools have closed and shops reopened late on Wednesday. Local rice prices also have gone up. In Negros Occidental province, Arsenio Yulo, Sugar Regulatory Administration chief, reported extensive damage to 1.9 million tons of sugar crops valued at about $696.4 million. The province produces most of the country's sugar for export and domestic use. Thousands of acres of rice and corn, among the staple crops in the central region, also had been damaged. The Philippine coast guard said 25 crew members were missing after the ship Dona Roberta sank near Cagayan de Oro, about 500 miles south of Manila. Two other cargo vessels were reported missing near the area. Three sailors also were missing after their navy craft sank in Cebu harbor. Seventeen workers, including six Americans, trapped on an oil rig off Palawan Island, were reported safe Wednesday. An additional 68 workers had been evacuated from the rig, operated by Alcorn Production-Philippines. The typhoon was the 14th and the strongest to hit the country this year.

DOC.HEAD: The Survey Says: Marriage Pays Off
DOC.TEXT: Single men looking for a raise or promotion should consider a serious option: Get married. Married men earn an average of 30.6 percent more than unmarried men, according to a University of Michigan survey released Tuesday. Husbands outearn bachelors in several other countries as well, said Robert Schoeni, a doctoral student at the school's Population Studies Center. ``The average earnings of married men were consistently higher than the earnings of their unmarried counterparts in all the countries we studied. The effect persisted even when education, age or experience, and race were taken into account,'' Schoeni said. He offered three possible explanations: -Employers are more likely to hire and promote married men because they consider them more stable and community oriented. -Women are more likely to marry financially successful men. -Married men feel responsible for a wife and family and become more productive. ``Our data doesn't clarify which is the correct explanation. I suspect, however, that all three explanations play a role,'' Schoeni said. Schoeni studied incomes in 12 countries, using data for 25- to 64-year-old males collected since 1983 by the Center for Population, Poverty and Policy Studies in Walferdange, Luxembourg. He said he found marriage had a particularly powerful effect on men's earnings in the United States, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland. In the United States, the effect was powerful at all ages: 28.8 percent at age 30; 30.3 percent at age 40 and 32.5 percent at age 50. In Italy and in pre-democracy Poland, the effect was weaker - 9.3 percent in Italy and only 3.1 percent in Poland. Schoeni said he didn't know why the gap was narrower in Italy. He said a planned economy like pre-democracy Poland's was not affected much by issues such as marriage. The gap in different countries: -Australia: 13.6 percent. -Canada: 14.4 percent. -France: 12.7 percent. -Germany: 12.4 percent. -Italy: 9.3 percent. -Netherlands: 11.9 percent. -Norway: 26.4 percent. -Poland: 3.1 percent. -Sweden: 26.1 percent. -Switzerland: 25.9 percent. -United Kingdom: 12.7 percent. -United States: 30.6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Teacher Gets 20 Years in Prison for Molesting Students
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Marks could...,' with five grafs to CORRECT that Marks could be paroled in about five years, sted four. ADDS comments from judge and prosecutor. Picks up 7th graf, `Marks' lawyer...'.
DOC.TEXT: A former teacher was sentenced today to 20 years in prison for molesting four school boys. He allegedly molested dozens of other students over 30 years. Douglas Marks, 63, was also fined $25,000 to pay for counseling of his victims and other youths involved in sex crimes.
