Marks pleaded guilty July 9 to four counts of felony sexual assault for molesting the four boys between 1985 and 1989. The fathers of two of those boys said they, too, had been victims of Marks. Court records cited 22 accusations of molestation dating to 1956, most too old to prosecute. County Attorney Rich Llewellyn said he had found 45 victims, and that Marks' deviant behavior extended back 50 years, first as a victim. District Judge Frank Davis of Dillon sentenced Marks to a 40-year term but suspended 20 years of the prison term. Davis also said if Marks is paroled, he can have no contact with anyone younger than 18 years old. Marks could be eligible for parole in about five years, Llewellyn said. During a presentence hearing last week, Davis refused to allow some of Marks' victims to testify. ``I decided I wasn't going to embarrass this poor man any more,'' he said. This morning, Davis told Marks: ``Last week I spared you a minitrial. I can't spare you any longer.'' Llewellyn said he was satisfied with the sentence, adding that Marks had shown little remorse. Marks' lawyer had asked that his client be sentenced to a treatment program and 238 days in jail, most served on weekends in the county jail at Boulder. Marks is a member of a prominent local family that owns substantial ranch property in the Helena-Boulder area and a sawmill in Clancy. A brother, Bob Marks, has been a state representative for 20 years and speaker of the Montana House in 1981 and 1987. Over more than three decades of teaching in this ranching region between Helena and Butte, Marks built a reputation as a selfless and devoted teacher. Marks was removed from a teaching job in Boulder in 1959 after three students accused him of molesting them. He found another teaching job the next year in Clancy, about 20 miles away, then was rehired at Boulder Elementary School in 1965. In 1984, a young man came forward against Marks. It was more than five years before Marks was finally charged and all four of the offenses to which Marks pleaded guilty occurred after the 1984 complaint.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Congressional Leaders Meet on Persian Gulf
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 9th graf pvs, bgng, Both Mitchell... to UPDATE with Michel comments and House to hold hearings; picks up 10th graf pvs, But on...
DOC.TEXT: Democratic leaders told President Bush today they believe the Constitution requires Bush to seek congressional authorization before using military force in the Persian Gulf. The White House left its options open. `The president did not indicate a commitment to do that or a refusal to do that,'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, at a news conference a few moments later, said Bush ``certainly will follow the Constitution.'' However, Baker said, ``it's a question - what the Constitution requires.'' Baker, who is a lawyer, said that the administration respects Congress' prerogative under the Constitution to declare war. But Baker said he would not ``play the game'' of getting into what the president might do since the use of force at this point was ``still hypothetical.'' Mitchell said he and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, at a two-hour meeting at the White House, ``expressed directly to the president our view that if he does make a decision to use military force, that under the circumstances, the requirements of the Constitution would have to be met.'' He said that ``would involve presentment of that decision to the Congress for authorization.'' House Republican Leader Bob Michel said Bush told the lawmakers that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein threatens to have a stranglehold on oil and free world economies and that hostages are in jeopardy. Michel quoted Bush as saying, ``If we don't take heed now, we'll pay dearly later.'' Both Mitchell and Foley said that they agreed with Bush that there should not be an emergency session of Congress to discuss Persian Gulf policy. But the Senate announced Tuesday it would hold hearings on the crisis and the House did the same today. But on Tuesday, two leading Republican senators endorsed the idea of a special session. ``With the election over, the budget behind us, the American people are starting to focus on this. We've lost some support. We need to regain it,'' said Dole, R-Kan. Meanwhile, Bush today notified Congress that he was extending for an additional 90 days the call-up for reservists already serving in the Persian Gulf region. Tours of duty run for 90 days, renewable for another 90 days by presidential order. Bush's action had been expected. The president said ``the effective support and conduct of operational missions in and around the Arabian Peninsula necessitates this action.'' Today's session comes less than a week after Bush announced 200,000 new U.S. troops will be sent to the gulf region to provide an ``offensive military option'' for use against Saddam Hussein's Iraqi forces. About 230,000 U.S. troops are currently in the gulf area. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee and a backer of the additional deployment, said the announced buildup triggered a ``mini-firestorm of concern'' in Congress. Following weekend sniping by several Democrats at the president's gulf policy, Dole and other Republicans asked Bush on Tuesday to convene an emergency session of Congress to vote on the administration's position. ``I think it ought to be put up to the Congress - put up or shut up,'' Dole said. ``And if they say no, well, then they say no. And then the president has to decide whether to go it alone.'' The White House publicly opposed a special session as unnecessary since the nation is not at war. But Dole said later Tuesday that Bush has not made up his mind and may decide after his foreign trip late this month. Bush is scheduled to spend next week in Europe for the expected signing of an arms control treaty, then visit U.S. troops in the gulf and go on to Mexico for two days. Mitchell gave little support to the GOP call for a special session, contending that such a step would be justified only if the president decides to go to war. But he said the Armed Services and Foreign Relations committees will hold hearings on the crisis in the next several weeks. Traditionally, when Congress adjourns for the year it can be called back into session only by the president. However, lawmakers this year gave their own leaders the authority to call them back after the Oct. 28 adjournment. In other gulf-related developments: -The Pentagon said it was raising the ceiling for naval reservists called to active duty from 6,300 to 10,000. -The Pentagon announced that Marines are preparing to conduct their first amphibious assault exercise in Saudi Arabia since being sent to the gulf. Spokesman Pete Williams would not say where or when the exercise will be held. -Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., and 21 other House Democrats announced plans to file suit next week in federal court to keep Bush from going on the offensive without congressional approval. -Baker, conferring with Canadian Foreign Minister Joe Clark in Bermuda, told reporters, according to a transcript provided by the State Department in Washington: ``The economic lifeline of the industrial world runs from the (Persian) Gulf and we cannot permit a dictator such as this to sit astride that economic lifeline. ... let me say that means jobs'' of the average American citizen.

DOC.HEAD: Secret Anti-Communist Network Exposed in Norway in 1978
DOC.TEXT: A secret network of trained resistance fighters was exposed in Norway in 1978 when a policeman tracking illegal moonshine stumbled on one of its arms caches. The network was set up in the late 1940s by people who saw Nazi troops sweep away their ill-prepared resistance in World War II and feared the Cold War could bring a Communist invasion. The Norwegian government confirmed the resistance network existed during the inquiry that followed the discovery of the weapons in 1978. At the same time, former CIA Director William Colby published his memoirs and referred to such groups. ``It was a little surprising that no one in the other NATO countries picked up on it, and raised questions about their own countries,'' Nil Gleditzch of the International Peace Research Institute in Oslo said Wednesday. Colby, who was stationed at the U.S. Embassy in Stockholm from 1951-1953, was quoted Wednesday by the Swedish news agency TT as saying he helped form an armed anti-Communist guerrilla force in ``a Scandinavian country.'' He would not name the country. Officials in other NATO countries recently confirmed their own anti-Communist cells, also established in the 1940 and 1950s, but the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has refused to say if it played a role. In Italy, a group known as Operation Gladio is being investigated for possible connections with right-wing terrorist killings in the early 1980s. Gleditzch said Norway's groups are not suspected of such wrongdoing. Hans Otto Meyer, an intelligence operative, was arrested in 1978 when an illegal still was found on his property. Police also discovered at least 60 weapons, many machine guns, and 12,000 rounds of ammunition. Meyer's claim that Norwegian intelligence provided some of the weapons, for use by a resistance cell, was eventually confirmed. Gleditzch said the reference in Colby's book stirred interest in Norwy. Rolf Hansen, Norway's defense minister at the time, told parliament the resistance groups were privately organized after the war. Later, they were placed under the supervision of the intelligence service, he said. The Norwegian underground network was not answerable to NATO or other countries, Hansen said, dismissing any connection to the CIA. But he would not discuss details, saying the organization's activities had to be kept secret. Government officials remain secretive. Asked to confirm that the groups are still active in Norway, Defense Ministry spokesman Erik Senstad responded: ``What Hansen said then still applies.'' Rear Admiral Jan Ingebrigtsen said the groups still existed in 1985, when he stepped down as head of the Norwegian Supreme Defense Command's intelligence service. ``There is nothing suspicious about it. But these are units that would stay behind in occupied territory and it is therefore necessary that they be kept top secret,'' he told the Norwegian news agency NTB. Christian Christensen, a former Norwegian intelligence officer, wrote many books about the groups, as recently as this autumn. He said private groups were formed in 1947, sometimes kept Communists under surveillance and became part of the intelligence service in 1948. Norway, a sparsely populated country, expects trained citizen soldiers to meet an invasion by arming themselves from thousands of arms dumps in rural areas and the mountains. ``The idea is to have so many (caches) that it would be impossible to knock out all of them,'' Senstad said. But Gleditzch said the so-called ``stay-behind'' groups are a last line of defense, with their own weapons. ``It's separate from the other arms dumps. There are most likely caches of weapons in closed-off rooms in people's basements,'' he said in an interview.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Approves Import Of Some Chilean Sandpears
DOC.TEXT: Sandpears from certain areas of Chile would be available to American consumers under an Agriculture Department proposal announced Wednesday. The pear variety would have to come from areas in Chile that have been certified by USDA as being free of Mediterranean fruit flies, highly destructive insect pests. James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said most of Chile is believed free of the Medfly, with only the northern provinces of Arica, Iquique and Parinacota considered as infested. If the proposal is approved, he said, consumers would gain a new, winter source of pears because the seasons in Chile are opposite those in the United States. Public comments can be submitted by Dec. 3 to: Chief, Regulatory Analysis and Development, PPDk, APHIS, USDA, Room 8656 Federal Building, 6505 Belcrest Road, Hyattsville, Md. 20782.

DOC.HEAD: Bernstein Remembered at Concert on His Magical Day
DOC.TEXT: On the stage where Leonard Bernstein made his sensational New York Philharmonic conducting debut 47 years ago, the orchestra remembered the maestro at a concert that included selections from his ``Mass'' and ``Chichester Psalms.'' Wednesday's midday concert at Carnegie Hall also came on the 90th birthday of the late composer-conductor's close friend, Aaron Copland. And it was the 36th anniversary of the first TV broadcast by Bernstein, who died Oct. 16. Speakers, introducing various selections and often quoting from Bernstein's writings, included Bernstein's three children, son-in-law and friends Lauren Bacall and Schuyler Chapin. Bernstein's daughter Jamie Thomas said her father had loved numerical coincidences ``and today there's a flock of them.'' The concert began with selections from Bernstein's ``Mass,'' which he composed for the opening of the Kennedy Center for Performing Arts in Washington, and ended with Psalm 133, in Hebrew, from Bernstein's ``Chichester Psalms.'' Conductors were Michael Tilson Thomas, Michael Barrett, Christoph Eschenbach and James Levine. The orchestra played the overture to Bernstein's ``Candide'' with a symbolically empty podium, which brought tears to some of the invited audience and a standing ovation. Cellist Mstislav Rostropovich played a Bach sarabande. Singers were the Westminster Choir, mezzo-sopranos Marilyn Horne and Christa Ludwig, soprano Clamma Dale, tenor Jerry Hadley and baritones Thomas Hampson and Chester Ludgin. First chair musicians from the Boston Symphony, Israel Philharmonic, London Symphony, Santa Cecilia Orchestra and Vienna Philharmonic flew here, at their orchestras' expense, to take part. Two pieces by Copland were played. The concert also included Schumann, Haydn and Mahler as well as excerpts from six Bernstein works. Bernstein was the New York Philharmonic's 25-year-old assistant conductor on Nov. 14, 1943, when he filled in at the last minute for an ailing Bruno Walter.

DOC.HEAD: Malcolm Muggeridge, British Media Celebrity, Dead at 87
DOC.TEXT: Malcolm Muggeridge, once Britain's best-known media celebrity, died Wednesday at a nursing home in southern England three months after suffering a stroke, his family said. He was 87. Muggeridge was an agnostic who became a Roman Catholic when he was nearly 80, and a youthful socialist who later mocked the trendy left. He had one unchanging fascination - death. ``I rejoice in it, I love it. ... If it weren't for death, life would be unbearable,'' Muggeridge said in a television appearance seven years ago, without a trace of morbidness. Muggeridge delivered the remark with the same puckish smile and twinkling eyes that enlivened his rigid views against contraception, abortion, divorce and pornography. Some commentators dubbed him ``St. Mugg,'' while others said he railed in old age against vices such as smoking, drinking and adultery that he had enjoyed as a younger man. But for one who spent a long life talking, writing, pronouncing, denouncing, laughing at himself and others and infuriating many in the process, he earned a rare reward: few ever accused him of being a bore or a hypocrite. Journalist, author, teacher, World War II spy for Britain's MI-6 counterintelligence service, editor and traveler, Muggeridge became famous through television in the 1950s and 60s. His caustic commentaries, waspish views on post-imperial Britain and a 1957 British Broadcasting Corp. ban for what was perceived as an attack on the royal family, made him familiar to millions. He continued writing and interviewing after he moved in the 1960s to the Sussex village of Robertsbridge, where he lived with his wife, Kitty, whom he married in 1927. He died in a Sussex nursing home Wednesday. They had three surviving children - one son died - and nine grandchildren. In middle life, Muggeridge, a heavy smoker and drinker - who once said ``I just liked getting drunk'' - gave up both vices because ``the old must choose between sainthood and suicide.'' Muggeridge, a self-confessed unfaithful husband, later changes his ways. ``Being unfaithful is the most despicable thing I have done in my life,'' he said. ``But I always owned up in the end and Kitty understands.'' Through a career that included spells as a foreign correspondent in Moscow and Washington, Muggeridge remained both fascinated and repelled by politicians. He espoused no political cause but loathed communism. That was due party to his experiences during a 1932-33 assignment in the Soviet Union as correspondent for Britain's liberal Guardian newspaper. Muggeridge's religious odyssey was tormented but conclusive. He described that journey in his 1969 book, ``Jesus Rediscovered,'' which he wrote after he decided to become a committed Christian and a nominal member of the Church of England. ``Christianity to me is like a hopeless love affair,'' he lamented in 1958. ``It is infinitely dear and infinitely unattainable.'' He described his conversion to Catholicism at age 80 as ``a homecoming, picking up the lost threads of life.'' He had found he couldn't take the Anglican church seriously. Thomas Malcolm Muggeridge was born into a lower middle-class family and reared in south London. His father, Henry, a clerk in a shirt-making firm, was a lifelong socialist and for two years a Labor Party member of Parliament. After attending state schools, Muggeridge went to Cambridge University and soon dropped his father's socialist views. He was mainly a free-lance journalist but also held high-powered staff jobs such as the deputy editorship of Britain's conservative Daily Telegraph, and editorship of the satirical magazine Punch. ``Life holds no more wretched occupation than trying to make the English laugh,'' was his verdict on Punch. The best thing about being a journalist, he once said, was the opportunity ``for contact with the eminent without being under the necessity to admire them or take them seriously.'' Winston Churchill was a ``disaster - he failed to notice the British Empire was over,'' and John F. Kennedy was ``a fraud.'' But Ronald Reagan was ``not such a fool as people say.'' He saw Western civilization as doomed, the inevitability of death as the most interesting aspect of life, and life itself as an adventure, mystery and - ``for anyone of any sensitivity'' - a disappointment. ``Human life, I have come to feel, in all its public or collective manifestations is only theater, and mostly cheap melodrama at that,'' he concluded. ``There is nothing serious under the sun except love; of fellow-mortals and of God.''

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Test Conducted After Protesters Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with protesters arrested, test conducted. Picks of 6th graf, `The four...'. SUBS grafs 11th graf, `The device...', and last graf to conform.
DOC.TEXT: Scientists tested a nuclear weapon today after security guards removed four protesters from the remote desert site. Department of Energy officials spotted the protesters near ground zero minutes before they planned to detonate the weapon. The test was delayed while the protesters were taken from the site, 105 miles northwest of Las Vegas. The test controllers are ``obviously glad that it went, and went without any prolonged delayes because of the infiltrators,'' said Energy Department spokesman Jim Boyer said after the 11:17 a.m. EST test. City Hall workers in downtown Las Vegas said the 10-story building shook slightly. Boyer, at a control point 30 miles from ground zero, said he felt a slight rolling motion. The protesters were arrested and taken to a base camp at Mercury, Nev. They were to be turned over to Nye County authorities. Earlier today, the environmental group Greenpeace said four people had reached ground zero this morning in an attempt to halt the test of the British nuclear weapon. The Energy Department initially disputed the claim. The test, scheduled for 9 a.m., was delayed several times in the final 30 minutes of the countdown because of technical difficulties, Boyer said. The four protesters were spotted by video cameras trained on the site as the countdown was about to resume with six minutes remaining. The four - three British woman and an American man - reached the area shortly after dawn, said Junior Bridge, a spokeswoman for Greenpeace. She said one had made contact with a security guard there. Energy Department spokesman Chris West had disputed the report, saying there was no one at ground zero except the scientists who arm the device. The nuclear device is buried 1,900 feet deep in a shaft filled with concrete. Ground zero is the ground level spot above where the underground explosion takes place. ``They could damn near be on top of it and it would just shake them up a lot,'' Boyer said of possible intruders. West has said that someone standing on ground zero could receive a jolt from the upward blast strong enough to break a leg. The device was expected to produce an explosive force of 20 kilotons to 150 kilotons of TNT. The atomic bomb that destroyed Hiroshima had the force of 13 kilotons. Bridge identified the British protesters as Juley Howard, 23, Jane Gregory, 27 and Lorna Richardson, 25, all of London. She said Michael Perry, 27, of the Rocky Mountain Peace Center, was also with the group. All British nuclear tests are conducted in Nevada. Britain has conducted 17 nuclear tests in Nevada since 1958. Bridge, who identified herself as nuclear weapons program coordinator for Greenpeace from Washington, D.C., said the women were taken Sunday by Jeep to a point 20 miles from ground zero. The test site covers 1,350 square miles of rugged desert terrain, an area larger than the state of Rhode Island. Anti-nuclear activists have hiked onto the site several times in recent years. In most cases, the intruders have been arrested by security forces who patrol by helicopter, airplane and all-terrain vehicles. The department once launched extensive searches when activists began penetrating in the id-1980s. They dropped the policy in 1986 as too costly. Department officials say an infiltrator reached ground zero only once: Two years ago a man appeared near a detonation site just minutes before a blast. The test was delayed an hour until the man was picked up by helicopter. Today's test was the eighth this year at the Nevada site and the 707th since testing began there in 1951. The last test was Oct. 12.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Report Critical of Osprey
DOC.TEXT: Congressional investigators said Wednesday the tilt-rotor V-22 Osprey, a plane legislators told the Pentagon to build over its objections, is too heavy and vibrated excessively in early tests. The General Accounting Office said it's ``impossible to know at this point'' whether the Osprey, which takes off like a helicopter but flies like a plane, will be ready for production in 1992 as scheduled. The agency expressed concern that the aircraft would be in production at the same time it was being tested. However, the manufacturers of the Osprey - Bell Helicopter Textron Inc. and Boeing Helicopter Co. - said ``the program is ready to move forward.'' The production and testing schedule don't pose a high risk, they said. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has said in his last two budget proposals that the Osprey should be canceled, arguing that a mix of conventional helicopters would be a cheaper alternative to the $23 million aircraft. Widespread support in Congress, especially in Texas and Pennsylvania where the aircraft is being built, saved the Osprey from the budget ax. President Bush earlier this month signed a military spending bill for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. That bill included $238 million in research money for the V-22 and $165 million in production funds. The provisions, added by Congress, also called for freeing $200 million for the program that had been included in the fiscal 1989 defense bill. Rep. Bill Dickinson of Alabama, ranking Republican on the House Armed Services Committee, released the Oct. 12 study by the GAO, the investigative arm of Congress. The Defense Department largely concurred with the GAO findings, and in a letter to Dickinson, Deputy Secretary of Defense Donald Atwood reiterated that the department doesn't consider the program affordable. The GAO found that early tests identified unacceptable vibration during flight. The contractor designed a vibration reduction package that has not yet been tested. As of Aug. 3, the agency said, the V-22 was expected to be about 2,822 pounds over the required weight. The contractor expects to eliminate about 1,600 pounds during production, leaving about 1,200 pounds of excess weight. And the GAO reported that, as of Aug. 8, about 86 deficiencies had been found during the first phase of government flight testing, including 33 that were deemed as adversely affecting airworthiness, crew effectiveness or safety, among other problems. Rep. Curt Weldon, R-Pa., a member of the House Armed Services Committee and a proponent of the aircraft that is built in his home state, said flight testing of the Osprey has proceeded without any major problems and should continue. ``While our Marines are training in the sands of Saudi Arabia, we on Capitol Hill are discussing whether or not to provide them with state-of-the-art equipment,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Delegation Defends China Visit
DOC.TEXT: Five U.S. lawmakers warned Chinese leaders on Wednesday that China could still lose its preferential trade status if its human rights record does not improve, delegation members said. ``We were trying to make the point with them that it was very important how they handle the human rights issue,'' Rep. Jim Lightfoot, R-Iowa, said at a news conference. He did not say how the Chinese officials responded. The five lawmakers made up the first congressional delegation to visit Beijing since June 1989, when Chinese troops opened fire on pro-democracy demonstrators, killing hundreds and possibly thousands of people. U.S. Sen. Warren Rudman of New Hampshire visited in Aug. 1989. They spoke on a day when China was savoring its role as host to three visiting heads of state or government - its busiest day of diplomatic activity in more than a year of semi-isolation. Indonesian President Suharto, Argentine President Carlos Menem and Thai Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan flew to Beijing after attending the enthronement of Japanese Emperor Akihito in Tokyo. Indonesia, Argentina and Thailand were not vocal critics of China's crackdown and did not take part in the Western boycott of high-level contacts with Beijing. Their visits thus were not a break with past policy. But they came at a time when Western countries as well are healing their breach with China. The European Community decided last month to end most of its sanctions against China, including its ban on high-level visits, and the United States has been gradually dismantling its sanctions. However, the U.S. congressional visit was not publicized until the official Chinese media reported on it, and the U.S. Embassy at first refused to provide information about the delegation. The congressmen said their mission was to stress to Chinese leaders that the key to improved bilateral relations was the resolution of human rights problems. In particular, they said China should resolve the fate of the several hundred people still imprisoned without trial for their participation in the democracy protests. ``The incident that occurred in June of last year has not been forgotten,'' said Rep. Michael G. Oxley, R-Ohio. ``Many of us wanted to express in person our outrage.'' The group also included Reps. E. Clay Shaw, a Republican from Florida, George W. Darden, a Democrat from Georgia, and Rep. John J. Rhodes III, an Arizona Republican. Bilateral trade dominated their talks with Premier Li Peng and other leaders, who initiated discussions about China's most-favored nation trade status, they said. The United States granted China the preferential treatment a decade ago, substantially lowering tariffs on Chinese products. President Bush renewed the status last May despite public pressure to punish Beijing. The House of Representatives has tried to reverse Bush's decision or to link the status with human rights improvements. Rhodes said that after their meetings Chinese leaders realized Congress will look for a ``final resolution'' of last year's crackdown when considering the future of bilateral trade. ``That means they make a final determination of the fate of those who are still in captivity,'' Rhodes said. ``We made that point over and over again.'' Authorities say 355 people remain jailed and under investigation in Beijing, but they refuse to say how many others have been sentenced or what the figures are nationwide. Some of the lawmakers said they thought Li indicated the cases of jailed dissidents would be resolved quickly, but others in the delegation disputed that interpretation. No one was able to quote the premier. The lawmakers also discussed the crisis in the Persian Gulf with Chinese leaders, but said they had no indication how China would vote on a U.N. resolution endorsing the use of force to compel Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Wildfires Erupt On Heels Of Record Heat, Continued Dry Conditions
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Stan Stephens called out the National Guard today to help firefighters battle a fire that threatened homes, hunters and ranches along the Missouri River. At least 30 homes were evacuated and a dozen hunters jumped into a creek to avoid getting burned as the 30,000-acre blaze raged uncontrolled though steep timber, small canyons and grassland near the river in western Montana. ``People that have been around fires for 30 years have told me this is the most unusal thing they have ever seen,'' said Dennis Casey, commissioner of state lands. ``There's so many hunters in there and it happened so quickly.'' No injuries were reported, but officials said they were concerned about hunters in the area, which is a popular hunting spot for deer, elk and bear. The fire began Tuesday night in two areas of the state-owned Beartooth Game Management Range north of Helena. Fire officials said record-high temperatures, extremely dry conditions for mid-November and high wind contributed to the fire's rapid spread. Bob LaSalle, one of about two dozen hunters who fled the fire, said a hunter in another camp told him the fire started from a spark from a cookstove. ``The cinders were falling on us,'' said Lynn Dumas of Big Sandy, another hunter. ``We had five minutes' warning. Just about enough time to saddle a horse. When we left we could feel the heat.'' About 40 guardsmen were sent to the fire lines with heavy trucks and other equipment to help 400 firefighters. About 200 miles to the northeast, another 200 firefighters were battling a 35,000-acre fire burning in grass and scattered timber on the Fort Belknap Indian Reservation. The fire started Sunday evening in a landfill in the reservation community of Lodgepole, officials said. The fire was thought to be contained Monday, but high winds whipped it out of control on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Found Guilty of Murder in Boyfriend's Poisoning
LaserPhoto covering
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) - A woman who prosecutors said spoon-fed her boyfriend home-cooked food laced with aroo travelers with an aggressive marketing campaign that includes heavily discounted seats for vacationers and first-class upgrades for anyone paying full coach fare. Eastern's traffic figures show more passengers are flying the airline, but it's still confronting enormous obstacles besides angry creditors and a debt exceeding $1 billion. Perhaps the most critical immediate problem is fuel expenses, which have nearly doubled since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2. Because Eastern is so weak financially, the impact of that unforeseen cost increase has hurt Eastern more severely than many of its rivals. As Eastern's fate was being determined in Lifland's court, travel agents expressed mixed views on the wisdom of purchasing its tickets. Some were advising customers that it might be better to make reservations with other carriers. ``We have warned them definitely that the bankruptcy judge could close them down,'' said William Cooper, president of Adventure Travels in Pompano Beach, Fla. ``The problem is that most of the people have bought their tickets for the Thanksgiving or Christmas holidays in advance.'' Cooper doubts Eastern's competitors would have any incentive to offer good deals to any travelers who might get stuck with worthless Eastern tickets. People who bought early tickets at cheaper fares might wind up shelling out more cash for expensive tickets bought close to their departure dates, he said. ``Some of the other carriers may say, `Hey, why are we going to give special promotional fares?''' Cooper said. At JB's World Travel in New York, owner Jack Bloch had a different view. ``The far-reaching thing of Eastern going under wouldn't affect most people,'' Bloch said. ``The fare loads on all the carriers are very light. The flights are wide open. I would think most of the carriers would allow people to fly standby.'' Several hours before Eastern and the creditors had their court date, Bloch said he would have no qualms about selling Eastern tickets.

DOC.HEAD: Germany Gives Up Claims to One-Third of Poland
LaserPhoto WAR50
DOC.TEXT: Germany and Poland signed a treaty Wednesday under which Germany permanently surrendered its claim to 40,000 square miles of territory lost in World War II - about one-third of present-day Poland. The pact, signed by Foreign Ministers Hans-Dietrich Genscher for Germany and Krzysztof Skubiszewski for Poland, ended one of the most intractable diplomatic disputes of the postwar era. Although the treaty has long been one of Poland's chief foreign policy goals, Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki avoided conveying any sense of triumph at the signing ceremony. He instead stressed sympathy for the ``tragedy'' of millions of Germans roughly expelled from their former homeland at the end of the war. By recognizing the border on the Oder and Neisse rivers, Germany gives up any claims to historically German lands in Pomerania, Silesia and East Prussia now populated mainly by Poles. The victorious Allies turned over the land to Poland in 1945 to make up for an even greater expanse of Polish territory taken in the east by the Soviet Union. As a price for international consent to reunification this year, Germany agreed to make the border permanent. ``The decision we have made ... is not an easy one for us Germans, for any of us - including myself,'' Genscher said after signing the treaty. ``And for those who have lost their home lands, who suffered expulsion, it is an especially painful one.'' The 2{-page treaty called for building ``a peaceful European order, in which borders will not divide.'' ``The Germans are not forwarding any territorial demands and will not forward any in the future,'' Genscher said. Because the frontier is now safe, Poles and Germans can put aside ``mistrust'' and ``meet on a new footing,'' he said. He repeated a promise to lift the visa requirement for visiting Poles by year's end. ``I am glad we have this stage behind us,'' said Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, the front-running candidate in this month's presidential election, who met with Genscher. ``Let's lift visas and other obstacles and there will be no problems.'' Mazowiecki took pains to address German concerns in what appeared to be the strongest apology ever made by a Polish statesman to those who lost their homes. ``The suffering of the German nation must be spoken about,'' he said. ``Every harm remains a harm, every tragedy remains a tragedy, irrespective of the harms and tragedies that we ourselves experienced.'' Johann Kroll, a leader of the Polish German minority present at the signing, said the treaty ``does not create too much joy for us.'' ``However, it is necessary,'' he said. ``The present borders ... we consider to be temporary because we count on the fact that ... borders will vanish in the common Europe.'' Kroll was referring to efforts by the European Community to achieve greater unity among European nations. Under a timetable agreed to by Kohl and Mazowiecki, the border treaty will be ratified by the end of February by parliaments of both countries. Meanwhile, a broader friendship treaty is to be prepared for ratification at the same time. The pact will contain assurances of minority rights for the up to 1 million ethnic German citizens of Poland. The Polish-German border was defined at Postdam in August 1945 by the Soviet Union, Britain and the United States. By that time, the Soviets had installed an obedient government in Poland and were occupying eastern Germany. After the Germans were deported, millions more Poles from the east moved into the new territory from homes that had fallen within the expanded borders of the Soviet Union. Names of towns were changed to Polish, and monuments and other signs of the area's German past were removed. By putting the border so deep in former German territory, Soviet leader Josef Stalin partly compensated the Poles for his own land seizures, punished Germany for the war and bound Poland to Moscow as the ultimate guarantor of its western frontier. Communist East Germany recognized the Oder-Neisse line in 1950 and West Germany disavowed any territorial claims in 1970. But conservatives and politically influential associations of expelled Germans pressed for decades to regain all or part of Germany's lost territories.

DOC.HEAD: Kremlin Frees Prices on Luxury Goods in Move Toward Free Market Economy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1 graf for 13th pvs, `The Russian...' to ADD that wine, tobacco, vodka will still be sold in Russia. Pick up 14th graf pvs, `It ordered...'
DOC.TEXT: The government said Wednesday it is lifting controls on the prices of luxury goods in an effort to encourage production. Only hours later, Russia's parliament declared the decree void in the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. The move by the Russian Federation set up the latest struggle in the war between the central Soviet and Russian governments. It demonstrated the fragmentation and confusion plaguing the Soviet Union as the base of power moves from the Kremlin to the republics. The battle began with a decree by the national Council of Ministers that prices would be freed on goods ``of no essential influence on people's living standards'' - such as jewelry, furniture and American cigarettes. It marked the first time in decades that the government has completely freed an entire range of retail prices to respond to the market forces of supply and demand. Floating prices is an important element in the government's outline for converting the Soviet Union from a centrally planned economy - in which the government sets all prices often regardless of the cost of production - to a free market economy. The council's decree applied to some of the items most in demand. Their prices have been fixed but in fact many of the goods are sold above the official price by corrupt store employees who sell them, truckers who deliver them and factory workers who make them. Shoppers have to wait as long as 10 years to receive furniture at the official price, but can get it immediately if they are willing to pay three times that rate. Other goods covered by the decree, which was released by the Tass news agency, are: natural furs, carpets, high-tech electronics, cut glassware, china, spare car parts and imports such as whiskey, gin and American cigarettes. Certain meat products and fish delicacies are also included. To prevent panic buying like that which preceded a round of price hikes planned for July 1 - and later canceled - the government announced the action just one day before it was to take effect, on Thursday. The government said freeing prices would ``provide extra incentives to increase the production of consumer goods and saturate the market.'' It also said the measure would undermine the black market for the items. The decree drew immediate criticism. ``I consider it pointless,'' radical legislator Gennady Filshin told the Russian Federation's parliament. An account of his remarks by the independent news agency Interfax did not report his reasons for opposing the move. The Russian Council of Ministers, in its retaliation, said the national decree has no force on Russian territory and forbade sale of the affected goods until further notice. It said wine, vodka and tobacco goods would continue to be sold at current, state-fixed prices. It ordered an inventory of the affected goods to be conducted for the purpose of preserving them, and said local government leaders would be held personally responsible for the results. Even a member of the national Council of Ministers, which adopted the decree, criticized it. Deputy Prime Minister Stepan Sitaryan said there would be many ``bruises.'' He predicted that prices of the goods affected would double, and that there would be a chain reaction that would drive up the prices of other goods. He said some businesses might intentionally decrease production to drive up prices artificially, so they can get a higher profit. Many of these problems, he said, could have been avoided if prices were freed simultaneously with a move to privatize businesses and end the state monopoly of the economy. As the old central planning system collapses, hidden inflation and hoarding have exacerbated many perennial shortages and created new ones. Soviets have been hoarding anything with lasting value, including many of the goods whose prices are being raised in the decree. Many people are particularly worried about the coming winter. A public opinion poll published in an edition of the weekly Moscow News, released Wednesday, said 62 percent of those questioned fear hunger in the next few months. Twenty-six percent had no fear and 12 percent did not know. The poll, conducted by the All-Union Center of Study of Public Opinion, did not give a margin of error. An accompanying open letter by a group of prominent politicians and economists said the government should head off difficulties this winter by opening strategic reserves saved in the event of war. ``The country is slipping into an abyss, a civil war,'' they warned. ``Unless a number of urgent, decisive measures are taken, a tragedy will be inevitable.''

DOC.HEAD: War Powers Act Requires Presidential Notification Of Hostilities
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The 1973 War Powers Act requires that the president consult with Congress formally when U.S. forces are introduced ``into hostilities or into situations where imminent involvement in hostilities is clearly indicated by the circumstances.'' Notification also is required when combat-equipped troops are sent to the territory of any foreign nation. The notification must include the president's explanation of why the move is necessary and the estimated scope and duration of the deployment. The law requires that the president terminate the military deployment within 60 days unless Congress has specifically authorized its continuation. The 60-day period can be extended to 90 days if the president certifies that such a move is ``an unavoidable military necessity.'' Administrations regard the act as an unconstitutional infringement by Congress on the president's powers as commander-in-chief of the armed forces. Rather than tackle the issue head-on, however, notification usually is given in a way that Congress regards as compliance with the law.

DOC.HEAD: Concern Rises Over US Role in Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 2nd graf to UPDATE with Berkeley arrests; picks up 2nd graf pvs: `While many ...; SUBS 11th graf pvs, `As in ...' with one graf to add details.
DOC.TEXT: From gatherings of Quakers here at the nation's biggest Air Force reserve base to demonstrations at California's venerable Presidio, signs of protest are growing along with the threat of war. Eighteen demonstrators were arrested Tuesday for investigation of trespassing and malicious mischief after a group of activists protesting the American military presence in the Middle East occupied the ROTC building at the University of California, Berkeley. While many Americans support the buildup in the Persian Gulf, others say they worry the country is repeating the mistakes of Vietnam. ``I don't think there's a clear recognition of the cost, the human cost of going to war,'' said Paul Wright, a former war protester and an editor at the University of Massachusetts press. He has a son stationed with the Marines in the gulf. Protesters have marched in Fargo, N.D., held peace vigils in New Haven, Conn., and poured oil and simulated blood over a mound of sand in front of San Francisco's Presidio, an Army base since 1846. Quakers and Buddhist monks have been gathering at the gates of Westover since August, their numbers growing from two or three to about 50 on Monday. ``I think as long as the president is beating the war drums and not wanting to have a full discussion of this in Congress, people are getting angrier and angrier,'' Frances Crow, a 71-year-old Quaker, said Tuesday. Much of the concern seems to focus on how Congress has not voted on the military action. ``I'm concerned that we're starting to make that leap of faith from supporting our troops to supporting this policy of the president,'' said Dean R. Kahler, who was paralyzed after being shot at the Kent State demonstration of 1970. Now a county commissioner in Athens, Ohio, Kahler echoed calls for Congress to reconvene. ``I think its important that Congress exercise its responsibility and not duck it,'' he said. ``I think they ducked it in the Vietnam era.'' Last week's decision to send up to 200,000 more troops to the gulf seemed to have raised concern that the United States is trying to assume anew the role of world policeman, said Marty Linsky, a lecturer in public policy at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. As in the Vietnam era, much of the protest is student-based, from the sporadic demonstrations at Berkeley to a peace vigil at Yale University on Sunday. Fifteen of those arrested in Berkeley were students. But unlike the 1960s, many of the demonstrators are veterans themselves, GIs who felt the ignominy of fighting in an unpopular war. ``I'm afraid they're going to go to war and going to kill a bunch of good young men for really nothing,'' said Leonard Lavender, a Korean War veteran who participated in Sunday's Veterans Day observance in Bozeman, Mont. ``Wait'll they start sending gung-ho women back in body bags,'' Lavender said. On the other side of the issue, several support groups are launching letter-writing and gift campaigns. A group in Minneapolis plans to collect 10,000 pounds of gifts to U.S. troops in the gulf. ``Some of them don't have any family,'' Roberta Nathe of New Hope said. ``We're going to be their adopted family.'' In Arizona, Operation Santa Claus will send gifts to soldiers deployed from Fort Huachuca, an Army base in Sierra Vista. There are about 230,000 U.S. troops in and around Saudi Arabia and an up to 200,000 more are expected. ``I wish they'd go ahead and do it and get it over with,'' said Rosa Lee, who owns a record and video store in Camden, S.C. Gen. William C. Westmoreland of Charleston, S.C., commander in Vietnam, said he believes the United States is not ready for battle. ``But we are moving into the position to be prepared,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Moslems And Sikhs Attack Hindu Neighborhood, Five Killed
DOC.TEXT: Moslems and Sikhs waving swords and firing revolvers attacked a Hindu neighborhood in the capital Wednesday, and police opened fire to halt the rampage. At least five people died. At least three of those killed were Hindus who died of stab wounds. Two people died from bullet wounds, the United News of India reported. Twenty-five people were reported injured, including eight policemen. Most of the injuries were stab wounds and gashes from swords, police said. Santosh K. Kain, a police commissioner, said three Hindu-owned shops and 10 vehicles were burned by the attackers. After the fighting, at least 20 men were detained by police. The trouble began when about 15,000 Sikhs and Moslems held a meeting in a mosque to express solidarity against the Hindu majority. Police said some of those who addressed the group made ``provocative speeches.'' A group of people, waving swords, daggers and revolvers, left the meeting and attacked a Hindu neighborhood about 500 yards away, Kain said. Some Hindus pelted the attackers with stones, residents said. The rioting in the capital's Sadar Bazaar neighborhood lasted about a half hour, they said. ``They came in a Matador (van) with naked swords and brandishing revolvers,'' said Vinod Kumar, a 22-year-old Hindu. ``They shouted provocative slogans....'' Kumar spoke to reporters in front of a burning two-story house, which he said belonged to a Hindu. Bricks and pieces of glass lay on the street amid pools of water. Hindu fundamentalism has been on the increase in India and peaked two weeks ago in the northern town of Ayodhya. The fundamentalists stormed a mosque in the town, claiming it was the birthplace of Lord Rama, a Hindu warrior-god. More than 380 people, mostly Moslems, have been killed across India in violence sparked by the Hindu campaign. Residents said about 35 percent of Sadar Bazaar's residents are Moslems and most of the rest are Hindus. A few Sikhs also live in the middle-class area. Hindus comprise 82 percent of India's 880 million people. Moslems make up 12 percent, while Sikhs are about 2 percent. Buddhists and Christians make up the rest.

DOC.HEAD: Smoking May Conceal the Pain of Emerging Heart Disease
With AM-Smoking-Offices, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Cigarettes increase smokers' pain tolerance and could therefore block the chest pains that serve as a warning for heart disease, researchers said Wednesday. In studies with 20 male smokers, ages 19 to 44, the researchers found that the tolerance to pain increased with each of three cigarettes smoked. The study, presented at the annual meeting of the Amerian Heart Association, was conducted by asking the smokers to keep away from cigarettes for 12 hours and then smoke three cigarettes at timed intervals. A hot probe was touched to their arms after each cigarette and warmed until it reached the threshhold temperature that produced pain, said Dr. Paula Miller of the University of North Carolina School of Medicine, the principal author of the study. A statistically significant rise in the temperatures the men could tolerate occurred after they smoked the cigarettes, she said. ``We have a lot of confidence in our findings because the responses were so consistent,'' said the senior author of the study, Dr. David Sheps, also of the University of North Carolina. ``Almost every man showed increases in threshhold and tolerance temperatures immediately after smoking a cigarette,'' he said. Smokers are known to have a higher prevalence of what is called ``silent ischemia,'' said Miller. Silent ischemia occurs when blood flow to the heart is briefly interrupted because of the buildup of fatty deposits and cholesterol in the arteries that nourish the heart. In many people, ischemia produces the chest pain known as angina, which is an indicator of heart disease. In silent ischemia, however, there is no pain to call attention to the underlying heart disease. Miller has been trying to understand why silent ischemia occurs, and she said that the pain-masking effects of smoking might explain why it is more common in smokers. In another study, she showed that the naturally occuring pain-relieving substances called endorphins also may help mask the pain associated with ischemia. People whose bodies naturally produce more endorphins may be more likely to suffer from silent ischemia, she said. The American Heart Association estimates that 2{ million Americans suffer from angina. As many as 3 million or 4 million Americans may suffer from silent ischemia, the heart association estimates.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pardons Turkey
DOC.TEXT: President Bush bestowed a presidential pardon Wednesday on a fat, white turkey, sending the gobbler to a children's petting farm instead of the Thanksgiving table. ``After everything that's been going on in Washington, it's great to share the stage with someone I can call a turkey and get away with it,'' Bush said as he acceted the 60-pound bird. ``I'm going to give you a presidential pardon,'' Bush said to the fowl from the farm of National Turkey Federation President Wyatt Upchurch of Raeford, N.C. The bird will live out its days at the Kidwell Farm in Herndon, Va. The turkey accepted the honor without a peep, sitting placidly on a little table in the Rose Garden while the president and several elementary school children stroked its feathery neck. Bush selected Macey Roberts, a third grader at New Hampshire Estates Elementary School in Montgomery County, Md., and fourth grader Ariel Lopez, of Key Elementary in Arlington, Va., to be the first ``turkey patters.'' ``Is he kind of calm?'' Bush asked as he stepped close to the bird. ``We had one a couple of years ago that started jumping around and scared all the kids.'' Last year, at the annual pre-Thanksgiving presidential turkey presentation, the bird gobbled so loudly that Bush had trouble being heard over it. One of the birds presented to former President Reagan flapped wildly during that year's Rose Garden ceremony. This year's turkey, however, went from crate to viewing stand to the ground for petting without a sound or flutter. Outside a White House gate were two animal rights protesters, one dressed as a turkey. ``We're here to speak for the 45 million turkeys who will die this Thanksgiving,'' said Robin Walker, of Hyattsville, Md. `` President Bush needs to recognize that turkeys have a right to life free of pain. He needs to recognized his vegetarian constituency.''

DOC.HEAD: Gov. Wilder Sees Someone Like Himself as Ideal '92 Nominee
DOC.TEXT: Virginia Gov. Doug Wilder lambasted President Bush's fiscal and civil rights policies Wednesday and all but declared himself the ideal Democratic nominee to take on Bush in 1992. Wilder, speaking at a luncheon sponsored by the conservative National Review magazine, depicted himself as far more fiscally conservative than Bush and said the Democrats must nominate such a person to regain the White House. The Virginia governor, the first black to be elected head of any state, also tied Bush to Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and said the two had reduced GOP conservatism to ``false symbolism and intimidation tactics.'' Wilder's associates have formed a political action committee the governor says is designed to aid fiscally responsible candidates. The PAC could be turned into a Wilder presidential committee if he declared his candidacy. Sounding themes that could easily become campaign slogans, Wilder said the Bush-Helms axis represents ``the new extremism'' as opposed to his own ``new mainstream.'' ``The new mainstream brings people together, while the new extremism pulls Americans apart,'' he said. ``The new extremism spouts mighty rhetoric about fiscal responsibility and balanced budgets, but then embraces a trillion dollar federal debt and sky-high taxes on Middle America and Forgotten America.'' Wilder said Bush demonstrated ``a willingness to mortgage the moral authority of the White House'' by vetoing the 1990 civil rights bill and aligning himself with Helms. ``He needed something to hold his 1988 coalition together and the senator needed something - anything - to hold on to his seat in Washington,'' Wilder said. This year's civil rights act was designed to restore broad job protections for women and minorities that had been eroded by several recent Supreme Court decisions. Bush said he vetoed the bill because it would have led to hiring quotas. Participants in a panel before Wilder spoke, notably former New York Mayor Ed Koch, said the bill surely would have led to quotas. They also said the GOP has a central and winning issue in the affirmative action question, at least until Democrats rethink their position. Proponents of the civil rights bill vehemently deny it would lead to quotas. Wilder accused Bush of falsely raising that specter and laying the groundwork for a devastating Helms ad against his black Democratic opponent, Harvey Gantt, in the closing days of the campaign. ``As one who has had some real experience with real racial quota laws, let me say that the Civil Rights Act of 1990 is not one of those laws,'' Wilder said. Turning to economic matters, Wilder charged the Reagan and Bush administrations with tripling the national debt, decimating the dollar and creating structural deficits that are still out of control. By contrast, he cited his own record of spending cuts and reordered priorities in Virginia. He then described his vision of a victorious 1992 Democratic presidential nominee: ``a candidate with proven fiscal management credentials; a candidate able and willing to make the tough choices at home and abroad.'' Asked his views on the Persian Gulf, Wilder said he had been encouraging Bush to better explain why the United States is in the Middle East, what it hopes to accomplish there and what further help it expects to get from allies. ``I support the president's positions. The question is, where are we going from here,'' he said, echoing a common Democratic view. Wilder sounded less like his party brethren and more like Helms when he was asked about the controversy involving the National Endowment for the Arts. ``There is no constitutionally protected right to obscenity,'' he said. ``Funding for the arts is one thing. Funding for obscenity is another.''

DOC.HEAD: Broadway Opening of `Shogun' Postponed After Leading Man Injured
DOC.TEXT: The Broadway opening of ``Shogun'' was postponed Wednesday until Nov. 20 after a piece of scenery fell on the musical's leading man during a performance and slightly injured him. Philip Casnoff suffered minor injuries Tuesday night, said Sam Rudy, a spokesman for the show. ``He's going to be all right,'' Rudy said. Rudy said the Wednesday matinee and evening performances were canceled, but preview performances will resume Thursday. The official opening, originally set for Nov. 15, was pushed back to Tuesday. The audience at the Marquis Theater screamed when the screen fell to the stage, grazing Casnoff on his head, Rudy said. No one else, on or off-stage, was injured. The performance was a benefit for Montefiore Medical Center in The Bronx. A doctor in the audience scrambled to the stage and examined Casnoff, Rudy added. ``The show was so exciting and the special effects so unbelievable that when I saw something coming from above, I thought it was part of the show,'' said Dr. Berish Strauch, who was sitting in the 10th row. ``It struck the leading man, Mr. Casnoff, and he dropped to the ground and just lay there,'' said Strauch, head of the department of plastic and reconstructive surgery at Montefiore Hospital and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. ``I realized quickly that he was hurt and that this was not part of the show, so I ran to the stage.'' The doctor said Casnoff probably was unconscious for about 15-20 seconds but when he examined him, the actor was able to move his arms and legs. Casnoff was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital where he was treated for bruises and then released. He suffered minor injuries to the face and neck. Casnoff was the lavish musical's second leading man. Peter Karrie, the original star, was fired during the musical's Washington tryout. In ``Shogun,'' Casnoff plays a 17th century English sailor shipwrecked in Japan. The musical is based on James Clavell's epic novel that became a successful television miniseries starring Richard Chamberlain. The book and lyrics for ``Shogun'' were written by John Driver and the music is by Paul Chihara.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey Supplies Increasing
DOC.TEXT: Consumers have plenty of turkeys for this Thanksgiving and more are on the way next year, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. An outlook report said stockpiles of frozen turkeys Sept. 30 were at near-record levels, up 8 percent from a year ago. And production in the October-December quarter is forecast to be up 5 percent. Further, the report said, 1991 turkey output is expected to rise 6 percent from this year, compared with a 1990 increase of 9 percent. Retail prices are averaging slightly higher than a year ago, said Larry Witucki of the department's Economic Research Service. ``It's hard to predict exactly, because we don't know what the retailers' special strategy will be in any particular year,'' he said. In the last quarter of 1989, retail prices of whole turkeys nationally averaged about 96 cents per pound, Witucki said. ``About all I can say is that it's another year of ample supplies in stores, at reasonable prices - but those may be a little higher,'' he said. Supermarkets in the Washington, D.C., area are offering specials on whole turkeys this week at prices ranging from 66 cents to 89 cents per pound. The 1990 turkey crop will total more than 281 million birds and produce an estimated 4.7 billion pounds of turkey meat, Witucki said. Not all of it will be sold as whole birds. Processors have developed many ways of selling turkeys, including turkey luncheon meats, turkey ham and turkey sausage. And there are the turkey parts such as breasts, drumsticks and thighs for those not wanting whole birds or certain kinds of meat. That has helped make turkey an item throughout the year, not just during the holiday season in the fall. About 35 percent of the turkey business still occurs in the last three months of the year, Witucki said. In 1960, almost 60 percent of the annual total came in the fourth quarter. Projections by USDA show per capita turkey consumption this year may average a record 18.3 pounds, retail weight, up from an average of 17.1 pounds per person in 1989. It could rise to 19.3 pounds in 1991. Total poultry consumption is projected by USDA at 90 pounds per person this year, rising to 94.7 in 1991. Broilers lead the pack with 69.6 pounds in 1990 and 73.3 pounds in 1991. Red meat consumption is estimated at 130.4 pounds per person in 1990, rising to 132 pounds next year. Beef is the leader at 67.8 pounds and will remain at about that level in 1991, according to the department. Pork, at 60.1 pounds, is projected at 61.7 in 1991. The USDA report said hams are in shorter supply this season, with Sept. 30 inventories down 22 percent from a year earlier. Wholesale ham prices rose to more than $1 per pound in late September ``but have not exhibited the typical strong seasonal upward pattern this fall,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: HUD Strike Force Report Examines Abuses in Housing Authorities
DOC.TEXT: Several New Jersey public housing commissions ignored housing authority executives who drew excessive salaries and wasted federal money, according to a report Wednesday by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. New Jersey was cited for the most egregious abuses in the report, which included 17 recommendations for the more than 3,100 public housing authorities nationwide, said Joseph G. Schiff, assistant secretary for public and Indian housing. ``I don't think there's anything of the depth in New Jersey elsewhere in the United States,'' said Schiff. The report also included reviews of housing authorities in Atchison, Kan.; Bremerton, Wash.; Montgomery, Ala.; San Bernardino, Calif.; Santa Fe, N.M.; Stamford, Conn.; York, Pa.; and Youngstown, Ohio. Schiff said Housing Secretary Jack Kemp on Wednesday sent letters to chairmen of all public housing boards asking them to give poor tenants a bigger role in housing management. He also wrote to mayors, city councils and governors who appoint housing officials outlining the type of experience housing board members should have. ``It is quite apparent that some executive directors and commissioners in New Jersey have treated their PHAs as private kingdoms, to the ultimate detriment of the residents and the American taxpayer,'' wrote Schiff, chairman of a special New Jersey strike force created by Housing Secretary Jack Kemp. ``You've got isolated instances that just blow me away, that I'm confident are not common practice,'' Schiff said. Kemp created the strike force on Jan. 22 after the discovery of more than $1.7 million misappropriated by the Passaic, N.J., Housing Authority, including multiple salaries paid to Paul A. Marguglio, the executive director. He and other executives subsequently pleaded guilty to criminal charges including conspiracy, perjury and tax evasion. The report found that many commissioners, believing HUD officials would advise them of problems within their authorities, merely rubber-stamped activities by their executive directors. The task force found problems ranging from contracts assigned without competitive bidding and salaries paid without records of hours worked to cost overruns and excessive travel. Among the wasteful practices chronicled were: - The Irvington, N.J., Housing Authority purchased a $26,290 automobile and paid a consultant $1,570 in connection with the purchase when the authority already had leased another car of the same model. The agency also had three pickup trucks available for staff use, although all of the authority's units are within walking distance of the administrative offices. - The North Bergen Housing Authority paid $12,600 for meals and drinks of board members and authority members before, during and after commission meetings from Aug. 22, 1988, to Jan. 18, 1990. The report recommends: - Tighter HUD guidelines on salaries and administrative costs. - A departmental policy to restrict the hiring of relatives. For example, reviewers found 22 related employees at the Housing Authority of North Bergen. - A review of methods for auditing the housing agencies. - Guidelines for legal services contracts. Losses from HUD abuses and mismanagement during the Reagan administration may cost taxpayers up to $2 billion. A court-appointed special prosecutor is now investigating former Secretary Samuel Pierce and other former HUD officials.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Adrift in State of Near-Chaos
DOC.TEXT: Arizonans aren't sure who their governor will be in January or even when they'll get a permanent head of a ship of state buffeted since 1985 by presidential ambitions, political beheadings and personal indecision. There may be more storms on the horizon. ``Rudderless?'' House minority leader Art Hamilton asked with a smile. ``We certainly have a rudder. It just seems at times that it's broken and that's why we're going around in circles.'' Hamilton is the only lawmaker still in the same leadership post he had in 1986. By January, the only other ongoing state-level political leader, Attorney General Bob Corbin, will be gone as well - to retirement. A political vacuum isn't the state's only problem. The state's business elite has crumbled, led by the collapse of financier-developer Charles Keating Jr.'s empire, savings and loan failures, and financial troubles besetting such major companies as convenience store giant Circle K and electricity producer Arizona Public Service Co. The sports establishment also is reeling as the National Football League and Fiesta Bowl try to deal with voter rejection of a paid state holiday honoring Martin Luther King Jr. The NFL is threatening to take away the 1993 Super Bowl, and the Fiesta Bowl spoke briefly of leaving as well. The state's lame-duck Legislature is trying to write rules this week and next for a gubernatorial runoff early next year between Republican Fife Symington and Democrat Terry Goddard. Democratic Gov. Rose Mofford, a caretaker elevated when Republican Gov. Evan Mecham was impeached in 1988 after a particularly stormy period, may stay on past the Jan. 7 end of her term. Or she may turn over the reins to fellow Democrat Dick Mahoney, elected last week to his first term as secretary of state, Arizona's equivalent of a lieutenant governor. Mofford first said she intended to run for a full term. But then, after Mecham had set off a storm by making a bid for re-election, she added to the turmoil by changing her mind. She has been criticized for her lack of decision and described as the ``stealth'' governor for her low profile and lack of programs. Symington beat Goddard 49.7 percent to 49.3 percent last week. But the write-in candidacy of a Mecham lieutenant deprived him of the absolute majority needed to avoid a runoff under a previously untested constitutional amendment inspired by Mecham's surprise election. Though voters approved the amendment, lawmakers did nothing to say how it should work. Even if the lame-duck lawmakers agree on a runoff for late January or February and overcome a court challenge filed by Symington supporters, there's more turbulence ahead when the new legislature convenes in early January and faces a $300 million deficit. After more than a decade in which Republicans controlled both legislative chambers, voters last week gave Democrats a 17-13 edge in the Senate while leaving Republicans in charge of the House, 33-27. ``We could be facing legislative paralysis at the start of the year without any executive leadership,'' said Dana Larsen, executive director of Arizona Common Cause. The state's political sea began getting choppy in 1985, when Gov. Bruce Babbitt, a Democrat, began running for president and pushed for a King holiday in a state where blacks are only 3 percent of the population. Frustrated by repeated lack of legislative action, Babbitt proclaimed a paid King holiday for executive-branch employees. Corbin issued a non-binding opinion that the proclamation was illegal, saying only the Legislature could establish paid state holidays. Mecham, a perennial political outsider who won a three-way race against two establishment favorites to succeed Babbitt, rescinded Babbitt's proclamation and was hit with a wave of entertainment and convention boycotts. The protests mounted when Mecham defended use of the word ``pickaninny'' and made remarks that offended other ethnic groups. Mecham later proclaimed an unpaid King holiday, which remains in effect but is scorned by supporters of the paid holiday. It came too late. By April 1988 he was impeached and ousted. Mecham supporters took their revenge at the polls that fall, ousting the Senate president, House speaker and several others who had voted for impeachment. Symington beat Mecham in a GOP primary comeback bid last September, but Mecham's chief lieutenant, running as a write-in in the general election, cost him the majority against Goddard.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Alitalia DC-9 Carrying At least 47 Crashes in Switzerland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD Swiss radio report that wreckage still burning hour after crash, eight bodies recovered. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: An Alitalia DC-9 with 40 passengers and seven crew members aboard crashed Wednesday night near Zurich's airport, the airline said. There was no official word on casualties but reports from the scene said at least 40 people were killed. Swiss Radio said eight bodies had been recovered from the scene, where wreckage was still burning an hour after the 8:20 p.m. (2:20 p.m. EST) crash. The jetliner, flight AZ404, was en route from Milan to Zurich, the state-run airline said in Rome.

DOC.HEAD: Census on Schedule Despite Complaints from Cities
DOC.TEXT: America's top census taker said Tuesday the 1990 count is on schedule despite a sweeping recanvass ordered after thousands of cities complained that some of their residents had been skipped. ``Census operations are substantially on schedule and we do not anticipate any delays,'' Census Director Barbara Everitt Bryant told a House panel. The final count will be delivered to President Bush by year's end as required by law and he will have the privilege of announcing the number that will be cited as America's population for much of the decade. Bryant declined to give any preview of the number, saying that was up to the president, and added that more information was needed to make a judgment on the accuracy of the census. ``It is too early to conclude anything about the coverage accuracy of the 1990 census,'' she said. She said a clearer picture would emerge in the months ahead as the numbers are refined and analyzed. The bureau is reviewing 5 million housing units in response to complaints from cities and 15 million as part of its own post-enumeration survey designed to check the accuracy of the census. The resulting recanvass will affect 20 percent of the nation's housing units. Bryant said the bureau is now wrapping up the final portions of this survey in Philadelphia; Lansing, Mich., and Buffalo, N.Y. Documented challenges to the preliminary count have been presented by 6,602, or 16.6 percent, of 39,189 local governments, Bryant said. She said 2,262 gave favorable responses to their surveys. Challenges, however, came from all of the 51 largest cities. Twenty-two of them challenged fewer than 100 blocks, 34 fewer than 500 blocks. But counts of more than 2,000 blocks were challenged by eight cities: Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Detroit, Honolulu, Los Angeles, New York and Philadelphia. In the census a decade ago, 6,500 governments presented such challenges but only 2,500 could provide documentation, she said. ``This time, 7,600 challenged and 6,600 provided documentation we could check,'' she said. ``This does not mean that the 1990 census has poorer coverage,'' she said. She said the governments were better prepared and motivated than in the past. ``We're taking everything they did very seriously,'' she told reporters after the hearing. But she said that in some cases cities were ``using just any kind of definition they could come up with.'' She said both the Census Bureau and some cities had made ``geocoding'' errors involving the location of housing units. In other cases, she said, mistakes were based on obsolete data. She said substantial inaccuracy rates were found in Chicago and part of New Jersey and there was evidence that information had been falsified. But she said the inaccuracies had little impact on the count. In one case, she said, New York officials claimed that 414 housing units had been omitted in Queens. But the tract was located within the Gateway National Seashore. ``All we could find were three lifeguard benches,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: NATO, Warsaw Pact to Sign Statement Ending Military Rivalry
With AM-Norway-Resistance, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The nations of NATO and the Warsaw Pact will officially declare an end to their military rivalry in a special statement drawn up for signing next week, sources said Wednesday. ``The two pacts are saying, `We're going to put the Cold War behind us, and we're looking at ways to improve our relations,''' said a Western diplomat, who demanded anonymity. ``We have a document that basically focuses on ending ... the kind of conflict inherent if not real between these countries,'' said a NATO official, who also spoke on condition of anonymity. Last-minute details were still being worked on in Vienna to polish the 2{-page non-aggression statement. But officials said it would be finished in time for signing on Monday in Paris by the leaders of the 16 nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the remaining six of the crumbling Warsaw Pact. The declaration, however, will be overshadowed by the completion of the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty, a historic agreement designed to slash tanks, artillery and other non-nuclear arms in Europe. The arms accord also was expected to be signed on Monday, shortly before the opening of a summit of the 34 nations of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, or CSCE. The gathering will bring together the leaders of the United States, Canada and 32 European nations - all but Albania. The less dramatic, but also important, non-aggression statement will end decades of hostility between the 41-year-old NATO and the Warsaw Pact, which was set up by Moscow in 1955. The document, according to sources, was expected to say that a ``new era of European relations is beginning'' and that the nations are ``no longer adversaries.'' They will promise to work to together to ``build new partnerships'' and ``extend the hand of friendship,'' according to the sources. And, they will pledge to refrain from the threat or use of force against each other. The statement will welcome new diplomatic contacts between the Western alliance and the East European countries. Since August, the Soviet Union and East European nations have tapped diplomats in Belgium to be their liaison with NATO. Mention also will be made of arms reductions in Europe and upcoming negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union to trim short-range nuclear weapons, also in Europe. The dozen European nations, which are attending the CSCE summit in Paris but are not part of either military alliance, will be invited to sign the agreement, officials said. At a July summit in London, President Bush and other leaders of the NATO nations proposed drawing up a non-aggression pact between the alliances. The Kremlin earlier in the year had raised the possibility of a joint Warsaw Pact-NATO declaration. Western officials were initially skeptical of Soviet motives, worrying that such a document would give life to the dying Eastern alliance. Some East European countries were said to be reluctant to do anything to preserve the pact. But Western diplomats also wanted to ease Soviet fears o becoming isolated militarily as its once-staunch allies in the East moved closer to the West. The resulting statement, according to the NATO official, reflects ``the mix of those two things: The express Soviet desire, which we knew had a hook in it, but at the same time a (Western) interest in trying to do something for the Soviets.'' ``So the formula we came up was the willingness to develop a document that would basically end the Cold War and would be signed by the countries of NATO and the Warsaw Pact - but as countries and not as members of the pact,'' he said. No promises were made of further NATO-Warsaw Pact contacts. ``It's a declaration of the end of the bloc-to-bloc approach,'' said the NATO source. Countries still in the Warsaw Pact are the Soviet Union, Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Romania and Bulgaria. East Germany dropped out when it merged with West Germany, which belongs to NATO. Hungary already has said it plans to pull out of the Warsaw Pact's military arm next year. Western officials say alliance support also is weak in Poland and Czechoslovakia. NATO members are: the United States, Canada, Britain, Belgium, Iceland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Germany, France, Denmark, Norway, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Greece and Turkey.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Medical Studies, Findings Reported Wednesday
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at some recent medical findings on both the research and practical fronts, as announced Wednesday:
DOC.HEAD: Heart-Hostility
DOC.TEXT: Hostile teen-agers are likely to grow up to be adults who have high cholesterol, according to a study that finds new links between anger and heart trouble. For years, many experts assumed that hard-driving, impatient people with classic Type A personalities were at high risk of heart attacks.
