But many have grown skeptical of this theory, and some now believe that the truly lethal personality trait is hostility and anger. ``People with high hostility at age 19 tend to have high cholesterol levels at 40,'' according to Dr. Redford B. Williams of Duke University. Redford's study was among several presented at the annual meeting of the American Heart Association to suggest that hostile people are more prone to heart trouble - both because of the effects of adrenaline and other hormones on their bodies and their tendency to have unhealthy living habits. ---
DOC.HEAD: Muscle Spasms
DOC.TEXT: Minute injections of a highly poisonous toxin have been found effective and safe in treating a variety of involuntary muscle spasms, a committee of experts announced at the National Institutes of Health. The toxin, obtained from a bacteria that causes botulism food poisoning, has been used successfully to treat spasms of the eyelids, throat, face and the vocal cords, the panel said. ``This is the most powerful toxin known,'' said Dr. Roger Duvoisin of the Robert Wood Medical School in New Brunswick, N.J. The complex protein, known formally as botulinum toxin, is produced by a bacteria in spoiled food and can lead to lethal food poisoning in large doses. Duvoisin said, however, that in very small injected doses the toxin has the ability to block signals from nerves to muscles. This action will halt involuntary muscle spasms. ---
DOC.HEAD: Hyperactivity
DOC.NOTE: For release at 6 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have discovered the first specific abnormality in the brains of people with hyperactivity, the most common psychiatric disorder of childhood, and believe it may an underlying cause of the condition. Their study found that parts of the brain essential for attention and controlling behavior do not work as hard as usual in hyperactive people. Experts described this as a potentially important insight into the sources of the mysterious ailment. People have long suspected that some physical irregularity is at the heart of the disorder, which affects between 2 percent and 4 percent of school-age children. However, Dr. Alan J. Zametkin, who directed the research, said, ``This is the first large study of hyperactivity that shows some sort of metabolic abnormality.''
DOC.HEAD: End embargoed material
Alcohol-Aspirin
DOC.TEXT: Taking a couple aspirins with a cocktail can get you drunker, doctors warned. Aspirin blocks the action of a stomach enzyme that breaks down alcohol before it reaches the bloodstream, researchers reported in the Journal of the American Medical Association. ``It's important that people be warned not to mix those two - not to take aspirin before they drink, or rather, not to drink after they take aspirin,'' Dr. Charles S. Lieber, director of the Alcohol Research Center at the Bronx Veterans Affairs Medical Center in New York, said in a telephone interview Tuesday. ---
DOC.HEAD: Smoking Heart
DOC.TEXT: Cigarettes increase smokers' pain tolerance and could therefore block the chest pains that serve as a warning for heart disease, researchers said. In studies with 20 male smokers, ages 19 to 44, the researchers found that the tolerance to pain increased with each of three cigarettes smoked. The study was presented at the annual meeting of the Amerian Heart Association by Dr. Paula Miller of the University of North Carolina School of Medicine, the principal author of the study. Smokers are known to have a higher prevalence of what is called ``silent ischemia,'' said Miller. Silent ischemia occurs when blood flow to the heart is briefly interrupted because of the buildup of fatty deposits and cholesterol in the arteries that nourish the heart. In many people, ischemia produces the chest pain known as angina, which is an indicator of heart disease. In silent ischemia, however, there is no pain to call attention to the underlying heart disease. ---
DOC.HEAD: Heart Shock
DOC.TEXT: Almost two-thirds of the 300,000 Americans who drop dead suddenly each year from cardiac arrest might be saved if automatic shocking machines were made as common as fire extinguishers, heart specialists say. Catastrophic disturbances in the heart's normal rhythm - what doctors call sudden death - account for about half of all heart disease fatalities. Shocking the heart with a machine called a defibrillator can restore normal beating. But the shock must be delivered within five minutes, or the victim will die or suffer brain damage. ``This is an immense problem,'' said Dr. Douglas P. Zipes of the University of Indiana. ``In terms of numbers, it far outstrips everything else, but it's a solvable problem.'' ---
DOC.HEAD: Snoring-Heart Attack
DOC.TEXT: About 2 million Americans unknowingly suffer from a breathing disorder called obstructive sleep apnea that doubles their risk of dying from a heart attack, researchers say. The disorder, in which people stop breathing for 30 to 60 seconds or longer during sleep, is most common in people who snore, said Dr. Bernard Burack, a cardiologist at the Montefiore Medical Center's Sleep-Wake Center in New York. ``That doesn't mean everyone who snores is going to drop dead,'' Burack said. But patients with the snoring-related disorder have a risk of heart-related death 2.1 times the national average, Burack reported at the annual scientific meeting of the American Heart Association. It occurs most often in men, but when it occurs in women it is even more lethal, Burack said. ---
DOC.HEAD: Smoking-Offices
DOC.TEXT: An anti-smoking group has blocked proposed national ventilation standards that it said would not have protected office workers against the toxic effects of second-hand cigarette smoke. A lawyer for the group charged in an appeal to the American National Standards Institute that the proposed standards reflected the aims of the tobacco industry, which had sought to soften the ventilation requirements in buildings where smoking is allowed. ``The tobacco industry almost succeeded in pulling off a tremendous coup,'' Richard Daynard, chairman of the Tobacco Products Liability Project in Boston, said. ``They were using the standards to cast doubt on the evidence that environmental tobacco smoke causes disease.'' In a letter that it has been sending to employers, the Tobacco Institute has said ``Where ventilation is adequate and ventilation systems are properly maintained, tobacco smoke is not a problem.'' It based that conclusion on the proposed ventilation standards. A copy of the letter was obtained by The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Urges Eastern Europeans to Have Faith in Face of Problems
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Wednesday urged the faithful in Eastern Europe to maintain hope in the face of ``multiple difficulties'' during the transition from dictatorship to democracy. Speaking at his weekly general audience, the pontiff pointed to the sweeping political changes that have occurred the past year in his native Poland, Hungary, Germany, Czechoslovakia, Romania, Bulgaria, the Soviet Union and parts of Yugoslavia. ``Let us remember the last months of last year as the beginning of a great transformation,'' he said. ``The life of society and political structures were tranformed. Nations are freeing themselves from totalitarian chains to create new forms of community life according to the rights of persons and human society.'' ``At the same time, everywhere we are witnesses of multiple difficulties,'' he continued. ``How difficult it is to make the truth of solidarity prevail in daily life. How difficult it is to rebuild, in new conditions, the dimensions of the realcommon good.'' John Paul said he was praying that ``courage does not desert us in difficulty, that we don't lose faith.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says United States Seeks to Control Oil
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz on Wednesday accused the United States of seeking to dominate the world oil market. The official Iraqi News Agency quoted Aziz as saying, `The main U.S. objective in the region is to control oil wells and dictate oil policies.'' He was responding to comments by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III a day earlier in Bermuda. In those remarks, Baker said U.S. officials are concerned that the Persian Gulf crisis will increase unemployment in the United States. He said Washington cannot permit Iraq to strangle ``the economic lifeline from the gulf.'' Baker's suggestion that Iraq might cut off oil supplies if it kept control of Kuwait ``deliberately obscured'' the oil policies that Baghdad has pursued the past 20 years, the foreign minister said. ``These policies have ... tried to prevent market fluctuations, whereas the regimes that have received U.S. troops were the parties that tampered with the oil market to serve the ruler's whims and their evil ambitions.'' It was not clear who he was referring to. Saudi Arabia, where most of the U.S. forces are stationed, has sought to prevent market fluctations. Saudi Arabia controls about one-fourth of the world's oil reserves, and Iraq, under control of Kuwait, accounts for about 20 percent of the world's oil reserves. Before invading Kuwait on Aug. 2, Iraq accused it and the United Arab Emirates of trying to wreck Iraq's economy by pumping excessive amounts of oil and bringing the price down.

DOC.HEAD: New Law Requires States To Suspend Driver's Licenses Of Drug Offenders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5 pvs, `It calls ... such suspensions,' with 3 grafs to note criticism of the measure, name the states that now require license suspensions; SUBS last two grafs pvs with 5 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from National Governors' Assn, other critics. Minor editing thruout to trim
DOC.TEXT: States must suspend the driver's licenses of all convicted drug offenders or risk losing part of their federal highway funds under newly approved legislation signed by President Bush. The measure applies to all states and all illegal drugs, including the 10 states where possession of small amounts of marijuana has been decriminalized but is still considered an infraction of the law. The legislation, included in the transportation appropriations bill for the current fiscal year, got little attention during the flurry of activity as Congress rushed to leave town at the end of October. News that the measure had become law drew criticism from groups as diverse as the National Governors Association and the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws. The legislation calls for withholding 5 percent of federal highway funds starting Oct. 1, 1993 from states that fail to impose six-month suspensions on drivers convicted of a drug offense. The cut would increase to 10 percent on Oct. 1, 1995. About half the states now allow suspension of drug offenders' licenses, but only New Jersey, Colorado, Georgia and Pennsylvania have mandated such suspensions for drivers of all ages, according to Liz Gibson of the American Legislative Exchange Council. Passed Oct. 27 and signed by Bush on Nov. 5, the measure accomplishes in large part what national drug control policy director William J. Bennett tried to impose more than a year ago. But White House chief of staff John Sununu, a former governor of New Hampshire, blocked that effort, arguing that states should be allowed to decide such matters for themselves, administration sources say. The new legislation notes that states can reject the rules and still obtain federal funding if their legislatures vote specifically against requiring the license suspensions and their governors go on record in agreement with that position. ``This forces the states to be accountable,'' said an administration source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We're not going to force you, but if you don't want to do it, you'll have to be public about it.'' Rep. Gerald B.H. Solomon, R-N.Y., who pushed the amendment, said his main targets were New York and California, which have both decriminalized marijuana. Both also have splits in party control: In California, the Democrats control the legislature, the governor is a Republican; in New York, the governor is a Democrat and his party controls the state assembly while Republicans control the state senate. ``Seventy-five percent of the drug purchases in America are done by casual drug users, and that's white, upper-middle class Americans that drive their Pontiac Firebirds into the ghetto and buy these killer drugs,'' Solomon said. ``You don't see the murders take place out in the suburbs, but it's the casual drug user who supplies the demand for these drugs,'' he said. ``If you do away with the demand for drugs, then the drugs will dry up in this country. ... When it starts to affect their livelihoods, maybe then they'll stop using these drugs.'' But license suspensions wouldn't necessarily affect their livelihoods, because they would receive limited driving permits enabling them to continue commuting to work, he said. In the current fiscal year, the Federal Highway Administration will distribute some $12.3 billion to the states. Of that total, California will get the largest chunk, some $1.1 billion. New York is to get $666 million. Nolan Jones, staff director for the National Governors' Association's justice and public safety committee, said his group fought the measure last summer and still opposes it. ``Numerous states have driver's license revocation laws, but they don't go as far as this calls for,'' Jones said. ``That points to why we are against the whole issue of mandates when looking at this sort of problem.'' Criticism also came from Lester Lamm, president of the Highway Users Federation for Safety and Mobility, which includes everything from road builders to insurance companies and automobile clubs. ``In many cass, they're holding a program hostage for something that the program managers have no say over,'' Lamm said. ``The state departments of transportation don't have any role in the criminalization of drug possession.'' NORML, which has urged the legalization of marijuana for two decades, also denounced the new legislation, saying, ``It seems ludicrous that we would take our concerns with drugs and somehow transform them to a completely different area, i.e. transportation and money for roads.''

DOC.HEAD: Officials Announce First Soviet-Japanese Space Flight
DOC.TEXT: A television journalist will become the first Japanese citizen in space when he joins Soviet cosmonauts on a mission Dec. 2, officials said. Toyekiro Akiyama of Japan's TBS television network appeared at a news conference Monday with Soviet cosmonauts Victor Afanasyev and Mussa Manapov at the Soviet space complex at Star City, the government newspaper Izvestia said Tuesday. The December flight, details of which have not been announced, will be the first for a Japanese citizen. Akiyama also will be the first journalist to take part in a Soviet space flight. The newspaper did not say why Akiyama was chosen over several Soviet candidates. Other foreigners, including those from France, Afghanistan and Cuba, have flown on Soviet space flights. The Soviet Union has been trying to boost the image and profitability of its space program following budget problems and a series of mishaps. A hatch on the Soviet space station Mir failed during a flight this year, and a rocket exploded on the launch pad last month, destroying what a U.S. expert said was probably a spy satellite. Soviet officials also named a backup crew for the Dec. 2 flight, including another Japanese journalist, Ryoko Kikuti. The Japanese journalists are training for the flight at Star City and will visit to the Moscow area this month for a brief rest before the liftoff, the newspaper reported. Asked at the news conference what part of the training they found most difficult, both Japanese journalists said it was learning Russian, Izvestia said. ``But they are confident that, with time, they will speak well,'' the newspaper reported.

DOC.HEAD: Body of Black Man Found at Toussaint Gravesite
DOC.TEXT: Scientists searching for the remains of sainthood candidate Pierre Toussaint say they have found the body of a black male, but are not sure it is Toussaint. ``This is the furthest we've gotten,'' Joseph Zwilling, spokesman for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, said Wednesday. He said three other bodies discovered in the old graveyard in lower Manhattan where Toussaint was buried were either white or female or both. Toussaint, who was born a slave in Haiti and came to New York with his French owners, could become the first black American saint if his candidacy is approved by the Vatican. He died a free man in 1853 after what church officials say was a life of exemplary charity and virtue. Zwilling said archaeologists and forensic anthropologists searching for Toussaint's remains would have to exhume the body and study the skull, teeth and other parts before deciding if it belonged to Toussaint. In 1989 the church began investigating and examining Toussaint's life, the first formal step if he is to be canonized. The process can take years. Identifying Toussaint's remains is part of that process. If he is made a saint, his bones may be distributed to churches and places where he once lived.

DOC.HEAD: The Wild East: Riots Latest Symbol of Growing Lawlessness
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with later figures, marchers thwarted. Picks up 5th graf, `Wednesday's confrontation...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BER2, FRA4, LaserColor BER102
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of riot troops stormed a barricaded neighborhood with bulldozers and armored trucks Wednesday and smashed a defiant community of anarchists in the heart of Berlin. Commuters watched as officers burst through the makeshift barriers after daybreak and battled for hours before driving hundreds of radicals from a row of tenements in the former East Berlin. At least 325 people were arrested and 70 officers and protesters were injured, including one squatter shot in the foot when a police officer's warning shot ricocheted, police said. One officer and 15 squatters had to be hospitalized, they said. About 50,000 people marched through eastern Berlin late Wednesday to denounce the police raid and to demand affordable housing. Many residents of eastern Berlin now get rent subsidies, a practice that will soon end. The protesters tried to march to the street where the squatters lived, but a huge police presence turned them back. No serious violence resulted, although protesters tore down or burned campaign posters that major political parties have put up for the Dec. 2 national elections. Wednesday's confrontation was the third in three days on Mainzer Street and the latest example of lawlessness in the former East Germany, once strictly controlled by Communist rulers. As many as 3,000 police, many of them paramilitary units brought in from other German states, moved in to seize the heavily fortified Mainzer Street and adjoining streets where leftist radicals had taken up positions. Armored personnel carriers and bulldozers burst through several barricades and officers used clubs, water cannons and tear gas in pitched battles with the radicals. Radicals fired flare guns and threw rocks and firebombs from rooftops and windows. The battle spilled onto several other streets and an adjoining six-lane thoroughfare was closed to traffic. ``And now, our street is kaput,'' said Waetroud Goets, 59, after the fighting spread to the block where she lived for 30 years. ``I never had any trouble with these people, but as soon as the police showed up they started throwing rocks.'' After the fighting, Mainzer Street was filled with smoldering debris - spent tear-gas canisters, junked cars and furniture that had been hurled from windows. Much of the street was torn up by the radicals, who used its cobblestones as weapons. Berlin Interior Minister Erich Paetzold said the clash was marked by ``unbelievable brutality'' from the radicals. Baerbel Bohley, an activist who helped lead the peaceful revolt that toppled communism last year, denounced the police raid as an unnecessary use of force. She said a peaceful solution could have been reached. Most of the radicals involved in the fighting are anarchists from the former West Berlin. Hundreds of radicals have taken over abandoned row houses in eastern Berlin and have built encampments on vacant land where the Berlin Wall once stood. The largest such community was on Mainzer Street, where 12 tenements were occupied and radicals set up special houses and cafes for women and homosexuals. Signs and slogans, such as ``Eat the Rich,'' and ``Learn to Burn,'' covered the tenements decorated with the red-and-black flags of the anarchist movement. Authorities evicted radical leftists from three houses in other parts of the city early Monday. Radicals on Mainzer Street began building barricades, and hurled rocks when police showed up Monday afternoon. That clash lasted until Tuesday morning, and at least 137 officers were hurt and 20 people were arrested. Experts say eastern Germany's freedom from authoritarian rule and its dire economic problems - including a high unemployment rate and a lack of affordable housing - have created a breeding ground for unrest. The crime has included rampages by hooligans after soccer games, attacks on foreigners and homosexuals by neo-Nazis and increases in prostitution, drugs and gambling.

DOC.HEAD: Former Duke University Student Convicted Of Impersonating Baron
DOC.TEXT: A former Duke University student was convicted Wednesday of defrauding two banks while masquerading as a wealthy French baron. A jury convicted Maur Rothschild of four federal fraud charges involving lines of credit and credit-card applications in 1987 and 1989. Prosecutors called him a veteran impostor. ``Mr. Rothschild knew exactly what he was doing and why he was doing it,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney John Stone said during his closing statement earlier in the day. ``Mr. Rothschild was nothing more than a con man.'' Rothschild, 38, faces up to eight years in prison and a $1 million fine. His sentencing is scheduled for Jan. 30. Rothschild showed little emotion when the verdict was read. He would not comment when he was led from the courtroom. The government has refused to say how much money Rothschild defrauded from Duke Federal Credit Union and Wachovia Bank & Trust Co. in September and December 1987 and April 1989, but it was believed to be thousands of dollars. Born in El Paso, Texas, as Mauro Cortez Jr., Rothschild signed two applications for lines of credit as Baron Maurice de Rothschild. On one he listed his mother as ``Baroness Maurie de Rothschild.'' In federal court documents, his name is listed as Maur Jeffrey Loche Rothschild. Rothschild said he meant to change his first name to Maurice but that a clerk made an error, changing it instead to Maur. He said he had been abused as a child and had undergone extensive therapy and ``basically it got to a point where I lived out my fantasies.'' He once tried to kill himself, Rothschild said. After the name change, he said he began to believe that he was a member of the French Rothschild family while he was a continuing education student at Duke in 1987. ``We're all disappointed with the verdict,'' said his lawyer, Matthew Martin. ``It's obvious Maurice signed these forms. Of course, the question is, `What was behind the signature?' Maurice is not the run-of-the-mill, ordinary person. He lives his life in a different way.'' Rothschild testified that the two banks pressured him into taking loans and never verified who he was. Martin said no one would deny Rothschild had problems. But he said: ``Don't you know the folks at these institutions began to salivate when they heard a member of the internationally known family of Rothschild had come to Durham. The banks were involved in his fantasy as well. Martin said the banks used a double-standard with Rothschild, taking his word on information because they didn't want to press a wealthy customer about detail. Stone said Rothschild was a ``veteran impostor'' who finally got caught at his game. Rothschild also faces state charges of fraudulently obtaining $1,200 from a private cancer fund in Durham between May and June last year.

DOC.HEAD: Toxin Found Safe, Effective in Treating Muscle Spasms
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf and 7th graf: ``Known formally,'' to fix grammar - ``bacteria'' is plural
DOC.TEXT: Botulinum toxin, best-known as a cause of lethal food poisoning, has been found to be safe and effective in small injections for a variety of muscle spasms, a National Institutes of Health committee announced Wednesday. The toxin, obtained from bacteria that cause botulism food poisoning, has been used successfully to treat involuntary clinching of muscles in the eyelids, throat, face and the vocal cords, the panel said. It also shows promise in the treatment of stuttering, misalignment of the eyes and for cramps experienced by musicians, writers and typists. Dr. Roger Duvoisin, chairman of the NIH panel and on the faculty of the Robert Wood Medical School in New Brunswick, N.J., said the toxin is an example of a highly lethal poison that can be beneficial used in small doses. ``This is the most powerful toxin known,'' said Duvoisin. And, yet, he noted ``it has given relief where little was available before.'' He said there are hundreds of thousands of Americans who suffer from some form of muscle spasm that can be treated by the toxin. Known formally as botulinum toxin, the substance is a complex protein produced by bacteria that in contaminated food can lead to lethal poisoning. But very small doses injected directly into specific muscles, Duvoisin said, have the ability to block signals from nerves to muscles. This action will halt involuntary muscle spasms. ``Muscle spasms can be quiet disabling maladies,'' said Duvoisin. Spasms can distort facial expressions, or cause eyelids to close tightly so that victims have to pry them open by hand, or cause the voice to jam when the vocal cords are involved. Unbalanced muscles can cause eyes to be crossed or pointed fixedly to the side. Duvoisin said that a form of muscle spasm cut short the piano career of Robert Schuman and led to a cramping disorder now described as the Schuman hand. Writers and typist have similar problems. The NIH panel, which evaluated the use of the toxin, said all of these conditions may be helped by small injections of the poison. Mrs. Robert Bruce, the president of the Benign Essential Blepharospasm Research Foundation and a member of the panel, said that the toxin shots were able to restore her to a full life. Her problem started, she said, when muscles controlling both eyelids suddenly contracted and refused to open. Mrs. Bruce said she was unable to see unless she pried her eyelids open by hand. When the lids were released, they jammed closed once more. ``I couldn't work, I couldn't drive, I couldn't cook,'' said Mrs. Bruce. ``I couldn't even go shopping. Someone had to lead me around by the hand.'' She tried a number of treatments - including hypnotism, biofeedback and 12 types of medications - but nothing worked. Then a doctor injected specific muscles in her face with small doses of the botulinum toxin. The effect was to loosen and weaken the malfunctioning muscles and Mrs. Bruce said it enables her to control her eyelids normally. Duvoisin said the toxin injections work for only a few months and then the effect wears off. He said there is no apparent limit on the number new injection rounds that can be used without side effects. The therapy takes a high degree of expertise and only a limited number of experts are skilled in its use, he said. More are being trained now. A round of treatment with the toxin can cost from $400 to $1,800, Duvoisin said.

DOC.HEAD: Interest in Economic News Jumps Sharply
DOC.TEXT: The Persian gulf crisis was the news story most closely followed by the American public last month, although interest in economic conditions jumped markedly, according to a poll released Wednesday. Nearly two-thirds of a nationwide sample of adults questioned in a Times-Mirror poll said they were very closely following the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait and the presence of U.S. military forces in Saudi Arabia. It was the fourth consecutive month the gulf situation has been the top story. Interest in the plight of U.S. hostages in Iraq and Kuwait was also high, with 49 percent saying they were following the story closely. Interest in the economy rose to its highest point for the year, 39 percent. That was 10 points higher than in September and only one point below the level of public interest the Times-Mirror poll found in the October 1987 stock market crash. And 38 percent of those polled said they followed news about elections and campaigns in their states - about on a par with this year's turnout level, estimated at 36 percent. A month earlier, only 18 percent reported paying close attention to election news. The budget negotiations on Capitol Hill intensified and concluded in October, but the level of public interest stayed the same as October - 34 percent. Only 46 percent of those questioned knew that Congress hmminent. An armed conflict would threaten world oil supplies and drive up prices. Crude oil prices gained $1.25 Tuesday on strong war words by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. But market fundamentals such as supplies and other technical factors played a larger role Wednesday. ``As weeks go by and people are more comfortable with the situation - to the extent that they feel war is not immediately around the corner - those become more important in decision making,'' Gohler said. ``From a fundamental point of view, the market is certainly relatively weak if you look at the numbers,'' he said. On Wednesday, President Bush clashed with leaders of Congress trying to limit his war-making powers but assured lawmakers he has not decided to use military force to push Iraqi troops out of occupied Kuwait. Gohler said API statistics showing home heating oil supplies 13 million barrels higher than a year earlier pushed down prices in that market. December-delivery contracts for wholesale home heating oil traded on the Merc fell 1.63 cents a gallon to 86.64 cents after rising 1.75 cents Tuesday. Later-month contracts also fell. Unleaded gasoline tumbled 2.72 cents a gallon to 80.39 cents, with later months also lower. Natural gas rose .17 cent per 1,000 cubic feet at $2.428 after rising .1 cent Tuesday. Later-month contracts were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Three British Detectives Face Charges in IRA Bombing Case
DOC.TEXT: Three detectives who investigated two IRA bombings in 1974 will be charged with falsifying evidence to alter justice, the Crown Prosecution Service said Wednesday. Four people convicted in the case spent 15 years in prison before an appeals court freed them last year. The court threw out the convictions after prosecutors admitted police tampered with some evidence. The officers were from the Surrey police force in southern England. The prosecutions follow a nine-month inquiry ordered by Home Secretary David Waddington. The Director of Public Prosecutions decided that former Detective Chief Inspector Thomas Style, former Detective Sgt. John Donaldson and Detective Constable Vernon Attwell will be prosecuted following the investigation into the Guildford and Woolwich pub bombings in 1974, the announcement said. It said the prosecution service found no evidence to justify charges against others, though two other Surrey officers face departmental disciplinary proceedings. Patrick Armstrong, Paul Hill and Gerard Conlon, all of Belfast, Northern Ireland, and Carole Richardson, an English woman, were convicted of murdering five people in Guildford Oc. 5, 1974. The prosecution case was based solely on confessions that the four repudiated in court. The convictions were upheld even after four members of an Irish Republican Army gang confessed to carrying out the Guildford bombing. Armstrong and Hill also were convicted of a pub bombing in the London suburb of Woolwich on Nov. 6, 1974 in which two people died and 26 people were injured - and which the IRA gang also claimed. Chief Constable Brian Hayes said he took comfort that only three officers from his force were being charged. He expressed relief ``that no evidence has emerged of any systematic conspiracy, corruption or wrongdoing in respect of the Guildford pub bombings case.'' Summonses were expected to be served on the three within the next week.

DOC.HEAD: Celebrities Gather to Urge Public to Butt Out for Smokeout
With AM-Smoking-Offices, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Rapper L.L. Cool J crooned against cigarettes Wednesday with actress Carol Channing and other celebrities who urged people to stamp out their butts for the Great American Smokeout. An eclectic mix of two dozen personalities from television, stage, sports, music and politics gathered on the eve of the 14th annual Smokeout to give firsthand accounts of what made them give up tobacco, or never start. The venue was the American Cancer Society offices. The society sponsors the yearly pitch to get at least some of the country's 50 million smokers to abandon their unhealthy habit for 24 hours, if not longer. ``Throw your cigarettes away for the day. ... The clouds of smoke will turn so sunny, not to mention savin' you money,'' the celebrities sang. Lung surgeon Dr. Bill Cahan told the crowd to remember people like Sammy Davis Jr., Yul Brenner and Leonard Bernstein. All died as a direct result of smoking, he said. ``I see the end result of smoking all too often. As a matter of fact, I've named my surgery room `Marlboro Country,''' Cahan said. In Philadelphia, a familiar stogie was stubbed out. Advertising for the automotive Pep Boys will no longer include a cigar-chomping Manny. Since the Roaring Twenties, a beaming, bespectacled likeness of the late Emanuel ``Manny'' Rosenfeld accompanied the other two Pep Boys - Moe & Jack - in ads for the auto parts and service chain that operates in 17 states. The celebrities in New York stepped up to tell their smoking stories. ``When I was 30 and doing eight shows a day, I smoked three packs a day,'' the effervescent actress Carol Channing said. ``I couldn't get into a bathtub without an ashtray, a match and a cigarette.'' A stern warning from her doctor got her thinking about quitting. But it was Cupid who deserves the credit, she said. ``At the same time, I met my future husband and he didn't smoke. ... I didn't want to smell like an old sewer around somebody I was stuck on.'' Rod Gilbert, a National Hockey League hall of famer, said he was 12 when he stole a pack of cigarettes from his older brother. When his brother found out, Gilbert said: ``He took me upstairs to the bathroom and hit me on the head with his fist ... and then said, `Get up, I'm going to hit you again.''' The bop on the bean and a stern lecture convinced him to leave the butts alone - for a while. After retiring from hockey, Gilbert said he got into the restaurant business and began smoking. He quit two years ago after having some polyps removed. Rapper L.L. Cool J never was and never will be a smoker. ``Smoking is the pits. It's terrible. It's garbage. I hate it. Get rid of them,'' he said. The Philadelphia-based Pep Boys agree. Rosenfeld smoked cigars until his death, but his image puffed on for the chain, which has 300 stores and employs 12,000 people. To coincide with the Smokeout, the cigar got tossed. ``The decision was based on our desire to promote a healthier image for employees and customers,'' said Fred Stampone, senior vice president of the company founded in 1921.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS first graf of final item to CORRECT spelling to Sondheim
DOC.TEXT: Stephen Sondheim's ``Into the Woods'' was named the best musical of the 1989-90 London theater season at the annual Evening Standard Drama Awards. ``Shadowlands,'' a play by William Nicholson based on the life of writer C.S. Lewis, won the best drama award. It opened on Broadway two days earlier to mixed-to-negative reviews. Its London run finished in September and its future in New York is in doubt. The best actress award went to Josette Simon. The British actress won praise in June for being the first black woman to play the Marilyn Monroe part, Maggie, in Arthur Miller's partly autobiographical play, ``After the Fall.'' Richard Harris was named best actor for his performance in the title role of Luigi Pirandello's ``Henry IV.'' The revival, which was not a commercial success, has been mentioned for Broadway next year.

DOC.HEAD: Rain and Snow in Northwest, Record Highs in Upper Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered across the Northwest on Wednesday, with snow at higher elevations, and temperatures rose nearly 20 degrees above normal in the upper Midwest and Plains, breaking records that were nearly a century old. Afternoon rain extended from San Francisco across north-central California. Showers were scattered over northwestern Washington state, with thundershowers at Hoquiam Pass. Rain over west-central Montana and the Idaho Panhandle changed to snow over northwestern Idaho. About 3 inches of snow fell overnight on Siskiyou Summit, near the California-Oregon state line, and 5 inches of new snow covered Washington's Stampede Pass at sunrise. By noon, temperatures over much of the upper Midwest reached as much as 20 degrees above normal for mid-November. The dividing line between warm temperatures and much cooler temperatures extended across north-central North Dakota, northwestern Wyoming and on to the central coast of California, the National Weather Service said. Record highs included 74 degrees at Concordia, Kan.; 77 at Denver; 73, a tie at Des Moines; 67 at Eau Claire, Wis.; 75, a tie at Goodland, Kan.; 73, a tie at Kansas City, Mo.; 68, a tie at La Crosse, Wis.; 74 at Lincoln, Neb.; 70 at Minnapolis-St. Paul; 78, a tie at North Platte, Neb.; 82 at Pueblo, Colo.; 68 at Rochester, Minn.; 67 at St. Cloud, Minn.; and 78, a tie at Valentine, Neb. The previous records at Denver, North Platte, Pueblo and Valentine had stood since 1894. The normal high temperature for Nov. 14 at Minneapolis-St. Paul is 43. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 30 degrees at Montpelier, Vt., to 84 at Harlingen, Texas, and Tampa, Fla. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 10 degrees at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Hispanics Lost Ground In 1980s
DOC.TEXT: Hispanic earnings and living conditions deteriorated in many metropolitan areas and Hispanics lost economic ground compared to other Americans during the 1980s, according to a study issued Wednesday. The independent, non-profit Aspen Institute said overall conditions for Hispanics improved in only one city, Miami, and remained relatively stable in only one other city with a large Hispanic population, San Diego. But the ``parity gap'' with Anglo-Americans widened in 11 other cities over the past decade, the report said. The 13 cities studied are home to two-thirds of U.S. Hispanics. ``While the rich got richer and the poor got poorer, did Hispanics get poorer than Anglos? They did,'' the report said. Between 1979 and 1987, the real median family income of Hispanics fell in all but four of the 13 areas - New York; McAllen, Texas; Miami; and Phoenix, where it remain unchanged. With the exception of McAllen, aided by a joint venture with Mexico, the greatest declines occurred among Hispanics in Texas, where the economy was hit by the oil price shocks of the 1980s, the study found. In Dallas, Hispanics' median family income fell from $23,274 in 1979 to $19,000 in 1987, while the percentage of Hispanics living in poverty grew from 20 percent to 30 percent over the past decade. In Houston, Hispanics' family income fell from $25,281 in 1979 to $19,000 in 1987. At the beginning of the 1980s, 19 percent of Hispanics were living in poverty, at the close of the decade, 30 percent were considered below the poverty level. In addition to studying income and poverty rates, the report looked at educational attainment, unemployment rates and other factors to judge overall Hispanic-Anglo-American parity. It said San Diego had the narrowest parity gap, followed, in order, by Miami, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Denver, Dallas, Houston, Chicago and New York. Comparable data was not available for McAllen, El Paso, San Antonio and Phoenix. Miami has made the greatest progress toward parity, the study said, followed by San Diego, Dallas, Chicago, New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Houston and Denver. The report warned that the growing gap between Hispanics and Anglo-Americans must be closed. ``The nation's competitive position cannot be maintained if a sharp division continues between stable leadership isolated in the suburbs and poor workers and an underclass isolated in deteriorating inner cities,'' said Solomon D. Trujillo, vice president and general manager of US WEST Communications. Trujillo is also chairman of the Aspen Institute's Hispanic Americans and the Business Community Program, which issued the report. The country's Hispanic population is estimated to be 34.8 million in the year 2000, up from 20.1 million in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Project Enlists Schoolchildren to Curb Exploitation
DOC.TEXT: An environmental group and a dozen of the country's major zoos hope to enlist schoolchildren in the fight to curb the commercial exploitation of endangered wild animals. The World Wildlife Fund unveiled a program Wednesday in which suitcases full of confiscated wildlife products - including elephant tusks and cat skins - will be used in an education program aimed at youngsters. The education kit ``will provide a hands-on way to show young people that what they buy does make a difference in saving endangered species,'' said Kathryn Fuller, president of the World Wildlife Fund and the Conservation Foundation. ``Suitcases for Survival'' are being sent to a dozen zoos around the country where they will be made available for teachers to use in classrooms. Most of the items were confiscated at U.S. ports because they violated the endangered species or other wildlife protection laws. The trade of wildlife products is estimated to be a $5 billion a year industry worldwide. Officials of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service estimate that only about 10 percent of the illegal products destined for U.S. sales are intercepted. An array of wildlife products confiscated by authorities were displayed at a news conference at the National Zoo. They included a leg rest made from an elephant foot, jewelry from elephant tusks, stuffed endangered sea turtles, skins from a variety of endangered cats as well products made from crocodile, snake and lizard skins and a knife handle made from a rhinoceros tusk.

DOC.HEAD: Rundown of History at Eastern Airlines
With AM-Eastern, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are key events in the history of Eastern Airlines over the past 15 years: 1975 - Frank Borman, former astronaut, becomes president. 1976 - Borman becomes chairman and wins pay freeze from workers. 1978 - Congress deregulates airline industry, allowing carriers to set their own fares and fly where they want. As fare wars begin, Borman plunges Eastern deep into debt by buying a fleet of new planes. 1980 - Eastern's debt swells to more than $2.2 billion. 1983 - Borman threatens to take Eastern into bankruptcy without concessions from employees to reduce costs. They relent in exchange for a 25 percent stake in the company and seats on the board. 1985 - Labor tension increases despite union participation in running the company. Eastern barely breaks even due to fare wars. 1986 - Eastern's debt increases to $2.5 billion. Company again considers bankruptcy, lays off more than 1,000 workers and gets wage concessions from pilots. But debt pressure forces the sale of the airline to Texas Air Corp. for $676 million. Borman quits. 1987 - Texas Air boss Frank Lorenzo, considered a union-buster by organized labor, vows to cut costs at Eastern. March 1989 - Lorenzo rejects union demands, workers strike and Eastern seeks protection from creditors in bankruptcy court. Lorenzo replaces strikers and sells some Eastern assets, notably the Northeast shuttle to developer Donald Trump. April 1989 - An attempt to buy Eastern led by former baseball commissioner Peter Ueberroth collapses. Eastern vows to reorganize into a smaller airline. September 1989 - Lorenzo predicts Eastern will turn a profit in 1990. November 1989 - Striking pilots and flight attendants vote to return to work, leaving machinists alone on picket lines. December 1989 - American Airlines agrees to buy Eastern's Latin American routes for $471 million, shrinking Eastern by about one-third. January 1990 - Eastern backs away from earlier pledge to fully repay all its debts. March 1990 - Special examiner in bankruptcy case finds Texas Air victimized Eastern by purchasing some key assets at unfairly low prices. Texas Air disputes the report but agrees to give Eastern $280 million in compensation. April 1990 - Angry creditors, frustrated by Eastern's rising losses and reduced plan for repayment, seek appointment of a special trustee to run the airline and possibly find a buyer. Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland grants their request, seizing control from Lorenzo and appoints veteran airline executive Martin R. Shugrue Jr. to run the airline. May 1990 - Shugrue launches a ``100 Days'' promotional campaign, vowing to make Eastern profitable and woo back passengers. He follows in September with a plan for targeting business travelers. November 1990 - Shugrue's estimates for recovery prove grossly optimistic, partly because of an economic downturn and rapidly rising fuel costs caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. Exasperated creditors decide to seek liquidation of the airline.

DOC.HEAD: For British Prime Ministers, End Can be Sad and Sudden
With AM-Britain-Thatcher, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Many British prime ministers serve long and glorious terms in office, but for some the end has been sudden and sorrowful. Few go out voluntarily in the style of Lord Salisbury, who retired in 1902 after 13{ years in office. And since then, no one has served longer than Margaret Thatcher, who faces her first serious challenge after 11{ years in power. She has lasted longer than Sir Winston Churchill and Herbert Asquith, who each served eight years, eight months. Both resigned under pressure from colleagues. Churchill lost the first peacetime election in 1945, but when a Labor Party government fell in 1951, Churchill was back at 10 Downing Street, the prime minister's home. ``Everyone has his day, and some days last longer than others,'' he said in a speech to the House of Commons in 1952. Churchill's days of power lasted until 1955 when, at age 80, he resigned under pressure from party colleagues who saw he could no longer concentrate on Cabinet business. His successor, Sir Anthony Eden, lasted only two years, his health and then his career broken by the Suez crisis. Churchill lived a decade after retiring, but others died soon after relinquishing power. The Liberal Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman was dead 17 days after resigning in 1908. The Conservative Bonar Law lived only five months after he quit in 1923. Neville Chamberlain, who was replaced by Churchill in the early months of World War II, lived only another six months. Asquith was maneuvered out in 1916, in the midst of a world war, by Liberal Party colleagues headed by David Lloyd George who believed they could conduct the war more effectively. Lloyd George, still regarded as perhaps the cleverest prime minister of the century, lost the 1922 election to Bonar Law's Conservatives but expected to return to power quickly. The defeat, however, was the end of Lloyd George as a force in politics and also of his Liberal Party. He remained in politics until his death in 1945 but had little influence and no power. Harold Macmillan resigned after nearly seven years as prime minister, after falling ill in 1963. He summoned Queen Elizabeth II to his hospital bedside and said his foreign secretary, the 14th Earl of Home, later Lord Home of the Hirsel, should succeed him and not R.A. Butler, Macmillan's deputy, whom the prime minister disliked. But Macmillan could have stayed on - he did not die until 1986 at age 92. In any event, Home lasted only a year before the party was defeated by Labor in a general election. During his term, however, Home changed the rules for selecting Conservative prime ministers - abolishing the smoke-filled room of party leaders in favor of a secret ballot by Tory lawmakers.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Kills 11 Before Dying in Shootout With Police
DOC.TEXT: Police on Wednesday fatally wounded a man described as ``absolutely ruthless'' who set fire to a neighbor's home in a coastal village and then shot to death 11 people who rushed to the scene. Two young girls wounded in the assault were hospitalized in stable condition. A police officer was also shot in the leg. Police identified the killer, who used high-powered rifles, as David Malcolm Gray, 33. Neighbors described him as a loner upset by his mother's recent death. New Zealand's worst massacre began Tuesday night when Gray set fire to a the house in the South Island village of Aramoana. He then began shooting people who came to help. ``There may have been a children's party on there or something as there seemed to be a lot of kids about,'' said neighbor Dorothy Crimp. The siege in the town 17 miles north of Dunedin ended 23 hours later when anti-terrorism police rushed a house where Gray was holed up and shot him in the chest. In between, Gray killed two children, including a 6-year-old boy who rode up on his bicycle to see what all the commotion was about; the head of police in nearby Port Chalmers; and eight other adults. While inside his home, Gray used high-powered rifles to keep olice at bay and prevent them from reaching the victims, who were scattered on the lawn and a nearby street. New Zealand Police Commissioner John Jamieson described the gunman as ``one tough customer'' and ``absolutely ruthless.'' ``We have a situation here obviously with a lunatic who's gone berserk,'' Jamieson said. ``There are young children getting shot down in cold blood.'' About 140 police poured into remote Aramoana. The town comprises just five streets and is home to about 25 people, mainly retirees. Officers steadily tightened a cordon around Gray's house before rushing in Wednesday afternoon. Armed men in uniform and black ski masks moved in, single file, as they hit the house with tear gas. Smoke spilled out the windows, but Gray was nowhere to be found - just a .22-caliber rifle, an air rifle, 9mm ammunition - and bodies. Police went door-to-door before moving back into the center of town. The search led to a house on the edge of town. Jamieson said the gunman opened fire on an anti-terrorism squad approaching the building, wounding one officer in the leg. Police lobbed smoke grenades and returned fire, hitting Gray in the chest. He died at the scene a few minutes later, Jamieson said. Dunedin police Sgt. Bill O'Brien said police were mystified over what drove Gray to the violence. ``We don't know why he has done this,'' O'Brien said. Neighbors described the unemployed Gray as a moody loner who had been upset by the death of his mother about three months ago. Mrs. Crimp called him ``a very quiet chap, a real loner. ... He never spoke to anyone.'' Frank and Iris Henderson, who live in nearby Waipuna Bay, said 6-year-old victim Leo Wilson lived in the house opposite them. ``He heard all the police cars and fire engines going past and went down on his bike to have a look at it all. He ran straight into it,'' Henderson said. The worst previous massacre in New Zealand occurred in 1941 when Eric Stanley Graham killed six police officers before he was shot to death.

DOC.HEAD: Tests Opposed by Testing Group, Teachers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs, `What is ...' to ADD comment from Education Department official. Picks up 5th graf pvs `Anrig's comment...' ^By TAMARA HENRY
DOC.TEXT: The head of the nation's largest testing organization said Wednesday a proposed exam to judge students and their schools would be unnecessary, unwarranted and wasteful. Gregory Anrig, president of Educational Testing Service, said at the National Press Club on Wednesday that he detailed his opposition to such a test in a letter to the president's Education Policy Advisory Committee. The panel reportedly is preparing to recommend national testing of all students in grades four, eight and 12, and want to use the results ``for important judgments about students and schools,'' he said. ``What is needed is not another test, but strategies to promote higher standards, clearer expectations for schools to achieve these standards, and demonstrations that these standards and expectations can be met successfully,'' Anrig said in the Sept. 19 letter. Deputy Education Secretary Ted Sanders agreed. ``We need to make better use of the instruments we have, both to guide classroom learning and to measure our progress in meeting national goals,'' he said. Anrig's comments underscored results of a Gallup Poll of the nation's top teachers released earlier Wednesday. Seventy-three percent of the teachers surveyed said they felt pressured to spend more time preparing students for tests, and 57 percent said classroom subjects were determined by what is covered on the test. ``Exceptional teachers, who perhaps understand and deplore this dilemma more than their peers, want to break the shackles that bind them to wasteful modes of instruction,'' the poll said in its summary. The Gallup Poll involved 231 teachers who were semifinalists cited for excellence from among 20,000 nominees to a nationwide program called ``Thanks to Teachers.'' Anrig said 47 states already have statewide testing programs, with results released annually. Congress also recently authorized trial state assessments using the federally funded National Assessment of Educational Progress. Anrig said the ETS next month will unveil instructional assessments for critical thinking, science, mathematics, writing and the arts at the junior high level. Rather than dictate curriculum, the assessment will assist and supplement instruction, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gallery Gets Painting Nearly 268 Square Feet
DOC.TEXT: A monumental work by contemporary German-born artist Anselm Kiefer titled ``Zim Zum'' has been given to the National Gallery of Art by a private committee of wealthy contributors, gallery director J. Carter Brown said Wednesday. ``Zim Zum,'' which measures nearly 18{ feet by 14{ feet, is the first Kiefer work to enter the gallery collection. Completed earlier this year, it will be put on public display Thursday in the gallery's East Building. The Kiefer work is made of several interlocking sheets of lead partially covered with canvas treated with oil, crayon, ashes, sand and lead and clay dust, with a canvas landscape painting across the bottom. Kiefer's complex works include references to Teutonic mythology and historical drama. The title ``Zim Zum'' refers to the Judaic concept of Tsimtsum, the instant of creation described in the Kabbalah, a mystical Jewish system of occult beliefs and scriptural interpretation.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Says It Will Seek Full Independence from Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Georgian declaration, Lithuanian prime minister's remarks, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TBL1
With AM-Soviet-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Georgia's new parliament declared Wednesday it will seek full independence from the Soviet Union, which it accused of seven decades of ``bloody terror and repression.'' In Lithuania, Prime Minister Kazimiere Prunskiene said her Baltic republic may soon face a second Kremlin economic blockade. She sought help in advance from other Soviet republics, Western companies and former U.S. Sen. Gary Hart. Angry members of the national legislature demanded that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev report to them on his attempts to hold the country together and on his Sunday meeting with his main political rival, Russian Federation President Boris N. Yeltsin. Gorbachev agreed to address the Supreme Soviet on Friday, the official Tass news agency said. Georgian lawmakers met in Tbilisi, their capital, for the first time since a pro-independence coalition, the Round Table for a Free Georgia, won Oct. 28 parliamentary elections. Those elections were the first true multiparty polling in Soviet history. Parliament voted 238 to 5 with one abstention to elect Round Table leader Zviad Gamsakhurdia, a 51-year-old author, as Georgia's president. He immediately reiterated his promise to lead the southern republic's 5.3 million people to complete independence and a market-based economy. ``We are for an economy totally independent of the central authorities, a maximum of privatization, and business contacts with all (other states) on a mutually beneficial basis,'' he told Interfax, an independent Soviet news agency. Tass said the parliament declared Georgia was entering a transition period to ``full state independence'' and dropped ``Soviet'' and ``Socialist'' from its name. It now is called the Republic of Georgia, instead of the Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic. The length of the transition period was not set. Georgia earlier declared economic sovereignty from the central Soviet government, but Wednesday's declaration went further and appeared to rule out signing a new treaty of confederation among the 15 Soviet republics, as Gorbachev wants. All 15 republics with the exception of Kirgizia now have taken steps toward sovereignty or independence, and the parliament of that Central Asian republic has been debating a possible sovereignty resolution for weeks. Georgia's parliament restored the state hymn, seal and flag used from 1919 to 1921, when Georgia was independent. In an amended preamble to the republic's constitution, the lawmakers said that in February and March of 1921, ``Soviet Russia rudely violated'' a peace treaty it signed with Georgia, occupied the republic by military force and effectively annexed it. The entire period in which Georgia has been part of the Soviet Union has been marked by ``bloody terror and repression,'' the preamble says. Georgia, in the Caucasus Mountains, is bordered by Russia, Armenia and Azerbaijan. The republic is a major resort area and the nation's fruit and vegetable basket. Georgia also has mining and industry. Lithuania was the first republic to declare independence, on March 11. Its parliament agreed to suspend the declaration in return for the Kremlin's calling off a crippling, 10-week trade embargo and entering negotiations. Mrs. Prunskiene said Monday night that Kremlin officials show no willingness to compromise and are trying to squeeze Lithuania economically before scheduled formal negotiations begin at the end of this month. She said another embargo was ``quite a possibility, an ominous reality that is approaching us.'' During the first blockade, from April 18 to June 30, Moscow cut off all oil, most natural gas and many raw materials, forcing Lithuanian factories to close and thousands to lose jobs. Mrs. Prunskiene said she met Wednesday with Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov; economist Grigory Yavlinsky, a deputy prime minister of the Russian Federation; and Gary Hart, the former U.S. senator from Colorado and 1988 Democratic presidential candidate. She said she wanted to discuss possible trade agreements with Moscow and other Russian cities or regions to ``help us in escaping a blockade which could be even worse than the previous one.'' She said Hart brought along ``representatives of a large investment bank and some other Western companies which have large-scale plans for investments in Lithuania.'' She declined to provide names or details.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Leftist Guerrillas Rescue Jailed Comrade, Kill Four
DOC.TEXT: Suspected leftist guerrillas killed three prison guards and a policeman Wednesday during a rescue of a jailed comrade from a hospital where he was undergoing an eye examination, authorities reported. Santiago police chief Gen. Oscar Tapia said another prison guard and an unidentified woman, apparently one of the attackers, were wounded. Tapia said the ``extremist commando'' fired with submachine guns at a group of prisons guards taking the imprisoned leftist, Marco Antonioletti, for an eye examination. Three guards were killed and one was seriously wounded, police said. The police officer, who was on duty at the hospital, was killed when he shot back at the attackers. Tapia said the guerrillas succeeded in rescuing Antonioletti. He is the leader of the Lautaro Front, a small radical gang indicted in the 1989 kiling of a police officer. Speaking in Arica, in northern Chile, President Patricio Aylwin condemned the attack. He noted it came as the government and National Renewal, the largest opposition party, were nearing agreement on legislation to free about 260 leftists imprisoned for political crimes under the former military regime. The attack is certain to hamper the agreement, said Jose Antonio Viera-Gallo, president of the lower house of Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Top-Line U.S. Tanks Enter Saudi Arabia to Replace Older Models
DOC.TEXT: The first of several hundred top-line American M1A1 tanks rolled into Saudi Arabia Wednesday night to replace older models and give U.S. forces a bigger edge against the Iraqis. The M1A1 Abrams tanks, the Army's premiere ground combat weapon, willreplace M1 tanks in all front-line Army units currently deployed in Saudi Arabia as part of Operation Desert Shield. ``The M1 is better than anything the Iraqis have,'' said Army spokesman Maj. Douglas Bidle, 38, of Arlington Heights, Ill. ``The M1 gave us an edge. This is a better tank, so obviously this is an even better edge.'' The M1A1 has better chemical and biological warfare protection, enabling the four-man tank crew to operate inside without wearing protective gear. M1 crews must don protective clothing and hook into a breathing system. The M1 has a 105mm gun, far smaller than the M1A1's 120mm gun, which can penetrate more and thicker armor. Bidle said the M1A1 also has ``improved survivability'' with better armor, better suspension and a newer transmission and final drive. The new tanks arrived on the civilian-crewed U.S. government cargo ship, the Norfolk, Va.-based Cape Ducato, after a three-week trip from Germany plagued by engine trouble. A steady stream of M1A1s rumbled out of the cargo hold onto the dock late Wednesday. Jane's Defense Weekly reported last month that 350 M1s would be swapped for M1A1s. The khaki tanks, which will now be repainted in desert camoflauge, were taken from pre-positioned storage facilities in Europe where they were part of NATO's inventory to be used in the event of hostilites. The Department of Defense, in announcing the replacement on Oct. 20, said the tanks would have had to be phased out anyway in the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty expected to be signed by the end of the year. The treaty is expected to cut the number of tanks in Europe. The Defense Department said it was proposing to the NATO allies that the older tanks continue to be counted under the treaty. Bidle said the M1 tanks being taken out of the desert will remain in Saudi Arabia as a reserve, to replace those lost in battle. The M1A1s will replace M1s in the 24th Infantry Division, the 197th Infantry Brigade and the 2nd Armored Division that is part of the First Cavalry Division, Bidle said. All are front-line units in the 230,000-strong U.S. force sent here to defend Saudi Arabia. The Department of Defense has said all tanks will be switched by the end of the year. The only unit in Saudi Arabia that has M1A1 tanks at the moment is the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment which brought them with them from Ft. Bliss, Texas. It is unclear whether the 200,000 U.S. troops being mobilized by President Bush to give the United States an offensive capability will also have M1A1 tanks.

DOC.HEAD: List of Previous Alitalia Crashes
With AM-Alitalia Crash
DOC.TEXT: Following is a list of most recent crashes involving Alitalia, the Italian state-run carrier: Oct 15, 1987 - An ATR-42 of the carrier ATI, a subsidiary of Alitalia, crashed near Como, Italy, on a flight from Milan to Cologne, West Germany. All 37 aboard killed. Dec 22, 1978 - An Alitalia DC-9 crashed into the sea three miles short of the runway of Palermo's airport, killing 108 of the 124 people on board. May 5, 1972 - An Alitalia DC-8 crashed on a mountainside near Punta Raisi Airport in Palermo, killing all 115 people aboard.

DOC.HEAD: Nationwide Labor Stike Fails; Government Attacks Rebels
DOC.TEXT: The government Wednesday squelched a nationwide strike over its economic policies by barring news coverage and threatening to fire participating workers. In a radio interview, President Cesar Gaviria announced that the army and air force were waging a major assault on the main base of the Armed Revolutionary Forces of Colombia. The leftist group, known by its Spanish acronym FARC, is the country's oldest and biggest rebel group. Radio and newspaper reports said the fighting at the base had left about 35 guerrillas and at least two soldiers dead. A spokesman at the Defense Ministry said the total dead was not yet known. Gaviria, who declared the strike illegal, said lftist guerrillas could take advantage of it to step up violence. Military and police reinforcements were increased throughout the country. Radio and television were prohibited from reporting on the strike. In one of the government's toughest stands in years against strikers, the president authorized businesses to fire employees who didn't show up to work. Most shops, banks and factories were open Wednesday, despite the work stoppage called by Colombia's four main labor unions. Labor unions had called the strike to protest Gaviria's economic policies of privatizing many state-run industries and raising prices of basic goods and services. Workers fear the new measures will increase poverty and unemployment. Despite the government measures, some workers, including those of the state monopoly telephone company, did observe the strike. Traffic in major cities was reduced. In addition, university students in the capital, Bogota, and in the northwestern city of Medellin staged demonstrations. Also Wednesday, Gaviria confirmed that the military, supported by jets and helicopter gunships, had been attacking the FARC's main base in the eastern province of Meta since last week. The army also reported that highway ambushes and gunfire attacks on military bases have killed nine policemen and soldiers the past three days. The FARC and another insurgent group, the National Liberation Army, are not participating in peace talks between the government and three other rebel organizations.

DOC.HEAD: FERC Approves Iroquois Gas Pipeline From Canada to Northeast
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 6th graf: ``Iroquois still,'' to CORRECT that Energy Department permits still needed, not Connecticut. Connecticut permits have been granted
DOC.TEXT: After four years of contentious debate among environmentalists, homeowners and rival energy suppliers, federal regulators Wednesday approved construction of a $583 million pipeline to bring natural gas from Canada to the Northeast. In the end, tight energy supplies in New England, New York and New Jersey outweighed the concerns of opponents of the Iroquois pipeline, who ranged from wildcat oil drillers in the Southwest to pop psychologist Dr. Joyce Brothers, whose Hudson Valley estate in New York would be crossed by the line. Jerry Langdon, a member of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, said Wednesday's unanimous decision by his agency represented a move to make greater use of North American, if not just U.S., energy supplies. Robert J. Reid, president of the Iroquois Gas Transmission System, a consortium of U.S. and Canadian gas companies and utilities based in Shelton, Conn., said, ``It was imperative that we receive FERC approval in November to maintain our timetable for constructing the pipeline.'' The pipeline will extend 370 miles from the St. Lawrence River through the woodlands of upstate New York, beneath the Hudson River, into affluent sections of western Connecticut and across Long Island Sound to Long Island. Iroquois officials hope to have gas flowing to New York and New England by November 1991 and to complete the line by January 1992. Iroquois still has a few regulatory hurdles to clear, including permits from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, for waterway crossings, and import permits from the Energy Department, expected to be pro forma under the U.S.-Canada free trade agreement. Thousands of property owners along the route have not yet agreed to let Iroquois pay to cross their land and Iroquois may have to settle some of those cases in court. ``This has been controversial almost since it was filed in 1986,'' said Susan Court, associate general counsel of the commission for gas and oil. Iroquois is designed to deliver 575 million cubic feet of gas daily, or enough to meet the energy needs of 1.5 million homes - though one reason it is being built is to make gas available for electricity generation. The daily amount could supply between three and four large electric power plants if it were all devoted to that use, though utilities receiving the gas may use it for any of their customers. The gas supplied by Iroquois will increase the energy supply flowing to the Northeast by 5 percent, according to Reid. Iroquois could double transmission capacity with additional compressors. Existing gas pipelines to the Northeast from U.S. gas fields have been running at capacity for years. No one sought to build new ones. TransCanada Pipelines Ltd., one of Iroquois' several owners, estimated the new line will generate $1 billion per year in exports for Canada. Canada has been supplying natural gas to the United States since the 1960s, but mostly in the West and Midwest. Domestic energy suppliers complained that Iroquois will discourage production and will compete unfairly with U.S. pipelines and oil companies. Iroquois' gas, however, will be more expensive than U.S. gas and cheaper than oil, according to a formula approved by the commission that ties the price to those two commodities. ``We really view oil as the competition, not other natural gas,'' said Iroquois spokesman Gary Davis.

DOC.HEAD: Some Panel Members Regret Recommendation Took So Long
DOC.TEXT: Some members of a scientific panel said Wednesday they should have moved faster to draft guidelines for adding steroids to the treatment of a killer pneumonia in people with AIDS. ``In retrospect, it should have happened more quickly,'' said Paul Meier, professor of statistics at the University of Chicago and vice chairman of the panel that convened last May. AIDS activists also said the panel took too long, but federal medical officials said these critics were disregarding some important facts. Still other panel members said the approval process could not have been significantly speeded up. The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases on Oct. 10 sent an alert to physicians informing them that recent studies had found benefits among some patients with Pneumocycstis carinii pneumonia whose treatment was supplemented with steroids. Steorids are known to weaken the immune system, and AIDS is a disease of a collapsing immune system. The letter, sent to 2,600 medical practitioners, was based on the findings of the 17-member panel organized by the institute and the University of California at San Diego. Mike Merdian, executive director of the National Association of People with AIDS, said the five months it took the panel to come up with its recommendations was ``unconscionable'' and ``unethical'' but not unusual. ``We've long said there are many therapies available we're not aware of,'' he said. But the chairman of the panel rejected the criticism and said the time it took members to analyze the studies was well spent trying to agree on the wording of any recommendations as to which patients would benefit most from steroid treatment, in what doses and for what period of time. The five months was ``a relatively short period,'' said Dr. Henry Masur, panel chairman and chief of critical care the National Institutes of Health clinical center. ``I don't think it will ever get much faster.'' Since steroids weaken the immune system, ``The whole concept of giving steroids to someone with AIDS is very novel and controversial,'' Masur said. Among the concerns are that steroids can increase the rate at which the AIDS virus replicates and make it more likely other infectious complications develop, he said. ``It was vitally important to make sure that steroids unequivocally improved survival and it was important to prove that while improving from one disease it didn't cause numerous other potentially fatal problems,'' he said. Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia is the biggest killer of people with AIDS. About 40,000 cases are expected to occur this year in the United States. The broad outlines of a consensus on the steroid issue was reached May 15, but it wasn't until the end of August that the experts agreed on the technical details, such as for whom the therapy should be recommended for and in what doses. They decided that the studies showed that patients who benefit most from steroids along with standard therapy were those who had moderate or severe Pneumocystis, but that there was no evidence of benefit for patients with mild disease. Bernard Bihari, executive-medical director of the Community Research Initiative, which treats AIDS patients in New York, said the issue was too important for lengthy disagreements to stall the discussions. ``They should have locked them in a room and said, `You're not coming out until you have a statement,''' he said. Dr. Samuel Bozzette, assistant professor of medicine at the University of California at San Diego and a panel member, said that ``in a perfect system, it could have been shorter, but it was not an unreasonable amount of time.'' He added that ``when you release one of these consensus statements, you are setting a worldwide standard of care, and one has to make sure that the recommendations are as carefully considered as possible.'' But he also agreed with Meier that the documents could have been passed around more quickly and ``day-to-day processes could have moved quicker.'' Meier said that the panel, which took about three months to complete its part of the task, ould have achieved that goal in about one month, but nobody set a deadline. ``A failure to recognize it (the process) was dragging is where I would fault us,'' Meier said.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Angry Teen-Agers Likely To Have High Cholesterol as Adults
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf and 6th graf to CORRECT reference to Williams, sted Redford.
DOC.TEXT: Hostile teen-agers are likely to grow up to be adults who have high cholesterol, according to a study that finds new links between anger and heart trouble. For years, many experts assumed that hard-driving, impatient people with classic Type A personalities were at high risk of heart attacks. But many have grown skeptical of this theory, and some now believe that the truly lethal personality trait is hostility and anger. ``People with high hostility at age 19 tend to have high cholesterol levels at 40,'' Dr. Redford B. Williams of Duke University said Wednesday. Williams' study was among several presented at the annual meeting of the American Heart Association to suggest that hostile people are more prone to heart trouble - both because of the effects of adrenaline and other hormones on their bodies and their tendency to have unhealthy living habits. One report from Yale University researchers found that people who react to situations with strong emotions, particularly anger, are especially likely to die of cardiac arrest. Williams' study, conducted with Dr. Ilene C. Siegler, was based on a followup 20 years later of 830 people who took personality tests while students at the University of North Carolina in the mid-1960s. They found that those who scored high on a hostility scale in college tended to have high levels of total cholesterol in their blood but relatively low amounts of HDL, the protective so-called ``good cholesterol.'' ``One explanation for this is the effect of hormones that mobilize lipids from fat stores,'' said Williams. When people get angry, their bodies pump out stress hormones, such as adrenaline, which trigger the body to release fat into the bloodstream to provide energy. ``Stress hormones give you a Hershey bar when they fire off,'' Williams said. Hostility may work to raise cholesterol and harm the heart in other ways, too. Other Duke research found that alumni who were especially rebellious or hostile were more likely to smoke cigarettes. This suggests that hostile people are less health conscious. In Williams' view, hostile people tend to be suspicious as well as easily angered. ``They are the people who, when they stand in the 12-item line at the supermarket, always count how many items other people have,'' said Williams. ``They always suspect that other people are trying to weasel through.'' In another study at Duke, researchers set up an experiment to see how people would respond when bothered by a technician while trying to solve word puzzles. Hostile people tended to react by getting angry at the harrassment, and their blood pressures rose. ``I think the effects of hostility are preventable or even reversible'' through stress management techniques, he said. The Yale study, by Dr. Lynda Powell, was based on eight to 10 years of followup of 929 men who had survived heart attacks. The researchers interviewed the men and scored how emotionally aroused they became by observing such things as tense facial expressions, rapid speech, quick gestures, rapid blinking, an aggressive attitude and other clues from their posture and words. ``We think hostility is a critical part of emotional arousal, but it's too specific,'' Powell said. ``Extreme joy can trigger the same thing. It is the resulting surge of stress hormones that puts the person at increased risk of death.'' Powell believes that chronic exposure to these hormones, which help the body gear up for emergencies, can damage the heart and trigger cardiac arrest. Her study found that those who scored high in emotional reactivity were three times more likely than more even tempered people to die of cardiac arrest, and their risk was five times higher if they also had high cholesterol levels.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Will Meet African Foreign Ministers This Weekend
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 8th graf: ``ABC News,'' report of decision to submit resolution and denial
DOC.TEXT: In an effort to solidify support for U.S. moves in the Persian Gulf, Secretary of State James A. Baker III will meet this weekend with the foreign ministers of three African countries that are members of the U.N. Security Council. He hopes to persuade them to support a resolution authorizing the use of force to expel Iraqi invaders from Kuwait. Baker last week lined up the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France. They are permanent members of the Council and could have killed the resolution with their veto. The three African countries are Ethiopia, Ivory Coast and Zaire. Enlisting them to support the Bush administration would give the toughened U.S. stance broaer approval among neutral and Third World nations. Baker's meetings with the African foreign ministers will be held Saturday in Geneva.
