DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto planned
Gap's Infant Offerings Are Another Winner
DOC.TEXT: Gap Inc. is a proud parent - again. After downscaling its trendy Gap apparel line into kid sizes, the California retailer has further miniaturized its offerings for the newborn-to-toddler set. The first babyGap appeared just nine months ago in a corner of a Gap store in San Francisco. Since then the company has spawned babyGap departments within 50 of its 150 GapKids stores that dot the nation's shopping landscape. Though still in its infancy, industry analysts say babyGap has become a ``roaring'' success story based on the same formula that catapulted the company to the status of industry darling: durable clothing in comfortable, generous cuts at affordable prices. Indeed, Gap went against the tide by selecting quality suppliers that do not normally manufacture children's clothing to create a ``hybrid of better quality and fun fashion which is unique in kids' merchandising,'' said Thomas Tashjian, an analyst with Seidler Amdek Securities Inc. in Los Angeles. For parents who cringe at swathing their little ones in synthetic fabrics, babyGap offerings are strictly 100 percent sturdy cotton. Banished from shelves are those anemic gender-identifying pastels - only deep, bold hues can be found on everything from rugby-striped jumpsuits to raime v-neck pullovers and crisp embroidered blouses in tiny sizes. Where else can you find a single-pocket T-shirt in black for a 1-year-old, a Gap spokesman asked rhetorically. The seasonal color palette and natural fibers are what attracted Laura Cooper, a mother from Brooklyn, N.Y., to the babyGap shops in Manhattan shortly after they opened. ``What they do well is edit each of the lines so that you're not overwhelmed with what to choose from,'' Cooper said. And individual items available in an array of colors make for ``an easy way to put together a complementary wardrobe,'' she said. Because Gap turns over its merchandise very frequently, Cooper heads straight for the ``sale'' sign. Though Gap spokesman Richard Crisman said the company is ``not in the business of offering sale racks,'' he conceded merchandise is set aside to make way for fresh offerings, which arrive every six weeks or so. ``You will find a new color palette and new designs (every six weeks) - it may be the same T-shirt, but it might be in a new color, or we may have added a detail,'' he said. The babyGap was the logical outgrowth of GapKids, which was created in 1985 out of Gap President Millard ``Mickey'' Drexler's search for stylish but long-lasting clothing for his own young son. Drexler, who rarely speaks to the press, voiced his frustrations to staff members and realized how tired others also were of pink and blue, Crisman said. Originally the kids' clothes were simply scaled-down versions of the adult line, but once executives realized what a hit they had on their hands, Gap established a team to design just the children's line. Because the kids stores are smaller - partially to minimize the risk in launching the line and also because the merchandise is, well, smaller - sales per square foot outpace that of Gap stores, already among the highest in the industry. Analysts have estimated Gap sales at about $360 a square foot; babyGap at $400. Even in this dismal retail environment, the Gap is expected to fare well during the crucial holiday season, mainly because it is a lean operation with low fixed costs and price tags that will not send recession-weary consumers into cardiac arrest. Big-sellers in the baby department are the denim overalls for $28, embroidered blouses for $16, and long-sleeve T-shirts in bright blue, purple, yellow or red for $10. Donald Trott, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., estimates that Gap will report earnings of $1.82 a share for the fiscal year ending Jan. 31, 1991, up from $1.38 the previous year. Sales are expected to total $1.94 billion, up from $1.59 billion. ``Their growth rate has been running at around 20 percent (a year), and it is expected to continue to run at that pace,'' he said. ``GapKids is certainly helping that growth rate. ... In terms of total contribution, babyGap is not significant yet, but we think it has good potential.'' Many GapKids stores are located either within or in sight of regular Gap stores in an effort to piggyback customer traffic. ``There's a benefit to both,'' Crisman said. Having children's and adult clothing under the same roof allows consumers to do all their shopping at one time. But separate children's stores eliminates the problem of kids who ``don't want to be shopping in the same store as their parents,'' Crisman said. The company's latest strategy is to open even bigger stores that can expand the product line and incorporate adult, kids and baby gear all under one roof. GapKids and babyGap are a significant part of Gap's future. The company plans to open more than 40 new Gap stores in 1991; it will open just as many GapKids with babyGap departments. ``We don't do anything here in a big way until we are entirely sure of it, and this is going gangbusters,'' Crisman said. The company, which also owns the Banana Republic chain, is expanding its Gap stores in Britain and Canada. The first free-standing GapKids store opened in London earlier this year. ``The regular line already has 750 stores ... and there isn't any reason why the kids line can't follow along the (parent's) coattails'' in terms of success, analyst Tashjian said. Perhaps Gap's greatest achievement has been its ability to capitalize on the handing down of tradition. Most middle-class babyboomers grew up with some relationship with the Gap; now their children can be clad in similar fare - all exclusive to the Gap.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Monday, Nov. 19

DOC.HEAD: One of Country's Largest Minority-Owned Banks Closes
DOC.TEXT: It was founded as an example of economic hope and inspiration for black Harlem. But now, Freedom National Bank of New York has closed its doors for good. Federal officials began paying off customers' insured deposits Tuesday at the bank, which was established in 1964 and was one of the largest minority-owned banks in the country. Freedom National lost nearly $4 million over the last two years and was expected to lose at least an additional $2 million this year, said the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. The federal agency declared the bank insolvent Friday, and community leaders scrambled during the Veterans Day holiday weekend to find $6 million need to stop the bank's closing. U.S. Rep. Charles Rangel of Harlem said enough money had been committed to save the bank, but the cash could not be moved to the right hands by a 7 a.m. Tuesday deadline set by FDIC regulators. Rangel said there was no question that a day's grace would have saved the bank, whose first chairman was baseball immortal Jackie Robinson. The bank had assets of $101.9 million, 22,000 depositors and 97 employees. ``Had this been a white bank in a white community, I'm sure they wouldn't have done this so precipitously,'' the Rev. Wyatt Tee Walker said outside the bank's main office in Harlem, where some 400 depositors waited on line to get their money. The bank also had two branches in Brooklyn. ``It looks like Freedom never had a chance. Black people come last in this country's agenda,'' said Walker, whose Canaan Baptist Church had more than $500,000 deposited in the bank. Few of those who started forming a line at the bank before dawn expressed fear about the safety of their money. When the doors opened, federal banking officials were sitting at long tables covered with checks to close out all of Freedom National's accounts of $100,000 or less, said FDIC spokesman Caryl Austrian.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Economists Looking For Guidance From Western Colleagues
DOC.TEXT: Soviet economists have been looking to their colleagues in the West for both guidance and reassurance as they struggle towards a market economy, Soviet and American economists meeting at Yale said. Economists from the Soviet Union can read about how the Federal Reserve System works but ``it's not quite the same as talking to someone who knows how it functions,'' said Merton J. Peck, a Yale economics professor involved in an international effort to assist the Soviets. Peck said Tuesday the Soviets are also looking for reassurance as they make a ``tremendous leap of faith.'' While sharp divisions exist in the Soviet Union over how to go about restructuring their economy, ``the interesting thing to me is there is current no discussion that we (the Soviets) don't go to the market,'' Peck said. Several Soviet economists, including a member of the group that drafted the so-called ``Shatalin 500-day Plan,'' are meeting at Yale this week with economists from the United States, Japan and Europe. The economists are part of a group established by the International Institute For Applied Systems Analysis, an East-West organization based near Vienna, Austria. The group was formed last year at the request of Stanislav Shatalin, economic advisor to Mikhail Gorbachev and head of the task force that wrote the 500-day plan. Previous sessions were held in Austria and Hungary. ``We need to rethink the questions that have been raised in the context of where the Soviet Union is going now,'' Peck said. Eugeny Yasin, an economist and member of the Shatalin group, told a news conference Tuesday that he was initially skeptical that the Soviets could gain much from meeting with foreign experts. But after taking part in the meetings with economists from the West, ``I completely changed my mind,'' Yasin said through a translator, a fellow Soviet economist. Peck said one of the problems in the past was that economists from the West used to go over and lecture their Soviet counterparts. ``We try to think of this exchange more as a dialogue and as problem solving. That is the distinguishing feature of our group,'' he said. While the international conference is under way at Yale, another Soviet exchange is taking place at Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven. Five faculty members and nine students from the Moscow Financial Institute, as well as the institute's director, will be learning about entrepreneurship, marketing and productivity at SCSU's School of Business.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Jumps 9.4 Percent in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: British Airways PLC said Wednesday its second-quarter profit rose 9.4 percent but its chairman warned that a profit in the second half was unlikely. For the three months ended Sept. 30, after-tax profits for Britain's biggest airline came to 116 million pounds, or $217 million, compared with 106 million pounds in the same period a year ago. Sales rose 4.6 percent to 1.4 billion pounds, or $2.6 billion, from 1.35 billion pounds a year earlier. For the first six months of the year, after-tax profit jumped 35 percent to 227 million pounds, or $424 million, from 168 million pounds a year earlier. Half-year sales gained 8.7 percent to 2.75 billion pounds, or $5.1 billion, from 2.53 billion pounds a year earlier. The airline's chairman, Lord King, said the company was ``unlikely to show a profit'' in the second half of the year because of higher fuel costs that have resulted from the Middle East crisis. He said fare increases won't recoup the extra costs associated with fuel costs and expected lower traffic growth. The group is carrying out a series of cost cutting exercises to ``minimize the impact'' of the problems the airline faces in the short term, he said. British Airways said that the increase in fuel costs over the half-year was limited to 7.4 percent because arrangements to buy fuel were made in advance of the actual purchases and because of exchange rate benefits. Fuel costs generally increased 23 percent in the second quarter from a year earlier. British Airways said 10.7 percent, or 13.6 million, more passengers were carried on scheduled services in the half year. The figures were converted into dollars at exchange rates provided by the company of $1.87 to the pound.

DOC.HEAD: Exports Decline, Domestic Sales Up This Year
DOC.TEXT: South Korea exported 249,000 motor vehicles between January and October, down 9.5 percent from a year ago, the Korea Automobile Manufacturing Association reported Wednesday. The decline in exports was attributed to price competition and sluggish demand in the United States which is Korea's biggest export market. The association said the number of Korean-made vehicles sold on the domestic market in the first 10 months of this year jumped 24.8 percent to 768,000 from a year ago. Association officials said total sales rose to 748,000 cars, up 9.4 percent from a year ago, and 269,000 comemrcial vehicles, up 29.7 perrcent. The officials said Hyundai Motor Co. topped the list of Korean automakers by marketing 530,000 vehicles at home and abroad during the 10 months, up 7 percent from a year ago. It was followed by Kia Motors Corp. with 313,000 motor vehicles, up 24.7 percent, and Daewoo Motor Co. with 135,000 vehicles, up 15.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Casino and Bondholders Break Off Talks
DOC.TEXT: Investors in the Taj Mahal Casino Resort and casino owner Donald Trump blame each other for breaking off debt restructuring talks just before a $47.3 million payment comes due Thursday. No new negotiations were scheduled after talks broke off Tuesday between Trump and holders of $675 million in bonds used to finance the Taj Mahal, the most ostentatious casino in Atlantic City. Wilbur Ross, senior managing director for New York-based Rothschild Inc. which is negotiating for bondholders, said they're willing to renew negotiations if Trump is reasonable. ``It's up to them,'' Ross said in a telephone interview from New York. ``We're perfectly willing to return.'' But Ross said bondholders remain willing to take their chances at throwing Trump into bankruptcy rather than accept the offer Trump made to restructure the money he owes. The bondholders are secured, or first in line in any list of creditor demands, he said. Trump has a 30-day grace period to make the payment after Thursday with failure opening up the prospect that the Taj Mahal could be thrown into bankruptcy months after it opened April 2 as Atlantic City's newest and biggest casino. Trump said in a news release Tuesday that the bondholders represented by Rothschild Inc. presented unrealistic demands. ``We saw no point in going forward,'' Trump said. ``Unfortunately this case will be in court for many years to come.'' Trump said numerous bondholders have contacted his New York-based Trump Organization seeking to deal apart from Rothschild Inc. Trump did not elaborate. Calls to the Trump Organization seeking comment were referred to chief financial officer Stephen Bollenbach. Telephone messages left for Bollenbach were not immediately returned. But he was quoted in New York-area newspapers today as saying he believed a compromise deal could still be struck. Ross said bondholders remain united. ``An age-old strategy is to try to divide and conquer your enemy,'' Ross said. He said Trump failed to budge on four bondholder demands - the amount of interest that Trump would pay, whether excess cash in the casino would be earmarked as supplemental interest for bondholders, the amount of equity that Trump would sacrifice in exchange for restructured terms and bondholders' influence over a board of directors. Ross would not be more specific about the negotiating terms, but Trump said in a filing last month with the Securities and Exchange Commission he would offer the bondholders 19.9 percent in the casino. The state Casino Control Commission is scheduled to hold a hearing Dec. 3 on the financial stability of Trump's three casinos, which include the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino and Trump Castle Casino Resort By The Bay. The commission scheduled the financial stability hearing after approving in August a $65 million emergency bank loan to Trump Castle designed to stave off a default at that property. All three casinos have suffered this year along with the entire gaming industry in Atlantic City. Gross gaming revenues at Trump Plaza and Trump Castle plunged after the Taj Mahal opened. The Taj Mahal has posted the city's highest gross gaming revenues since gambling came in 1978. But the mammoth casino, which cost $1 billion to build, has failed to make the $1.3 million a day that analysts said it would need to break even on its debt-financed property. Rothschild represents a steering committee of about 35 percent of the bondholder interests. The steering committee was elected by about 85 percent of the bondholder interests, Ross said.

DOC.HEAD: Reports More Foreign Investors Leave South Korea
DOC.TEXT: More foreign companies have withdrawn from South Korea in the first nine months of this year than in either of the past two years, a government report said Wednesday. The report attributed the development to the nation's economic slowdown and unfavorable labor and management conditions. A Finance Ministry report said 30 foreign firms withdrew in the first nine months this year. The report said 28 foreign investors left South Korea in 1989 and 19 left in 1988. Many of the foreign companies leaving South Korea have sought business in the European Community and East European countries, the report said. It said wage hikes, labor unrest and a structural shift in South Korea's economy following an economic slowdown were responsible.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Parent To Inject $725 Million; 200 More Layoffs Announced
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS cycle designator
DOC.TEXT: CS First Boston Inc. will lay off about 200 workers by the end of the year and surrender majority ownership to the parent of Credit Swisse in a major rescue effort for the struggling investment bank. First Boston will sell $300 million in equity to CS Holding, raising the Swiss company's stake to 60 percent from 44.5 percent. Also, CS will give CS First Boston $425 million in cash for the bulk of its troubled loan portfolio. The weak loans have weighed heavily on its balance sheet and led to a potentially damaging credit rating review. The rescue is the latest fallout from Wall Street's lingering recession that has eliminated tens of thousands of jobs, dried up profitable business sectors and forced major firms to seek help from corporate parents. The deal also marks the first time a foreign company has taken majority control of a major U.S. investment bank. CS First Boston is the parent of First Boston Corp., which had about 3,850 employees at the end of October. ``We want to be certain that the depth of our commitment to CS First Boston is clear and that the strength of our investment banking affiliate is beyond question,'' CS Holding Chairman Rainer S. Gut said in a statement. The bailout by CS Holding is the second this year by the parent of an ailing Wall Street subsidiary. American Express Co. early this year injected $1.3 billion into Shearson Lehman Holdings Inc. and took the company private. The First Boston restructuring rids the firm of the majority of $1.1 billion in temporary ``bridge loans'' made to corporate clients that the firm has been unable to sell because of the collapse of the junk bond market. Under the plan, CS First Boston will place all its bridge loans except for those to Campeau Corp.'s Federated Department Stores subsidiary and to Jerrico Inc. into a special limited partnership. In exchange, CS First Boston will receive a stake in the partnership, which also will contain some equity investments, and the $425 million in cash. The firm still will hold $377 million in the troublesome bridge loans, however. Additionally, CS First Boston announced it was writing off $360 million in soured investments, including the Federated and Jerrico bridge loans and some real estate, venture capital and leveraged buyout investments. That action is expected to reduce the firm's 1990 earnings. First Boston made just $11 million last year and reportedly has losses so far this year. Wall Street analysts said the moves were favorable and could head off a potential downgrade in First Boston's credit rating, which would make the firm's daily borrowing requirements more costly. ``The closer relationship with CS Holding and the strenghtening of the financial structure are positive steps,'' said John J. Kriz, a vice president with Moody's Investors Service Inc., a major credit rating agency. Moody's several weeks ago placed First Boston's credit rating under review. Kriz said Moody's would evaluate the rating in light of the recapitalization plan. The 200 layoffs are in addition to about 100 firings in recent weeks in the firm's stock and operations departments. By the end of the year, First Boston will have reduced its total U.S. employment by nearly 8 percent. The company employs 5,800 people worldwide. The firm was taken private in 1988 in a merger between First Boston and its European affiliate. But it fell on hard times last year, particularly because of the collapse in the market for junk bonds, the high-yield securities in which the company was a major player.

DOC.HEAD: Germany Announces Plans for Defense Spending Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to CLARIFY that what was announced were budget outlines, not final budget; move tax proposal higher; edits throughout to conform.
DOC.TEXT: The German government on Wednesday announced plans to cut defense spending by 2.5 billion marks, or $1.7 billion, next year and impose no new taxes in the first budget of united Germany. Partial budget proposals, approved by the conservative Cabinet on Wednesday and outlined by Finance Minister Theo Waigel, also called for setting a federal deficit cap of 70 billion marks, or $47 billion, for 1991 and reducing the federal deficit to 30 billion marks, or $20 billion, by 1994. The 1990 federal deficit was 66.8 billion marks, or $45 billion. A detailed budget is expected to be presented to the new unified German government next spring. The partial proposal did not give an overall spending figure for the united country, but Waigel said he expected spending to be no more than 2 percent higher than the combined 1990 budgets of East and West Germany. Officials said the two countries had total budgets of 396 billion marks, or about $265 billion, before they unified on Oct. 3. Waigel said he did not expect there would be tax increases. ``If decisive measures are taken, tax increases will not be necessary,'' Waigel said. ``It would be counterproductive to take measures that weaken the German economy.'' The two German governments spent about 57 billion marks, or $38 billion, on defense in 1990, an official in the finance ministry said. The 1991 cuts of 2.5 billion marks would represent a 4 percent reduction in defense spending. Earlier in the week, Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg outlined plans to cut Germany's armed forces to 370,000 from about 525,000 over the next four years. Germany agreed to the troop reduction in exchange for the Soviet Union's blessing of united Germany's continued NATO membership and the gradual withdrawal of Soviet troops from former East German territory. Waigel told reporters the government expected the economy to grow 3 percent to 3.5 percent in what used to be West Germany in 1991. He said projected growth for a united Germany in 1991 would be 2 percent to 3 percent. Inflation was expected to run about 3 percent next year, but could decline to 2.5 percent, Waigel added. Western states must show solidarity and bear more of the cost of German unity, the minister added. Living and industrial standards in the five new eastern German states created after Oct. 3 unification were devastated by 40 years of communist central planning and neglect. The 1991 budget plans call for the federal government to spend 74 billion marks, or $50 billion, and the western states an additional 3 billion marks, or $2 billion, on unification costs. Waigel said the federal and western state governments had spent 46 billion marks, or $31 billion, on unification in 1990. Waigel said it was impossible to predict how the budget might be affected if war breaks out in the Persian Gulf. Germany's constitution prohibits it from sending soldiers to non-NATO countries. But Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Stoltenberg both favor changing the constitution to allow German troops to take part in U.N. actions. Kohl says the new Parliament, to be elected Dec. 2, will consider the matter.

The stock market edged upward today as traders kept a wary eye on interest rates and oil prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 6.18 points to 2,541.58 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. DOC.HEAD: EC Commission Proposes Cancelling Developing Nations' Debt to EC
DOC.TEXT: The European Community Commission on Wednesday proposed to cancel $4.3 billion in debt that 69 developing nations owe the European Community as a whole. The debt, worth 3.1 billion European currency units, is owed by African, Caribbean and Pacific nations that have special trade ties with the EC. EC Development Commissioner Manual Marin said his debt cancellation proposal ``does not cover bilateral debt,'' between the ACP and the 12 EC states but between the ACP nations and the Community as a whole. The ACP nations are mostly former European colonies. Their debt to the EC stems from special loans and risk capital the EC has granted through trade and aid treaties over the past 15 years. Marin said his proposal for debt cancellation would be ``a new political signal'' of the Community's willingness to help some of the world's poorest nations. While some have a poor record in repaying debts to individual donor nations, Marin said the ACP nations have always paid back their debts to the Community. His called his proposal for a blanket cancellation of debt ``an overall gesture'' of goodwill to developing nations regardless of their human rights records or efforts to overhaul their economies. Linking debt cancellation to respect for human rights, he said, ``was a delicate matter'' that was not for the EC Commision to decide, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Grains and Soybeans Open Lower
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices slid today for the fourth consecutive session, hitting new near-term contract lows today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Grain prices also plunged. Traders say followthrough selling from yesterday's poor close will pressure futures throughout the day. Corn, soybean and wheat prices are all suffering from near-record harvests and little export demand, and prices have slumped as speculators move to the sidelines waiting for activity. Soybeans also have been hurt by a government report issued last week that found a higher than expected supply of the crop than was previously expected. Soybeans could gather some support today, however, from Taiwan's reported purchase of 20 thousand tons of the crop and rumors that Israel and Mexico also may be in the market. In early trading, wheat futures were 5{ cents to 3{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.58 a bushel; corn futures were 1} cents to { cent lower with December at $2.28 a bushel; oats were 3\ cents to 2} cents lower with December at $1.09{ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 4{ cents lower with November at $5.58{ a bushel. Wheat settled Tuesday 3 cents to { cent lower with December at $2.63 a bushel; corn settled 1 cent to { cent lower with December at $2.30\ a bushel; oats settled 3\ cents to 2\ cents lower with December at $1.12\ a bushel; soybeans settled 10} cents to 3} cents lower with November at $5.63 a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle settled .15 cent to .28 cent higher with December at 88.35 cents a pound; feeder cattle was .15 cent to .28 cent higher with November at 88.35 cents a pound; hogs were .13 cent to .73 cent higher with December at 54.10 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .90 cent to 1.50 cents higher with February at 73.07 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Former Shop Teacher Turns Hobby Shop Into Big Business
DOC.TEXT: Gerrard W. Haworth was a high school shop instructor with a hobby shop on the side when he was turned down for a bank loan to start a wood products business. That was in 1948. It was probably one of the few setbacks Haworth encountered in his business venture. And even that one was temporary; his parents wound up lending him the $10,000 needed to get started. Today, Haworth Inc. is a global office furniture company with worldwide sales that approached $550 million in 1989, 4,200 employees and 370 dealers. ``Sometimes I have to pinch myself to realize how far we've come,'' said the spry 79-year-old Haworth, who remains the company's chairman. ``It all started as a little hobby shop on the side; I bought a few tools and started building this and that in my spare time.'' Among his spare-time projects was a request from a Philadelphia client to build wood dividers for an office - a new concept at the time, and one that has revolutionized the layout of offices around the country. Office partitions were the focus of Haworth's business until 1975, when he sold the $10 million business, Modern Products Inc., and son Richard helped transform the family company into a full-line office furniture supplier. From 1978-88, the company grew at more than twice the industry's rate, with sales increasing annually, anywhere from 20 percent to 60 percent. ``A few years before my father died, I took him to this 600,000-square-foot building we had built here and he took it all in and said, `Gerry, why do you want to get so big?''' the elder Haworth recalled. ``I said, `Dad, I don't know how to control it.''' Indeed, growth at Haworth has been practically uncontrollable since 1976, when the company introduced a pre-wired office panel. It further revolutionized office design by eliminating the need for new electrical wiring or extension cords every time an office was created or altered. ``The electrified panel put them on the map. People went nuts for it,'' said Alan Zimmerman, president of Radley Resources, a Westfield, N.J., marketing and consulting firm. ``To start from nothing and suddenly have a half-billion-dollar company is incredible.'' Despite its success, Haworth kept a relatively low profile in the industry until five years ago, when it accused industry leader Steelcase Inc. of Grand Rapids of stealing the technology for the patented panel. After a prolonged court fight, Haworth won. The two sides now are negotiating what Haworth is owed, and analysts say the figure may be in the tens of millions. The company is facing off with another competitor that's threatening its No. 3 spot in the industry. Westinghouse Electric Corp.'s Kentwood-based furniture division went on a buying spree this year, snapping up several companies, including Knoll International of New York. The acquisitions are expected to boost Westinghouse's furniture sales to about $600 million, which is what Haworth is predicting for 1990. ``I don't really consider ourselves out of the No. 3 slot, though we don't have the clarity of being there that we had before,'' said Richard Haworth, president and chief executive officer. ``But I don't really think that's the point. The point is that we can still provide better quality and service.'' Still, Haworth isn't sitting back. The company has made several recent purchases of smaller companies and product lines and says it still is looking toward more expansion, especially in Europe. And like the company that bears his name, the elder Haworth says he has no plans to slow down. ``When people ask, `Gerry, why don't you hang it up?' I laugh. I started this business as a hobby, why shouldn't I continue it has a hobby?'' said Haworth, who traded his teaching job at the local high school for a chance to start a business and better support his wife and four children. He remains keenly interested in the education field. He recently donated $5 million for a new business college at his alma mater, Western Michigan University in Kalamazoo. The building, which will open in January, will be called the Haworth College of Business. A mild-mannered man with an easy smile that shaves at least 10 years off his age, Haworth has a paternalistic quality and commands respect as he addresses new employees - called ``members'' - at the start of a two-week orientation at the company's headquarters. One of the first to arrive for the 7:30 a.m. session, Haworth makes sure the groggy-eyed trainees are well-acquainted with the ``Haworth Creed:'' The customer comes first. ``You are the ones on the front line. The first impressions you make with the customers are the lasting ones,'' said Haworth, a bespectacled man with a receding white hairline. He speaks for just a few minutes before giving the floor to his son, who closely resembles his father in appearance and personality, but with a slightly harder edge. ``I think it's great having dad talk to them (the employees),'' the younger Haworth said. ``It adds a feeling of stability ... and I think they sense he really does care.''

DOC.HEAD: Australian Air Leasing Company Orders $150 Million in Planes
DOC.TEXT: Ansett Worldwide Aviation Services has ordered five more Boeing 737-500 airliners, worth about $150 million, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group announced Wednesday. Two of the five aircraft were delivered last week, one to Europe Aero Service, a French carrier, and the other to Balkan Bulgarian Airlines. Ansett Worldwide, an Australian leasing company, has now announced orders for 86 Boeing jetliners including 55 737s, 22 757s and nine 767s. For the year, Boeing has announced orders for 460 aircraft, with an appoximate value of $41.5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Sentencing Put Off Until Next Week
DOC.TEXT: Sentencing of former junk bond financier Michael Milken will take place next week, a clerk for U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood said Wednesday. The sentencing was expected to take place this week. No reason for the delay was given. A specific date and time for the sentencing was not announced. Milken, 44, the former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s high-yield bond department, faces up to 28 years in prison for his guilty plea to six felony counts of conspiracy and fraud related to illegal securities trading. Prosecutors are seeking a stiff prison sentence. Milken and his attorneys have asked the judge for a term of community service. Sentencing initially was scheduled for Oct. 1 but was delayed for a hearing into additional government allegations against Milken. Milken did not testify at the hearing but submitted a lengthy letter to the judge accepting responsibility for his crimes but requesting lenience.

DOC.HEAD: P&G Employee Stock Plan Financing for Retirees
DOC.TEXT: The Procter & Gamble Co. said Monday its Leveraged Employee Stock Ownership Plan will borrow as much as $1 billion to buy P&G stock to help pay retiree medical benefits. P&G will guarantee the 30-year loan, which will be used to buy a special issue of convertible preferred stock with earnings devoted to retirees' benefits, P&G spokesman Patrick Hayes said. P&G said prices and terms of the preferred stock have not been set. P&G's board of directors has authorized using proceeds from the preferred stock issue to buy back common stock and offset dilution of its outstanding shares, the company said. The LESOP was created in March 1989 with a $1 billion, 15-year loan that was used to buy convertible preferred stock from the company.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls in Europe, Gold Rises
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with end of trading in Europe, NY midday quotes
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined against most major currencies in European trading today, pressured by worries about the U.S. economy. Gold prices rose. In London, the pound was weakened by internal political pressure on British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, as former Defense Minister Michael Heseltine announced he will challenge her for the leadership of the Conservative Party. Sterling fell to $1.9615 from $1.9640 late Tuesday. In New York at midday, the pound was quoted at $1.9588. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.28 yen to a closing 129.05 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 129.52 yen and in New York at midday, it was quoted at 129.92 yen. DOC.HEAD: Mouse Maker Z-Nix Settles Suit Against Software Giant Microsoft
DOC.TEXT: Z-Nix Co., a small personal computer accessory maker, has settled its lawsuit accusing PC giant Microsoft of restraint of trade and breach of contract. Under terms of the settlement, Microsoft will license Z-Nix to use Microsoft's Windows software through 1991. It will then negotiate a renewal with Z-Nix. In announcing the settlement Monday, neither company revealed details. Z-Nix, based in Poona, makes the point-and-click computer control devices known as mice. It filed the $4.5 million suit in Los Angeles federal court last week. The suit alleged that Microsoft unfairly doubled its $27.50-per-copy charge for Windows when Z-Nix wanted to pair the software with its own mouse device.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Shares closed lower on London's Stock Exchange Wednesday as investors assessed the news that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is being challenged as leader of the governing Conservative Party. Former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine said he will challenge Mrs. Thatcher in a ballot among Conservative legislators Tuesday. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell 10 points, or 0.5 percent, to close at 2,046.0. The Financial Times 300-share index was down 10.4 points at 1,583.2. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 5.88 points to close at 1,086.64. Volume was 356.5 million shares, off from 422.9 million shares Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: GE, Thorn Form New Lamp Company
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co. and Thorn EMI PLC are forming a new lighting company in the United Kingdom, the companies announced Wednesday. GE will hold a 51 percent interest and take management control of the new company, GE-Thorn Lamps Ltd. The two organizations will collaborate on lamp marketing and distribution, and after three years Thorn EMI's minority interest will transfer to GE. Under the agreement, which is subject to regulatory approval, GE will also buy Thorn Lighting's principal light source interests outside the United Kingdom. GE will acquire Thorn's British manufacturing plants at Enfield, Leicester, Mitcham and New Malden to form the new company. GE will also acquire Thorn's 100 percent interest in Gluhlampenfabrik Jahn in Germany and Thorn's 51 percent investment in Sivi Illuminazione in Italy. Thorn will retain facilities at Merthyr, Preston and Rodney, Great Britain. Colin Southgate, Thorn's chairman and chief executive, said the alliance is a good match. ``GE is a world leader in light sources, while our strengths are in fittings,'' Southgate said. ``This alliance will allow Thorn Lighting to concentrate its resources and energies on designing, manufacturing and marketing innovative fittings for world markets.'' Said John D. Opie, GE senior vice president: ``We view this as a teaming of two businesses that are highly regarded in their fields.'' GE, which operates 13 businesses including lighting, had revenues of $55 billion and net earnings of nearly $4 billion last year. Thorn, based in the United Kingdom with operations in 43 countries, had revenues of more than $7.4 billion in its 1989-90 fiscal year.

DOC.HEAD: Intermittent Windshield Wiper Inventor Settles with Ford for $10.2 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 5th graf pvs, Durkee said, with comment from Kearns. Picks up 6th graf pvs, Kearns, 63. Similar version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Robert Kearns, who owns the patent for intermittent windshield wipers, today settled a 12-year-old lawsuit against Ford Motor Co. for $10.2 million. U.S. District Judge Avern Cohn approved the settlement after spending most of a 20-minute court hearing making sure Kearns understood terms of the deal. Kearns' lawsuits against 19 other automakers remain active. He contends that each failed to pay him royalties for using his invention - a windhield wiper that starts and stops at intervals. Bill Durkee, Kearns' attorney, said the next target probably will be Chrysler Corp. The nation's No. 3 automaker behind General Motors Corp. and Ford has agreed not to argue about whether Kearns' patents are valid, a contention that had been argued during the suit against Ford. Durkee said he would have liked to continue the case against Ford, but, ``As a practical matter, with all the other cases pending, there was a logjam. ``When you step back and look at all this, sometimes it's better to get on with other things,'' he said. Said Kearns: ``I don't think the goal was the magnitude of the money. What I saw my role was to defend the patent system,'' said Kearns. ``If I don't go further, there really isn't a patent system.'' Kearns, 63, and a former resident of Gaithersburg, Md., now lives in a one-bedroom rented apartment in Houston, Texas. He is a former engineering professor at Wayne State University in Detroit. He said he planned to use the money to pay legal bills and, perhaps, buy a house in Texas. He also said proceeds from the Ford case would be used in lawsuits against the other defendants, including GM, Chrysler and Japanese and European automakers. Durkee said preliminary work still needed to be done in many of the cases, all pending before Cohn. Ford attorney Malcolm Wheeler said the company had resolved all disputes with Kearns. ``We're pleased to be done with the litigation,'' he said. ``We still believe that if we had another shot at it, the patents would have been held invalid. We think this is an extremely reasonable settlement.'' Originally, Kearns sought $141 million and had rejected a $30 million settlement offer from Ford. Last July, after one mistrial, a federal jury ordered Ford to pay $5.2 million plus interest, which pushed the award to between $8.5 million and $11.5 million. By the end of this week, Durkee said a $10.2 million check in Kearns' name will be put in an escrow account to which Kearns would have immediate access.

DOC.HEAD: Acura's `Little Ferrari': An Eye- and Money-Catcher
DOC.TEXT: While some car buyers are drawn to big rebates, others can't resist paying $40,000 over list price for a new set of wheels. The Acura NSX is commanding that kind of money from those who want an exotic car without a Ferrari or Lamborghini price tag. ``It's a bargain,'' said sales manager Betsy Volaric of Sunshine Acura in Farmington Hills. The NSX, which looks a bit like a shrunken Ferrari Testarosa, carries a list price of $60,000 with a manual transmission and $63,000 for one with an automatic. But since Acura, the luxury division of Honda Motor Co. Ltd. of Japan, plans to import just 3,000 of them a year, demand is far outpacing supply. That pumps up the price. Premiums on cars are nothing new to the auto industry. Last year, buyers shelled out up to $25,000 for the hard-to-get Mazda Miata, which carried a base price of $13,800. Volaric said her dealership, one of 300 Acura dealers in the country, is tacking $20,000 to $25,000 onto the price of the NSX, because that's what the market will bear. ``Anybody who is familiar with the exotic car market realizes that $85,000 is a bargain,'' she said. Ferraris and Lamborghinis begin at more than $100,000 and stretch past $300,000 each, before any premium. Acura spokesman Mike Spencer said dealers in markets with high exotic-car interest, such as Los Angeles and Miami, are getting up to $100,000 for an NSX - $40,000 over sticker price. ``Legally, we can't tell the dealers what to sell the cars for,'' he said. ``At the same time, they look at this as `Geez, if Isell the car to a speculator for $60,000 and he turns around and sells it for $80,000 to $90,000, who's the fool here?''' A fool has no place behind the wheel of an NSX. The sleek, two-seater packs a 3-liter, V-6 engine which puts out 270 horsepower. It's top speed is rated around 165 mph, and it can go from a standing start to 60 mph in about 5.5 seconds. Tooling around Detroit freeways in an NSX causes normally vacant highway stares to come alive. Even at highway speeds, motorists hover around the NSX for a closer look. In a recent test drive: -The driver of a Mazda RX-7 on the right looked for a minute, dropped back for a different view, came up on the left for another peek and moved to the front to take a look at the NSX in his rearview mirror. Afterwards, he dropped back to the right, nodded his head up and down vigorously and flashed a thumbs-up sign. -A load of what appeared to be teen-agers in an Oldsmobile pulled alongside and accelerated, appearing to dare a highway race. The NSX is a conspicuous car and the offer was ignored. Parked at a local mall, the car was a magnet for nearly everyone who walked by, including car crazies and store clerks. ``I thought it was a Ferrari,'' said Denise DiDonato, of Rochester Hills, a cosmetics clerk at Saks Fifth Avenue in a suburban Detroit shopping mall. ``It's cute, very cute.'' She owns a 1990 Lincoln Town Car - 56.8 inches longer and 1,000 pounds heavier than an NSX. Kevin Corcoran, of Franklin, could have been doing an advertisement for the car: ``It's extraordinarily flashy and reasonably priced as far as these things go. There's a lot of Italian in it.'' Corcoran owns a pickup, in which he spends most of his highway time, and a McLaren, an extremely low-volume exotic sports car. With a target volume of 3,000 annually, the NSX doesn't pose a significant volume threat to any car now being sold in the United States. It's priced somewhere around a Porsche 911, the Mercedes-Benz 300-series, a BMW 7-series or a Chevrolet Corvette ZR-1, the hottest car made by a major American manufacturer. The NSX doesn't look nearly as muscular as the ZR-1, and it isn't. The ZR-1's 5.7-liter, V-8 engine produces 375 horsepower, nearly 30 percent more than the NSX. The all-aluminum NSX makes up for some of that difference in weight, coming in at 3,010 pounds compared with the ZR-1 at 3,465 pounds. Canadian visitor Craig Donnelly is an NSX fan. He said he had a poster of a black one back home in Ottawa, where he also has a Pontiac Sunbird. ``It's got the same size engine as that,'' he said nodding to the NSX, ``but it doesn't go like that.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday, Nov. 18

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Europe Still At Loggerheads over Farm Subsidies
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Wednesday the United States would not budge on its demand for sharp cuts in agricultural subsidies in the current round of world trade talks. At a joint news conference with Yeutter, U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said agriculture was the key to resolving the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Mrs. Hills said quick progress was possible only if the European Community showed the political will to achieve it. But she doubted whether negotiators could have a deal ready for signing by the end of the weeklong meeting, which begins in Brussels on Dec. 3. However, an American official in Brussels told reporters that the United States has no intention of walking out of the talks, despite the acrimonious dispute with the European Community. ``We want to keep at this. It is important. Even if the prospects are unpromising ... you soldier on,'' said the official, who demanded anonymity. ``I don't think the United States would be the first to walk away from the table and I think we would discourage others from walking away,'' he said. The United States has asked its trading partners to slash farm income supports by 75 percent and export subsidies by 90 percent over a 10-year period, starting in 1991. The United States hopes that lowering trade barriers will enable its farmers to sell more goods on the world market. Other farm-exporting countries, like Argentina and Australia, also would like a chance to export more. The European Community, however, contends it needs its vast network of agriculture supports to protect its farm community of some 10 million farmers, many of whom have small operations. The EC has suggested trimming subsidies on major farm crops by 30 percent over 10 years, retroactive to 1986. It has made no promises to reduce export subsidies. Yeutter said the Europeans have already cut about half of the offered 30 percent, reducing their actual offer to a 15 percent cut. Yeutter, who is visiting European capitals in search of a compromise, said he has encountered a view among Europeans that the United States will back down on its demands. ``That is a dangerous impression and one that is doomed to be incorrect,'' Yeutter said. German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann said after a meeting with Yeutter that Germany hoped the talks could proceed on technical questions despite the agriculture impasse. But Yeutter said the heart of the issue must be addressed. Hills said many of the 105 nations involved in the Uruguay Round will not be interested in making progress in other areas of the talks, such as intellectual property or services, if they do not achieve progress in the agricultural talks. Hills, U.S. Secretary of States James A. Baker III and Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher will travel to Brussels for another set of talks on Friday. Top EC officials were in Washington earlier in the week to address the dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Nike Names Ad Agency to Develop Minority Campaign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS name of group to `Operation PUSH' in 5th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Nike Inc., targeted for a boycott by a civil rights group, named the Muse Cordero Chen agency to develop a minority-oriented advertising campaign. The Beaverton, Ore., shoemaker said Tuesday that Muse Cordero Chen will be assigned to Nike's ``Just Do It'' corporate campaign and its ``Stay In School'' public affairs program. Muse Cordero Chen will work with Nike's ad agency, Wieden & Kennedy of Portland, Ore. Muse Cordero is based in Los Angeles and specializes in creating marketing campaigns aimed at blacks, Hispanics and Asians. Its clients have included Honda, the U.S. Census Bureau, Southern California Gas Co. and Home Savings of America. Ken Smikle, president of the African American Marketing & Media Association, a Chicago trade group, said Nike's move appeared to be motivated by a boycott led by Operation PUSH, the civil rights group founded by the Rev. Jesse Jackson. ``After months of denial, Nike has admitted that it can use the expertise of minority marketers,'' Smikle said. ``The major concern that we have is that they be given a significant account - one that involves product advertising.'' But Nike spokeswoman Liz Dolan said the search for an agency to handle a minority campaign started two years ago and was not inspired by the boycott. Dolan said the boycott ``made us aware that a multi-ethnic agency is what we were looking for. Our thinking changed from just looking for a Hispanic agency to one that could do Hispanic, African American and Asian'' ads. Agency President J. Melvin Muse said his firm has not place a dollar value on the Nike account. The agency handles about $16 million in ad spending a year.

DOC.HEAD: Grains and Soybeans Prices Tumble
DOC.TEXT: Grains and soybeans futures prices fell for the fourth consecutive session Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as speculators fretted over abundant supplies and poor demand. Follow-through selling from Tuesday's poor close pressured futures throughout the day as commercial firms cashed in, in light of good harvesting weather in regions where the crops are grown. Corn, soybeans and wheat are all suffering from near-record harvests and little export demand, and prices have slumped as speculators move to the sidelines waiting for activity. ``We haven't seen any things confirmed in terms of export activity,'' said Mark Weidner, an analyst for Cargill Investor Services Inc. ``Without confirmation or seeing shipments going out, rumors of activity will be just that and we'll continue to see falling prices.'' Soybeans also have suffered from a government report issued last week that found a higher than expected supply of the crop than was previously expected. Reports of Taiwan's purchase of 20,000 tons of the crop and talk that Israel and Mexico also may be in the market failed to slow the future's slide. At the close, wheat futures were 7} cents to 6 cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.55\ a bushel; corn futures were 6\ cents to 4{ cents lower with December at $2.24 a bushel; oats were 5\ cents to 2\ cents lower with December at $1.08 a bushel; soybeans were 10 cents to 5} cents lower with November at $5.54\ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: MCA Stock Jumps In Wake of Report of Intensified Talks with Matsushita
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be updated with closing stock price.
DOC.TEXT: MCA Inc. stock climbed Wednesday after a published report suggested talks are intensifying over the possibility that Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. will make a definitive bid to acquire the entertainment company. MCA and Matsushita confirmed in September they were in talks about a buyout and there was speculation the Japanese electronics manufacturer would offer about $85 a share for MCA, owner of Universal Pictures and Universal Television. In trading late Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange, MCA was up $4.25 a share at $62.50. The Wall Street Journal reported that officials of MCA and Matsushita have scheduled talks for Monday and hope to agree within days on terms of a buyout. A spokeswoman for MCA in Universal City, Calif., said the company had no comment on the report; a spokesman for Matsushita failed to return a phone call. With about 92 million shares outstanding, a bid of $85 a share would value MCA at about $7.8 billion. The Journal story said that a specific price is still up for negotiation, and it cautioned that there is no certainty that a deal will be negotiated or that the timetable will be followed. If a deal were worked out, it would be the latest example of foreign ownership of a major American movie studio. In the biggest such deal to date, Japan's Sony Corp. bought Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. last year for $3.4 billion plus debt that raised the total value of the deal to about $5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Toy Retailers In Guessing Game On Holiday Spending
With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: ``Christmas was on its way, lovely, glorious, beautiful Christmas, around which the entire kid year revolved.'' That was how humorist Jean Shepherd summed up the holiday season in the 1983 film ``A Christmas Story,'' the tale of a little boy's quest for the Christmas present of his dreams, an air rifle. And so it is for millions of children - Christmas is the high point of their year. But this Christmas is a difficult one for many of their parents, who are concerned about the economy and the Middle East and have less money to spend on toys. Consumers are in a quandry, caught between financial restraints and wanting to fulfill their children's Christmas wishes. Toy retailers and manufacturers already have felt the pinch. Toys R Us Inc., the nation's biggest toy retailer, suffered a slump in sales after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August that mirrored the drop-off in business throughout the retail industry. Robert Nakasone, a Toys R Us vice chairman, acknowledged that these are uncertain times, but he expected a merry Christmas nonetheless. ``People may cut back for durables ... but when it comes down to your kid at Christmas, it's pretty hard to say no to them,'' he said. Even in relatively poor economic years, he said, Toys R Us has had some of its best holiday seasons. In 1982, in the midst of the country's last recession, toy sales for the entire industry rose 13 percent. But some industry analysts were not as sanguine. Daniel Barry, of Kidder Peabody & Co., said toy sales could slip along with other merchandise sales this season. Retailers and manufacturers are concerned because even one less toy under a Christmas tree, when multiplied by the more than 60 million children age 16 and under in the country, can make for a poor Christmas season. Perhaps the most sensitive area is video games, which again are on many wish lists this Christmas. Retailers and video game manufacturers face several unknowns. Given the uncertain business environment, no one is sure how many parents are willing to invest big on Nintendo and other more expensive video systems. The biggest question is whether the new systems, which offer more advanced technology and more sophisticated graphics and sound effects than Nintendo, can take market share from the industry leader. Children who have tired of Nintendo games - or whose Nintendo systems have worn out - are asking for the new units, known as 16-bit systems. A bit is the smallest unit of information in a computer, and 16-bit systems can process more information and instructions than eight-bit systems like Nintendo. The 16-bit systems, which include NEC Corp.'s TurboGrafx-16 and Sega's Genesis, must overcome a big obstacle - their price. The basic Genesis unit has a list price of $189.95, while the basic TurboGrafx-16 goes for $159. Those prices don't include game cartridges, which can run $50 or more apiece. In comparison, Nintendo looks like a bargain. Its basic unit can be found for under $100 in many stores, and many of its cartridges sell at a discount because there is a glut of them on the market. Nintendo's hand-held model, Game Boy, also has a price edge over its new competitor, NEC's TurboExpress. Game Boy has a list price of $100 while TurboExpress lists for $249. It all comes down to how much parents want to indulge their children and how much they can and want to spend. Manufacturers say they already are feeling the effects of a cautious consumer. ``In a normal year, retailers in October would purchase enough to take them all the way through Christmas,'' said Ken Wirt, NEC's vice president for home entertainment. But this year, he said, storeowners so far have ordered enough merchandise to last them only through the Thanksgiving weekend. Paul Valentine, an analyst with Standard & Poor's Corp., said manufacturers of traditional toys, such as dolls and action figures, have had similar experiences. ``The turmoil in the retail industry has definitely had an impact on the toy industry,'' he said. But some traditional toys are expected to be sure winners this season, analysts say. Children's love affair with Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles is continuing, so the Playmates Toys Inc. action figures and their spinoffs, which include videos, books, clothes, watches and games, should do well. The Simpsons are expected to be found in varying forms under plenty of Christmas trees. Manufacturers have licenses from the producers of the popular television series for a range of merchandise including dolls and plastic figures. Dolls based on the rock group New Kids on the Block have been selling well ever since their introduction earlier this year by Hasbro Inc., and they're expected to be a hit again at Christmas. Barbie, Mattel Inc.'s long-reigning queen of toys, continues to dominate the doll business, with new outfits, a swimming pool and her own Corvette among the offerings. Meanwhile, there's been an explosion of baby and toddler dolls as that segment continues to thrive. A parent shopping in a well-stocked toy department or store may dozens of dolls to choose from, with most ranging from $20 to about $60. There are dolls that drink, wet their diapers, fall down, cry, shiver or take baths, and dolls that can be dressed up, made up or have their hair dyed. The toy companies have tried to outdo one another in making their dolls stand out. Hasbro created Baby Uh-Oh, which soils its diapers after it has been fed. The idea turns some adults off, but little girls love it and the dolls have been selling well, according to Valentine. Another toymaker, Ideal, has aimed straight for mothers' heartstrings by bringing back some of the most popular dolls from 30 years ago: Betsy Wetsy, one of the drink-and-wet dolls of the early 1960s, and Tiny Tears, who weeps having her bottle. Besides video games and Ninja Turtles and other action figures, boys are expected to receive toys based on Hulk Hogan and other wrestling stars. Standard & Poor's Valentine said Tonka Inc.'s Wrestling Buddies and Hasbro's World Wrestling Federation figures have sold well.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday, Nov. 18

DOC.HEAD: Reorganized Pharmaceutical Company Posts $24 Million Net Income
DOC.TEXT: Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc., the newly created pharmaceutical giant, on Wednesday reported third-quarter net income of $24 million, or 36 cents a share, on sales of $838 million. The company resulted from the merger of Rhone-Poulenc's human pharmaceutical businesses and Rorer Group Inc., which was completed July 31. Rorer alone made $19.6 million on $260 million in sales in the third quarter of 1989. Net income included a pre-tax gain of $23 million from the sale of assets. Including Rhone-Poulenc's human pharmaceuticals business from the third quarter last year, the new company's sales for this quarter were up 21 percent and income was up 33 percent, the company said. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange rates, sales grew 6.4 percent. ``Our new organization structure is firmly in place and activities are under way to consolidate and streamline operations worldwide,'' said Robert E. Cawthorn, the company's chairman, president and chief executive officer. ``In addition, we have fully integrated research and development activities,'' he said. ``Financially, our objective remains to at least break even in 1990 in spite of the exceptional restructuring charges.'' For the first nine months, the company reported a net loss of $162 million after pre-tax restructuring and special charges of $289 million in the first half of the year. Sales for the first nine months were $1.8 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Woolworth Earnings Up; Toys R Us Profits Flat
With AM-Retail Sales, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Woolworth Corp. said Wednesday its third-quarter earnings rose 14 percent and Toys R Us Inc. reported its profits were flat as both retailers were adversely affected by the slowdown in consumer spending. Woolworth fared better than several other retailers who reported their earnings fell as sales slumped during the third quarter. But the company said it got a boost in part from gains in earnings from its overseas operations. U.S. consumers, who were already spending cautiously because of the faltering economy, sharply curtailed their purchases of clothing, furniture, toys and appliances after the Middle East crisis erupted and sent oil prices sharply higher. May Department Stores Co. and J.C. Penney Co. Inc. reported Tuesday their third-quarter earnings fell because of sluggish sales. Retailers and industry analysts expect consumers to spend conservatively even during the Christmas shopping season. That could spell trouble for the storeowners, who depend on holiday sales for half their annual profits.
DOC.HEAD: F.W. Woolworth Corp.
DOC.TEXT: Woolworth said it earned $80 million, or 62 cents per share, in the quarter ended Oct. 27, up 14 percent from $70 million, or 54 cents per share, in the same period a year ago. Revenue rose to $2.47 billion from $2.17 billion. Woolworth reported declines in its general merchandise sales in the United States, but said these were offset by gains in its Kinney shoe division in this country and in its European stores. For the first nine months, Woolworth reported earnings of $168 million, or $1.30 per share, up from $154 million, or $1.19 per share, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $6.73 billion from $6.03 billion. Besides its Woolworth general merchandise stores, the company operates specialty stores including Foot Locker and Lady Foot Locker sportwear stores and Kinney shoe stores.

Toys R Us said it earned nearly $28.73 million, or 10 cents per share, in the quarter ended Oct. 28, compared with $28.69 million, or 10 cents per share, in the same quarter of 1989. Sales at the nation's biggest toy retailer totaled $1.05 billion, up from $916.2 million. The company's sales, especially at its Kids R Us children's clothing stores, stalled after the Persian Gulf crisis began. However, toy retailers are expected to fare somewhat better than general merchandise and apparel retailers during the Christmas season. Toys R Us said it earned $88.4 million, or 30 cents per share, in the first nine months of the year, up from $79.3 million, or 27 cents per share, in the same period a year earlier. Sales totaled $2.96 billion, up from $2.46 billion. The company has 451 toy stores in the United States, 98 in other countries and 164 clothing stores.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Credit System Shows Sharp Profit Drop
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RESTORES `million' in 3rd graf after $132 and $494
DOC.TEXT: The Farm Credit System, the federally chartered cooperative banking network that provides most of the nation's agricultural loans, reported Wednesday a 41 percent drop in third-quarter earnings. Net income for the quarter ended Sept. 30 totaled $93 million, down from $158 million in the comparable period a year ago. For the first nine months of 1990, the system earned $455 million, compared with $514 million a year earlier. Income before an extraordinary loss related to a repurchase of debt totaled $132 million in the current quarter, and $494 million during the nine-month period. The system reported net interest income of $288 million in the quarter, up from $236 million last year. But the improvement was offset by a reduction in the negative provision for loan losses. The provision was $4 million, compared to $76 million in last year's third quarter. The system is cooperatively owned by its farm borrowers and is made up of 37 regional banks that issue operating and mortgage loans through local land bank associations and production credit associations.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Deletes extraneous 3rd and 4th grafs.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market climbed to an eight-week high Wednesday, resuming its recent rally with encouragement from falling oil prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 24.25 points to 2,559.65, its highest close since it stood at 2,571.29 on Sept. 18. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by more than 9 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 999 up, 532 down and 473 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 179.31 million shares, up from 160.24 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 214.70 million shares. The price of crude oil for December delivery dropped almost $2 a barrel, to $31.16 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices of many other commodities, which didn't join oil in its summer upsurge, have also been falling of late. That has helped to ease inflation worries on Wall Street, and fueled hopes that the Federal Reserve would see more and more leeway to relax its credit policy. Interest rates have been falling steadily in the credit markets amid expectations of easier credit. Prices of long-term government bonds moved up slightly Wednesday, lowering their yields to the neighborhood of 8.5 percent. Declining interest rates have proved particularly helpful for bank and other financial stocks that had been deeply depressed by credit-crunch fears and worries about a weak real estate market. In the banking group Wednesday, BankAmerica gained | to 23~; Citicorp | to 14; Chase Manhattan [ to 11[; Chemical Banking | to 12], and Manufacturers Hanover { to 19~. Elsewhere in the financial sector, Federal Home Loan Mortgage rose { to 39|; Beneficial Corp. 1~ to 42]; Household International 1{ to 26, and HomeFed } to 7]. Among actively traded blue-chip industrials, International Business Machines rose 1{ to 113{; General Motors ~ to 39~; Philip Morris ] to 48~, and Pepsico ] to 25|. Equifax Inc., which increased the proportion of shares it plans to pay to acquire Telecredit Inc., dropped 1~ to 14]. MCA gained 3 to 65{ on reports suggesting that full agreement might be reached soon on a proposed acquisition by Matsushita Electrical. Matsushita slipped 2} to 126\. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $25.60 billion, or 0.86 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.37 to 174.68. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 3.53 to 375.22, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 2.73 at 320.40.
