DOC.HEAD: Government Alleges Insider Trading By Ex-Philips Executive
DOC.TEXT: Government lawyers charged Wednesday that a former Philips Industries Inc. executive avoided nearly $570,000 in personal losses by selling company stock while he had inside information. Robert H. Brethen, a former Philips vice chairman, is accused of selling the stock when he knew that a proposed leveraged buyout was in jeopardy because of low earnings projections. During opening statements at Brethen's civil trial, Securities and Exchange Commission attorney Jim Tyne said Brethen sold 109,733 shares of Philips stock in January while possessing information about the projections. The SEC sued Brethen in federal court in February. The agency is asking U.S. District Judge Walter Rice to order Brethen to give up the $570,000 plus interest and to pay a $1.7 million penalty. Tyne said Brethen, who retired last December, knew through internal reports that company officials were forecasting lower earnings in the fall of 1989 and that Philips was failing to meet the lower projections. Tyne also said Brethen knew that failure to meet the projections threatened a proposed leveraged buyout of the Dayton-based building and transportation products maker by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners Inc. ``No one outside the company ... knew these projections, and particularly the public didn't know about these projections,'' Tyne said. But David Cupps, Brethen's attorney, said questions about the financing for the buyout as well as changes in Philips' operating costs were included in a public proxy statement filed Dec. 20, 1989. ``That disclosure was not secret,'' he said. Cupps said published reports had stated that banks were backing away from helping to finance the buyout. William McCanna, Philips chief operations officer, testified that Brethen had access to three sales forecasts prepared by the company in October 1989 that were decreasingly optimistic. He said the forecasts were not public. Tyne said Brethen was told by company officials shortly before he retired that Merrill Lynch was disappointed with the company's third-quarter earnings and there could be difficulties arranging bank financing. ``Right after his retirement, he started talking to lawyers about selling his stock,'' Tyne said. Tyne said one attorney told Brethen the information was confidential and another told him he shouldn't sell his stock. ``The evidence will show he was warned not to sell his stock,'' he said. The government alleges Brethen sold 100,000 shares of Philips stock at $22 per share on Jan. 9 and an additional 9,000 shares at $19 per share two days later. At the end of trading that day, Philips announced Merrill Lynch was unable to proceed with the buyout because of Philips' third-quarter earnings. The price of Philips stock fell to $15.50 per share the next day. Tyne said Brethen later told the SEC he sold the stock to pay off some debts, but that evidence shows he had enough assets to cover those obligations. Last August, Philips shareholders approved the acquisition of the company by Tomkins PLC of the United Kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler, Time Warner Agree on Multimedia Marketing Package
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. has signed up for a multimedia marketing package from Time Warner Inc. that will draw upon the media and entertainment giant's far-flung interests in magazines, records, movies, videos and cable TV. Under terms of the deal, Chrysler will tout cars and trucks in multi-page advertising inserts or special issues of magazines such as People, Time and Fortune and in commercials on Time Warner's cable TV systems. Chrysler also will be given the chance to place its products in Warner Bros. films and to offer Warner Bros. records, Time-Life Books and Time-Life videos as premiums in such promotions as getting people to take a test drive. Spokesmen for Chrysler and Time Warner said the program was the biggest marketing package Time Warner has assembled for a single advertiser. Terms of the deal were not disclosed but it was believed to be in the $40 million range covering two years starting in 1991. Diversified media companies such as Time Warner, created last year with Time Inc.'s acquisition of Warner Communications Inc., have often argued that their vast array of media holdings make them more attractive to advertisers. Those capabilities have taken on even more importance in recent months as the advertising market has slumped and media companies scramble to compensate by tailoring programs that suit particular advertiser's needs. While the details of some of Chrysler's plans with Time Warner remain to be worked out, the companies said one of them will involve placing multiple-page inserts in several of Time Warner's magazines each quarter. They said the inserts will carry a ``Rediscover America'' theme marking the approaching celebration of the 500th anniversary of Columbus' discovery of America. In connection with the inserts, Chrysler plans to underwrite referenda on issues such as energy, the environment and education. Both the ad inserts and the referenda should heighten consumer awareness of Chrysler's products, said Tom Jakobowski, a spokesman for Chrsylser.

DOC.HEAD: MCA Stock Jumps In Wake of Report of Intensified Talks with Matsushita
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing stock price in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: MCA Inc. stock climbed Wednesday after a published report suggested talks are intensifying over the possibility that Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. will make a definitive bid to acquire the entertainment company. MCA and Matsushita confirmed in September they were in talks about a buyout and there was speculation the Japanese electronics manufacturer would offer about $85 a share for MCA, owner of Universal Pictures and Universal Television. In trading Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange, MCA rose $3 a share to close at $65.50. The Wall Street Journal reported that officials of MCA and Matsushita have scheduled talks for Monday and hope to agree within days on terms of a buyout. A spokeswoman for MCA in Universal City, Calif., said the company had no comment on the report; a spokesman for Matsushita failed to return a phone call. With about 92 million shares outstanding, a bid of $85 a share would value MCA at about $7.8 billion. The Journal story said that a specific price is still up for negotiation, and it cautioned that there is no certainty that a deal will be negotiated or that the timetable will be followed. If a deal were worked out, it would be the latest example of foreign ownership of a major American movie studio. In the biggest such deal to date, Japan's Sony Corp. bought Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. last year for $3.4 billion plus debt that raised the total value of the deal to about $5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Agency Approves Iroquois Pipeline
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS `state of Connecticut' to `Department of Energy' in 12th graf, Iroquois still. Picks up 13th graf, A Hudson.
DOC.TEXT: A $583 million pipeline that would pump Canadian natural gas to the Northeast won federal approval Wednesday over objections from Hudson Valley and Connecticut property-owners whose land would be crossed. The unanimous decision by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission in favor of the Iroquois pipeline came after four years of debate among environmentalists, homeowners and rival energy suppliers. Opponents included oil wildcatters in the Southwest as well as psychologist Dr. Joyce Brothers, whose Hudson Valley estate would be crossed by the pipeline. But tight energy supplies in New England, New York and New Jersey apparently outweighed environmental arguments and the protests of domestic oil and gas suppliers. ``The gas is needed in the area to be served by Iroquois,'' said FERC Chairman Martin Allday. ``It is my personal goal to get pipe in the ground to serve customers.'' FERC board member Jerry Langdon said the decision would help move the United States toward relying on energy supplies in North America, if not within its own borders. ``Canada is going to play a role in our natural gas supply in the future and I think that the Iroquois Pipeline is going to be an integral part of that,'' Langdon said. Supporters of the project include Massachusetts Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., and New York Gov. Mario Cuomo. The pipeline will extend 370 miles from the St. Lawrence River through the woodlands of Upstate New York, beneath the Hudson River, into affluent sections of western Connecticut and across Long Island Sound to Long Island. Iroquois officials hope to have gas flowing to New York and New England by November 1991 and to complete the line by January 1992. ``It's a great day,'' said Robert J. Reid, president of the Iroquois Gas Transmission System, a consortium of U.S. and Canadian gas companies and utilities based in Shelton, Conn. ``It was imperative that we receive FERC approval in November to maintain our timetable for constructing the pipeline.'' Iroquois is designed to deliver 575 million cubic feet of gas daily, or enough to meet the energy needs of 1.5 million homes. Iroquois still has regulatory hurdles to clear including permits from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and the Department of Energy. Thousands of property owners along the route have not yet agreed to let Iroquois pay for right-of-way privileges across their land. Iroquois may have to settle some of those cases in court. A Hudson Valley citizens group called GASP has promised to file an immediate appeal with FERC and, if that fails, to appeal the decision in federal court. Domestic energy suppliers complained that Iroquois will discourage domestic energy exploration and production and will compete unfairly with U.S. pipelines and oil companies. Iroquois' affiliates include Connecticut Natural Gas Corp., Brooklyn Union Gas Co., TransCanada PipeLines Ltd., and the New York Power Authority. Customers include Long Island Lighting Co., Boston Gas Co., and Consolidated Edison Co. of New York.

DOC.HEAD: Southland's Losses Mount in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Southland Corp., which filed for bankruptcy last month, said Wednesday it lost nearly twice as much money in the third quarter as it did in the same period last year. Southland showed a smaller loss for the nine months that ended Sept. 30 than in the same period of 1989, however, and it reported higher revenues. Southland owns 7-Eleven, the nation's largest convenience store chain. The company lost $122.5 million, or 61 cents a share, on revenue of $2.26 billion in the third quarter. That compares to a loss of $63.4 million, or 33 cents a share, on revenue of $2.23 billion in the same quarter a year ago. The burden of paying off a $4.9 billion takeover financed with debt forced the company to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last month. The filing allows Southland to operate under court supervision while it develops a plan to pay creditors. Southland submitted a ``prepackaged'' reorganization plan that had won approval from 90 percent of its creditors. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Harold C. Abramson set a Dec. 14 confirmation hearing for the plan. On Wednesday, the company said it had sufficient working capital to maintain normal operations at its convenience stores, distribution and food centers. Sales at comparable stores rose 1.1 percent during the quarter and 2.4 percent during the first nine months. But gross profits from those sales declined in the quarter and was up only slightly for the nine months because there were fewer 7-Eleven stores. For the nine-month period, Southland lost $250.0 million, or $1.26 a share, on revenue of $6.35 billion. In the 1989 period it lost $299.8 million, or $1.55 a share, on revenue of $6.29 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Meet to Discuss $700 Million Suit Against Chevron USA
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys representing both sides in a $700 million class-action lawsuit against Chevron USA Corp. met for the first time Wednesday under a federal judge's order, a lawyer said. The attorneys, who discussed the lawsuit for about six hours, planned to meet again Thursday, said Jo Wilson, attorney for the plaintiffs, who would not comment on the discussions. ``We're hopeful we will be able to report some progress to the judge on Monday,'' she said. The lawsuit was filed in 1986 on behalf of more than 40,000 former Gulf Oil Corp. employees, retirees and Chevron employees who previously worked for Gulf and their family members. Plaintiffs allege San Francisco-based Chevron violated the federal Employment Retirement Income Security Act when it merged the Chevron and Gulf pension plans two years after it acquired Gulf Oil, of Pittsburgh. They also complained that many Gulf employees who did not end up with jobs at Chevron were unjustly denied pension benefits. Ms. Wilson has said the Gulf plan had $700 million in surplus funds when Chevron merged the plans in 1986. Since the merger, she said, Gulf retirees have found their benefits reduced by about 20 percent. Chevron attorneys say the company has not touched any of the money in the merged pension fund for other corporate purposes, and an ongoing pension plan cannot have excess assets. U.S. District Judge Simeon T. Lake III last week ordered attorneys from both sides and Chevron officials to begin negotiations ``in good faith towards a settlement,'' Ms. Wilson said. Houston attorney Robert J. Malinak, who represents Chevron in the case, did not return a telephone call Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Amax Subsidiary Acquires More Gas Reserves
DOC.TEXT: A subsidiary of Amax Inc. has agreed to buy the capital stock of Ladd Petroleum Corp. for $515 million, the companies said Wednesday. Ladd, a subsidiary of General Electric Co., is an oil and natural gas producer in the United States and Canada. It has 650 miles of pipelines and proven and probable reserves of about 500 billion cubic feet. The Ladd stock will be purchased by Amax Oil & Gas Inc., a Houston-based Amax subsidiary with interests in 1,500 natural gas wells and about 500 billion cubic feet of gas reserves. Allen Born, Amax's chairman and chief exeuctive officer, said Ladd's assets and operations will make a good strategic fit with his company's and provide Amax with a strong position in the natural gas marketplace. Both firms' properties are concentrated in the Gulf Coast, Texas and Oklahoma. The deal is expected to close by the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Third-Quarter Loss
With AM-Eastern, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines, its survival on the line, Wednesday reported a net loss of $252.8 million for the third quarter. The carrier said two major non-recurring items had an enormous impact on the quarter, with Eastern gaining $212.3 million on assets sales and losing $284.8 million to a settlement with the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp. on the company's fixed benefit pension plans. The net loss without those two items was $180.3 million, Eastern said. The company reported $518.3 million in operating revenues for the quarter ending Sept. 30. The carrier said year-earlier figures weren't directly comparable because of the March 1989 strike, which drastically curtailed the airline's operations for months. It has been operating under bankruptcy court protection since then. Eastern said its quarterly performance also suffered from a near-doubling of fuel prices in August and September, stemming from the Persian Gulf crisis. For the first nine months of 1990, Eastern's operating revenues were $1.621 billion with a net loss of $424.9 million, after a gain of $361.3 million on the sale of assets and after the $284.8 million charge in the pension settlement. For the same period in 1989, Eastern had operating revenues of $1.016 billion, with a net loss of $569.7 million.

DOC.HEAD: Recreational Vehicle Maker Files in Bankruptcy Court
DOC.TEXT: Starcraft Corp., a recreational vehicle company, filed for protection from creditors in federal bankruptcy court Wednesday, blaming high gasoline prices, the threat of war, and a weakening economy. Chairman Michael Bell said he expects Starcraft and its subsidiaries will pay off their debts and emerge from court-directed reorganization ``in a healthy condition.'' In a statement released through the company's attorneys, Bell cited ``high and fluctuating domestic gasoline prices, the ongoing Middle East crisis and the perception of an approaching economic recession.'' Van conversions, an important segment of Starcraft's business, shrank at least 30 percent in September, a month after Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait and gasoline prices began rising, according to Ford Motor Co. and General Motors Corp., the largest suppliers of van chassis to the conversion industry. Last month Starcraft laid off 30 employees at its headquarters. The company employs about 400 people at offices and a van conversion plant in Goshen, Ind., and about 300 at a travel trailer and motorhome plant in Topeka, Ind. The company earlier had closed production facilities in Corcoran, Calif., and Delhi, La. Last year Starcraft began production of an expensive line of motorhomes, some of which retail in the range of $100,000, just as demand began falling, but chief financial officer Richard Newberry said last month he expected to sell the remaining inventory. Starcraft had failed to make a $2.1 million interest payment to bondholders in mid-July, and Bell entered talks with holders of $25 million of 16.5 percent notes. In his statement, Bell said the ``major financial lender to Starcraft Corp. has entered an agreement to continue working capital availability to the companies.'' Starcraft subsidiaries are Starcraft Van Conversions Corp., Starcraft Recreational Products Corp., and Starcraft Transportation Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Tumbles; Grains and Soybeans Prices Fall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS third graf to CORRECT December gold price; PICK UP 4th graf, Gold began ...
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices tumbled Wednesday on New York's Commodity Exchange in a session marked by growing recession fears and reaction to White House actions concerning the situation in the Persian Gulf. On other commodities markets, silver, platinum and energy futures prices slipped; grains and soybeans prices collapsed; cattle futures rose; and pork futures were mixed. Gold settled $8.70 to $8.50 lower with December at $378.50 a troy ounce. Gold began falling in early trading amid profit-taking from Tuesday's gains and closed sharply lower after trading was stopped several times by an automatically triggered mechanism activated when prices go below a set figure. ``Basically, two events caused the drop,'' said Peter Cardillo, director of commodities research for Jesup, Josephtal & Co. Inc. in New York. ``There was confusion over whether or not the Federal Reserve has eased interest rates and statements out of the White House suggesting they were not going to call a special session of Congress to debate the gulf crisis.'' Silver and platinum prices followed gold, Cardillo said. Silver settled 4.3 cents to 3.4 cents lower with December at $4.175 an ounce. Platinum settled $5.90 lower across the board with January at $413.90. Energy futures also fell the New York Mercantile Exchange on recessionary fears and continued attention to events connected to the Persian Gulf. Light sweet crude settled $1.96 to 26 cents lower with December at $31.16 a barrel; heating oil settled 1.91 cents to 1.36 cents lower with December at 86.64 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline settled 2.72 cents to 1.41 cents lower with December at 80.39 cents a gallon. Grains and soybeans futures prices tumbled for the fourth consecutive session on the Chicago Board of Trade as speculators fretted over abundant supplies and poor demand. Follow-through selling from Tuesday's poor close pressured futures throughout the day as commercial firms cashed in, in light of good harvesting weather in the regions where the crops are grown. Corn, soybeans and wheat are all suffering from near-record harvests and little export demand, and prices have slumped as speculators move to the sidelines waiting for activity. ``We haven't seen any things confirmed in terms of export activity,'' said Mark Weidner, an analyst for Cargill Investor Services Inc. ``Without confirmation or seeing shipments going out, rumors of activity will be just that and we'll continue to see falling prices.'' Soybeans also have suffered from a government report issued last week that found a higher than expected supply of the crop than was previously expected. Reports of Taiwan's purchase of 20,000 tons of the crop and talk that Israel and Mexico also may be in the market failed to slow the future's slide. Wheat futures settled 7} cents to 6 cents lower with December at $2.55\ a bushel; corn futures were 6\ cents to 5 cents lower with December at $2.24 a bushel; oats were 5\ cents to 4 cents lower with December at $1.07} a bushel; soybeans were 10{ cents to 5} cents lower with November at $5.54\ a bushel. Cattle futures prices were spurred another day by strong cash market sales on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, but pork futures prices were mixed to lower as trade took profits on gains made this week. Live cattle settled .15 cent to .55 cent higher with December at 79.12 cents a pound; feeder cattle was .20 cent to .80 cent higher with November at 88.55 cents a pound; hogs were .60 cent lower to .25 cent higher with December at 53.90 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.02 cents to .10 cent lower with February at 72.05 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Bally Reports $84.7 Million Loss, Misses Loan Payment
DOC.TEXT: Bally Manufacturing Corp. on Wednesday reported a third-quarter loss of $84.7 million and said the company missed an $18.4 million payment to bondholders. The Chicago-based company said the loss of $3.02 per share for the three months ending Sept. 30 compared with a loss of $3.71 million, or 21 cents per share, for the same period a year ago. The results for the latest quarter included $9.1 million in litigation costs and a $69 million write-off in intangible assets, all related to a missed payment Oct. 15 on $1.8 billion in debt from a restructuring of Bally's Nevada casino subsidiary. Wednesday ended a 30-day grace period for Bally to make the loan payment, said Bally spokeswoman Janie Lewis. She said the company was ``still in negotiations with our bondholders'' on a debt restructuring plan. The third-quarter 1989 results included an $8.4 million expense associated with the refinancing of Bally's Park Place casino hotel in Atlantic City. Excluding extraordinary items, Bally posted a net loss of $6.5 million in the third quarter compared with a gain of $4.7 million a year ago. Third-quarter revenues rose to $531.3 million from $530.4 million, Bally said in a statement. Bally operates four casino hotels and numerous fitness centers across the country and also markets a line of gaming equipment of securities fraud at sentencing by U.S. District Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum. Mulheren did not address the court before sentencing. He relied on statements by Puccio, who asked for leniency because Mulheren suffered from manic depression and because of his many charitable acts. ``The most we have here is someone who momentarily strayed and committed one act on one day against a lifetime of honesty and respectability,'' Puccio said. Cedarbaum said Mulheren's crimes required incarceration. ``Anyone who tampers with the integrity of the stock market will go to prison.'' After sentencing Mulheren to a year and one day in prison, Cedarbaum allowed him to remain free pending appeal. If his conviction is upheld, it is unlikely Mulheren will serve the entire sentence because he will be eligible for parole after serving four months. Asked his reaction to the sentence, Mulheren said, ``Nobody likes to go to jail, right?'' Prosecutors had charged that Mulheren bought 75,000 Gulf & Western shares at Boesky's behest, driving the stock to $45 a share, the price at which Boesky wanted to sell about 3.5 million shares back to the company. Boesky - the ex-stock speculator whose admissions led to several prominent indictments on Wall Street - agreed in 1986 to plead guilty to one count of lying to federal investigators and pay $100 million in fines. He was released from custody in April after serving two years of a three-year term. The high point of Mulheren's trial came when Boesky was called as a prosecution witness against his former business associate and friend. Boesky admitted he traded suitcases stuffed with cash for confidential information about imminent takeovers. Mulheren, a laid-back multimillionaire who often flew by helicopter to his trial, flouted convention in court as he had in his Wall Street career. During testimony, Mulheren wore a tennis shirt, blue jeans and boat shoes. In 1988, after learning Boesky had implicated him, Mulheren was arrested leaving his Rumson, N.J., mansion carrying a loaded assault rifle. Police said he planned to shoot Boesky. Authorities in New Jersey last year dropped weapons possession charges. Mulheren's lawyers blamed the incident, which was not disclosed at the trial, on his failure to take lithium prescribed to treat manic depression. Some criminal charges against Mulheren remain because the jury was unable to reach a verdict on 26 additional counts of securities fraud, mail fraud and record-keeping violations. Cedarbaum declared a mistrial on that portion of the case and the government has yet to decide whether to retry Mulheren on the pending counts. Those charges alleged Mulheren ``parked'' for Boesky securities of Unocal Corp., Warner Communications Inc., Storer Communications Inc., Boise Cascade Corp., American Hospital Supply Inc. and R.H. Macy & Co. Parking is the illegal practice of disguising ownership of securities to avoid federal reporting requirements. Mulheren's co-defendant, Leonard DeStefano, 34, a former trader at Mulheren's defunct firm Jamie Securities Co., was acquitted of all conspiracy and record-keeping violations charges brought against him.

DOC.HEAD: Western Union Losses Continue to Grow
DOC.TEXT: Western Union's losses continued to grow in the third quarter, doubling because of the company's huge debt, the communications firm said Wednesday. Western Union said its loss for the three-month period ending Sept. 30 was $26.6 million, or 42 cents a share, on revenues of $145 million. In the same period last year, the company lost $13.1 million, or 47 cents a share, on revenue of $157 million. Many preferred stock shareholders converted their securities into common stock, raising the number of outstanding shares and affecting the earnings per share figure. The losses stem from debt load the company has been forced to carry for the past six years, spokesman Warren R. Bechtel said Wednesday. Fees to financial advisers, lawyers and other services are also piling up as the company tries to restructure the debt, he said. Preparing for a threatened strike by the Communications Workers of America in August also ate into third quarter earnings, Bechtel said. The biggest revenue loser was Telex, Bechtel said, although he would not specify the revenues and expenses of each of Western Union's business and financial services. For the first nine months of the year, Western Union lost $72.3 million, or $1.22 per share, on revenues of $436.3 million. In the same period last year, Western Union lost $18.1 million, or $1.12 per share, on revenue of $474.1 million.

DOC.HEAD: Transportation Department Approves United Chicago-Tokyo Flights
DOC.TEXT: Federal transportation officials gave final approval Wednesday to United Airlines' planned new routes between Chicago and Tokyo. The Department of Transportation approved the routes over the objections of American Airlines, which had sought to offer the service. United applied two years ago for permission to offer non-stop service between the two cities. ``We are elated by the final decision to entrust this valuable route to United,'' said Stephen M. Wolf, chairman of UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines. United plans to begin the new flights Jan. 8, using new 747-400 aircraft and offering same-plane service to Washington, D.C.'s Dulles International Airport.

DOC.HEAD: Fast-Food Giant Test Markets Low-Fat Burgers
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's Corp. on Wednesday announced it is test marketing a low-fat hamburger that trade groups said could help woo health-conscious consumers. But nutrition experts cautioned that the efforts of McDonald's and its competitors, such as Hardee's and Wendy's, do not mean fast-food has become health food. The new hamburger, called the Lean Deluxe, boasts a 91 percent fat-free beef patty. Counting the sesame seed bun and fixings - ketchup, mustard, pickles, onions, lettuce and tomatoes - it has a 10.5 percent fat content and 310 calories. That compares to a 20.7 percent fat content and about 410 calories in a Quarter Pounder. The burger is currently being test-marketed in 54 franchises in the Harrisburg, Pa. area, said Chuck Rubner, a spokesman for the Oak Brook, Ill.-based company. ``We're excited about it and are very optimistic,'' Rubner said. ``They like the taste of the product and they like the fact that it's a low-fat alternative.'' There currently are no plans to nationally market the hamburger. The patty is composed of 90 percent lean beef, 9 percent water and 1 percent seasonings, Rubner said. Among the items listed as seasonings is carrageenan, a gum-like product used in meats and other foods to bind the ingredients. The carrageenan, which does the binding job of fat, is the secret to the patty, said Mary Adolf, a spokeswoman for the Beef Industry Council of the Meat Board. The board funded work by Auburn University to develop the low-fat beef and Ms. Adolf said McDonald's is the first to test-market the technology. Hardee's Food Systems Inc. earlier this year test marketed in four cities an 84 percent fat-free hamburger and plans to sell it nationally in 1991, said John Merritt, a spokesman for the Rocky Mountain, N.C.-based company. The Dallas-based American Heart Association and the Center for Science in the Public Interest in Washington, D.C., said there currently is no other fast-food chain marketing a hamburger with as low a fat content as McDonald's claims. Nutrition experts welcomed the development, but cautioned that one new product in a menu loaded with fat and cholesterol is not a healthy substitute. ``One has to look at a food's place in relation to the total diet,'' said Karen Miller-Kovach, a spokeswoman for the American Dietetic Association. ``If you go into a restaurant, order the (fat-free) burger and an extra-large order of fries, then you may not be doing yourself any favor.'' The new hamburger also does little to reduce sodium content, said Michael Jacobson, director of the Center for Science in the Public Interest. ``The (regular) Quarter Pounder has 660 milligrams of sodium,'' compared to 650 milligrams in the Lean Deluxe. ``That level is what I consider a dangerously unhealthy amount,'' he said in a telephone interview. Miller-Kovach said the Lean Deluxe is part of a growing health trend for fast-food companies like McDonald's and Wendy's, which recently introduced a grilled chicken breast sandwich. ``What we're seeing is a change in the fast-food menu - not necessarily away from the old-time fat-filled and greasy foods that have made fast-food companies fat and happy - but to provide other alternatives for customers,'' she said. Rubner noted that McDonald's has also added low-fat milkshakes and yogurt, whole grain cereals and switched to cooking its french fries in all-vegetable oils instead of beef tallow.
